## Watch the Video[](#toc_1)

![Mastering email deliverability](https://embed-ssl.wistia.com/deliveries/004537ae19de9c597793beee11ac0ca1.webp?image_crop_resized=960x540)

## Overview[](#toc_2)

Email Service Providers (ESPs) often have strict rules to protect users from unwanted or undesirable emails. To avoid these "spam blockers" you need to follow email best practices. If you do not, your emails may bounce and never reach your intended audience. This, in turn, puts your domain health at risk.

Read on to learn how to avoid spam filters and improve email deliverability when you [send emails](https://app.apollo.io/#/sequences) via a mailbox connected to Apollo.

Let's (Not) Bounce

Please note that the guidelines below are only best practices. They are not guaranteed to eliminate all bounces or instances of spam-blocked emails. Spam filtering is user-specific—if someone marks an email as spam, their email service provider's spam filtering will update itself to catch similar emails in the future. Two people can receive the same email and encounter different filtering behavior.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Email Deliverability Best Practices[](#toc_3)

Feeling Overwhelmed and Not Sure Where to Start?

We feel you! Staying clear of spam filters can be pretty daunting. If you're short on time and want a quick summary, hop into our [email deliverability checklist](https://21165194.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/21165194/Checklists_Apollo%E2%80%99s%20Cold%20Email%20Deliverability%20Checklist.pdf) and follow the best practices to improve your email deliverability rates.

At a high level, there are 2 primary causes for email bounces and ESPs marking emails as spam:

1.  Domain reputation
2.  Email content and formatting

[Back to Top](#top)

### Domain Reputation[](#toc_4)

For a better chance of avoiding spam filters, follow the steps below to configure your domain settings.

#### Set Up the SPF, DKIM, and DMARC for Your Sending Domains[](#toc_5)

Welcome-listing your domain improves your deliverability and ISP reputation. You should configure the following domain attributes to help raise your spam score.

*   [Set Up SPF Records](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046457454861-Set-Up-Sender-Policy-Framework-SPF-Records-to-Authorize-Your-Emails): An authorization method that specifies which email servers can send and receive emails on behalf of your organization.
*   [Set Up DKIM Policies](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046544644365-Set-Up-Domain-Keys-Identified-Mail-DKIM-to-Authenticate-Your-Email): An authentication method that uses cryptography to securely encrypt and decrypt emails sent to and from your organization. It also prevents in-transit altering of sent or received messages.
*   [Set Up DMARC Policies](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046576375437): An authentication method that specifies how to handle emails that don't pass SPF and/or DKIM checks. DMARC also generates reports to prevent email spoofing.

Master of Your Domain (Providers)

The information you need to configure SPF, DMARC, and DKIM is specifically related to your domain and is not related to Apollo. Apollo doesn't have email servers. All emails are sent directly from your email provider. Instructions to configure SPF, DMARC, and DKIM vary by domain provider. Contact your domain provider to obtain this information and receive any support you need.

When you have configured SPF, DMARC, and DKIM, consider implementing the following:

#### Set Up a New Domain[](#toc_6)

This domain should be different from your primary sending domain and you should only use it to send marketing emails. Additionally, this means you can create new mailboxes from this domain and add and replace them in Apollo for each user profile. For more information on how to connect mailboxes to Apollo, refer to the [Link Your Mailbox to Apollo.io](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409127806093) article.

#### Set Up a New Tracking Domain[](#toc_7)

A tracking domain is a secondary (or sub) domain name related to your original domain. It allows Apollo to redirect a tracking pixel added to emails to track opens, clicks, and unsubscribes.

Tracking pixels are often flagged as spam. Tracking domains redirect the attention of the email from your main domain and will help with deliverability.

Follow [these instructions](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4415240542733-Set-Up-a-Custom-Tracking-Subdomain-URL-) to set up a new [tracking subdomain](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/tracking-subdomains).

Tighten Up Tracking Domains

On occasion, you may find that a server flags your domain as spam. If this happens, you can spin up a new one with the tracking subdomain. Make sure you follow the same instructions to create a new [tracking subdomain](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4415240542733-Set-Up-a-Custom-Tracking-Subdomain-URL-) with a different name to reset your deliverability if needed.

### Email Content and Formatting[](#toc_8)

*   **Remove Links from the Body of Your Email**: Spam filters look for links, especially in first-contact emails. Ensure you've removed links from your signature and in the body of your emails.
    
*   **Remove Images from the Body of Your Email**: Images or attachments, especially in automated or first-contact emails, can activate spam blockers and cause bounces. Remove these assets and stick to text. Save your images and attachments for step 3 or later in sequences once you've sent a few other emails. As with links, even images in your signature can cause issues.
    
*   **Don't Apply Special Formatting to Your Text**: Spam blockers scan for formatted text. Avoid using different colors, fonts, bolding, italicization, and underlining.
    
*   **Keep Your Paragraphs Concise**: Lengthy content can activate spam blockers or cause bounces. Keep your wording simple and to the point.
    
*   **Avoid Words that Trigger Spam Filters**: Spam filters are constantly evolving. As a result, there isn't a shortlist of words to avoid. Try to communicate in a professional, personable way. Avoid words and phrases that sound suspicious, urgent, or needy. As a best practice, ask yourself if the email you intend to send is one you would want to receive yourself. For further recommendations, refer to [Avoid Spam Triggers in Your Email Content](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4415045401485-How-Do-I-Write-Effective-Sales-Emails-#toc_9).
    
*   **A/B Test Your Messaging**: Always test your messaging to see what works best. You can [A/B test in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4410749683597-Add-an-A-B-Test-to-an-Email-Step-in-a-Sequence) to try multiple versions of a message. If one version has a higher bounce rate, compare the differences to understand the cause.
    

[Back to Top](#top)

### Additional Considerations[](#toc_9)

Still having issues with spam-blocked emails? Here are some additional steps you can take:

*   **Connect Apollo to a SendGrid or Mailgun Account**: SendGrid and Mailgun are mass emailing services that use their own email servers. They also replace the tracking URLs and direct them to their servers to resolve deliverability issues. If you already use SendGrid or Mailgun, you can integrate your account with Apollo. If you do so, you do not need to configure a tracking subdomain. SendGrid and Mailgun manage your tracking links on their end.
    
    For Old-Timers Only!
    
    Please note, Apollo only recommends integrating with your SendGrid or Mailgun account if you already actively use their platform for transactional or marketing emails related to your service or product. If you don't, consider using [this Apollo partner](https://agencies.apollo.io/partners/senders) to help you follow deliverability best practices.
    
    Click [here](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4414449230093) for more info on the SendGrid integration or [here](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8688131737229-Integrate-Mailgun-with-Apollo) for more on the Mailgun integration.
    
    There Can Only Be One (Tracking Link)
    
    If you've connected your Apollo account to SendGrid or Mailgun and your emails are flagged as spam, you may need to replace the tracking link within your SendGrid or Mailgun account. Both platforms provide a feature that functions like Apollo's tracking subdomain. For more info and support on deliverability with your SendGrid or Mailgun account, refer to [this help article](https://docs.sendgrid.com/ui/account-and-settings/how-to-set-up-link-branding#what-is-link-branding) for SendGrid or [this support article](https://docs.sendgrid.com/ui/account-and-settings/how-to-set-up-link-branding#what-is-link-branding) for Mailgun.
    

*   **Include an Unsubscribe Link in Your Email Signature**: Customize the text in an opt-out link from your [email settings](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/account). Apollo then automatically adds the link with your signature on all of the emails you send via mailboxes connected to Apollo. Recipients are more likely to click an unsubscribe link instead of marking your emails as spam. When a recipient unsubscribes, it does not affect your overall sending reputation. If they mark you as spam, it does. For more info on how to configure your unsubscribe link, refer to [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409140379661-Configure-Your-Opt-Out-Unsubscribe-Email-Link).

*   **Update Apollo Send Limits**: Head to **Settings**, click **You**, and then click the [**Mailboxes**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/account/mailboxes) tab. Click a mailbox and consider lowering the sending limits to 50 emails per day with a delay of 90s between each email. For more info, refer to the [Email Sending Limits Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409233349005-Email-Sending-Limits-Overview) article. Want to follow best practices but need to send more emails? You can [**link more mailboxes**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409127806093-Link-Your-Mailbox-to-Apollo-io) to send a higher volume of emails without putting your domain at risk. [![Send Limits](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/avoid_spam_filters/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/avoid_spam_filters/i1.png)

*   **Only Send Messages to Contacts with Verified Emails**: Use the [email status filter](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423314404621-Email-Status-Overview) and the [date refreshed in Apollo filter](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ur1X4mLDFf4&t=642s) when prospecting. You should only add contacts with valid, up-to-date emails into your sequences.
    
    Stop, in the Name of Accuracy!
    
    If a contact with a [verified email](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423314404621-Email-Status-Overview) spam blocks you, it doesn't mean the email address is inaccurate. It means the contact likely exists and your email was either automatically or manually marked as unfit or inappropriate for delivery.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Buying intent helps you engage with the right prospects from the right companies at the right time. With timely insights into the online intent-to-buy behaviors of your ideal customer profiles, buying intent allows you to easily identify the solutions and products that your target markets are actively researching online.

Once you have identified your ideal customer profiles in Apollo, you can use buying intent to visualize key online behavior, filter by the ideal companies with the highest intent scores for your selected topics, and prioritize your pipeline accordingly.

Plan Your Topics and Filters

Your access to buying intent topics and search filters depends on your Apollo plan. Refer to [Apollo's pricing page](https://www.apollo.io/pricing) for more details.

The following sections details how Apollo calculates and sources buying intent, and the different intent topics available to you.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Understand Intent Signals[](#toc_2)

Apollo partners with buying intent data providers Bombora and LeadSift (a Foundry company) to provide buying intent signals. For more information about how these Apollo partners collect intent data, please refer to Bombora's [intent data overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9296665299213) and Foundry's[intent data product information](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9296665299213).

To utilize buying intent signals in Apollo, you must first select [intent topics](#select-intent-topics). These are the different keywords and competitors that you are targeting. When a company actively searches for 1 of your selected intent topics, this triggers an intent signal. Apollo captures and updates intent signals weekly. Based on the frequency, trend, and recency that these intent signals fire, Apollo calculates [intent score](#intent-scores) for companies.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Intent Topics[](#toc_3)

Intent topics are products and services that prospects actively research online across social media, company websites, job boards, news sites, and other sources. It can be a keyword or even competitor names.

In Apollo, you can choose from over 14,000 intent topics from Bombora, and over 1,600 intent topics from LeadSift within 110 broader categories such as 3D software, sales, and financial services. Refer to [Intent Topics](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9296665299213) for a complete list of available topics.

You can find powerful granularity when searching at the intent topic level in Apollo. This means that you can apply the specific intent topics that best fit your market, even if it is very niche.

For example, if you are in the development tools industry, you could apply something granular to your search such as "artificial neural network software," "cookie and website tracker scanning software," or "augmented reality SDK software," to name just a few of your available options.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Intent Scores[](#toc_4)

Apollo uses data from Bombora and LeadSift to calculate intent scores. This score indicates the strength of a company's buying intent. A higher intent score indicates a contact is more likely to engage with your company and convert into paying customers.

When Bombora provides an intent topic, Apollo utilizes the accompanying intent score that is placed in a range of 0-100. Apollo considers scores from 0-61 to be low, 62-75 to be mid, and 75-100 to be high.

When LeadSift provides an intent topics, Apollo's proprietary algorithm calculates intent scores based on the following components:

*   **Frequency**: How often is a company searching for a particular topic with intent? For example, a company triggers 3 signals within the last 3 months.
*   **Trend**: Has there been an upward or downward trend in the search for a particular intent topic over the last 30 days in comparison to the previous 30 days?
*   **Recency**: When was the last time a company searched for the intent topic? For example, the intent score could be different if the most recent search was 1 week ago or 1 month ago.

Apollo considers each of these components when giving the company a score based on LeadSift's data, and then groups the scores into the following categories:

*   **High**: A company triggers at least 4 intent signals in the last 90 days or demonstrates an upward trend with at least 2 intent signals in the last week.
*   **Medium**: A company triggers at least 2 intent signals in the last 90 days and at least 1 intent signal in the last 2 weeks.
*   **Low**: A company triggers at least 1 intent signal in the last 90 days.

If both Bombora and LeadSift provide data for an intent topic, Apollo chooses the higher score between the 2 sources.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Search For Articles[](#toc_4)

To search for a specific article in the Apollo Knowledge Base:

1.  Use the search bar on the [homepage](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us) to find articles using keywords. You can also see _where_ in the knowledge base the article is. This makes it easy to find related content in the future. [![Search Bar](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/knowledge_base_guide/i1a.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/knowledge_base_guide/i1a.png)
2.  If the results you expect are not in the preview, hit **Return** on your keyboard to load a full list of results. [![Full Results](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/knowledge_base_guide/i2a.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/knowledge_base_guide/i2a.png)
3.  Click on a section in the navbar to narrow your search. [![Narrow Search](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/knowledge_base_guide/i3a.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/knowledge_base_guide/i3a.png)
4.  Apollo Knowledge Base articles use tags that mimic the structure of [the Apollo.io platform](https://app.apollo.io/#/control-center). This means you can use keywords like **Home**, **Search**, **Engage**, **Plays**, **Enrich**, **Deals**, and **Settings** to find articles specifically related to that part of the platform.
    *   In addition, Apollo tags each article with the related feature and keywords so you can search using terms like **sequences**, **CRM**, **CSV**, and any other related keywords.
5.  You can also use one of the following modifiers on your search to show a specific type of article:
    *   **How-to**: Articles that explain a process or teach you how to use a specific feature.
    *   **Overview**: Articles that provide contextual information and top faqs about a feature or function in the platform.

## Overview[](#toc_0)

Buying intent helps you engage with the right prospects from the right companies at the right time. With timely insights into the online intent-to-buy behaviors of your ideal customer profiles, buying intent allows you to easily identify the solutions and products that your target markets are actively researching online.

You can leverage buying intent in Apollo to prospect smarter. When the individuals within a company search with intent for topics related to your product or service, this fires an [intent signal](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8047704465933#toc_3). Apollo ranks these companies by [intent score](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8047704465933#toc_4). This means that you can easily identify and target the right companies that are actively searching for a solution that your company provides.

Plan Your Topics and Filters

Your access to buying intent topics and search filters depends on your Apollo plan. Refer to [Apollo's pricing page](https://www.apollo.io/pricing) for more details.

The following sections provide more information about how to configure the settings, leverage buying intent when prospecting in Apollo, and filter by intent topics and intent scores.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Select Your Intent Topics[](#toc_1)

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Buying Intent**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/intent-data).
2.  Click the checkboxes next to the topic(s) you want to use. Then, click **Save Intent Topics**. [![Choose your intent topics.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i24.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i24.png)
3.  You and your team cannot change the intent topics again for 24 hours. If you want to make the changes, click **Save Intent Topics** again.

You have now selected your intent topic(s).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Filter Companies By Intent Score[](#toc_2)

To filter your Apollo search results by intent score:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Search**, then click either [**People**](https://app.apollo.io/#/people) or [**Companies**](https://app.apollo.io/#/companies).
2.  Click the **Buying Intent** drop-down. From here, you can filter by intent score, intent topics, and time range. [![Find the buying intent filters.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i30.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i30.png)
3.  Click the checkboxes for the intent scores and topics that you want to apply to your search. Apollo updates the search results as you change the filters. [![Filter By buying intent.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i26.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i26.png)
4.  Apply any other filters that you want to add to your search. Then, click the **Net New** tab to access qualified prospects that match your buying intent filters.

You have now applied the buying intent filters to a search.

To save the your search, click **Save Search**. You can also set up alerts for whenever new records match your saved search.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Access Intent Data When Prospecting Companies[](#toc_3)

With your intent topics added, you can view all the companies that have shown buying intent related to your selected topics. To do so:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Search** > [**Companies**](https://app.apollo.io/#/companies).
2.  Apply filters to your search. Then, click the **Net New** or **Saved** tab. [![Filter search results.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i29.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i29.png)
3.  In the search results, Apollo displays an intent signal bar next to any companies that have shown high, medium, or low intent for your selected topics. No bar displays for companies that do not show buying intent.
    
    Hover over the intent signal bar to access the insights. The graph shows historical movement of the score over the previous 90 days.
    
    [![Access more intent information.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i28.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i28.png)
    

You have now accessed intent data when prospecting companies in Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Edit Your Intent Topic(s)[](#toc_4)

To make changes to your intent topic selections from the search page:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Search**, then click either [**People**](https://app.apollo.io/#/people) or [**Companies**](https://app.apollo.io/#/companies).
2.  Click the **Buying Intent** drop-down, then click **Edit**. [![Change intent topics.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i23.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/leverage_intent_data_in_apollo/i23.png)
3.  Click the checkboxes next to the topic(s) that you want to add or remove. You and your team cannot change the intent topics again for 24 hours. Make sure you want to make the changes, then click **Save**.

You have now edited your intent topics.

## Overview[](#toc_0)

The website visitors feature enables you to track the accounts that have visited your websites. This means you can uncover the names of companies that have generated activity on the domains you choose to track and filter them based on when they visited and how engaged they are in the buying process.

Using Apollo to track your website visitors reduces the need for your sales team to coordinate with your own IT and marketing teams to understand whether prospects are actively engaged with your websites. You can also use [more search filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661) to further reduce the noise in your visitors data and target only your ideal prospects based on company information.

Refer to the following sections to learn how to track your websites' visitors and view the related data in Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Set Up Tracking[](#toc_1)

### Step 0: Before You Begin[](#toc_2)

Apollo admins can complete the instructions provided in [step 1](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389#toc_3) and [step 3](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389#toc_5) of this article. Technical skills are not required.

The instructions in [step 2](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389#toc_4) require either knowledge of HTML and a front-end language like JavaScript, along with access to your website's codebase, or access to a tool such as Google Tag Manager. If you or your team do not have access or the technical skills needed, work with your organization to arrange the necessary help.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Step 1: Add Website Domains[](#toc_3)

To add the websites that you want to track and find the Apollo JavaScript snippet:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > **Prospecting** > [**Website visitors**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/websites).
2.  Click **Add Domain**. [![Add a domain to track.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i51.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i51.png)
3.  Enter the URL for the website where you want to track traffic.
    
    (Optional) For the domain you added, open the **Advanced Intent Settings** drop-down to set the scoring criteria for your website visitors. Your scoring criteria establishes how important visits to specific website pages are to you, and helps you identify accounts showing a strong interest in your product when \[viewing your website visitor data\](#view-your-website-visitor-data).
    
    For example, if you believe that visits to your pricing page represent a strong interest in your product, you might want to set **Page URL** to your pricing page's URL and **Intent** to `High`. [![Enter domain details and intent scoring.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i28.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i28.png)
    
4.  Click **Save**.
5.  In the **Apollo Script** section, click **Copy Code**. Do not attempt to copy or type the code manually. If you're not the one adding the code to your website, send the copied JavaScript snippet to the personnel responsible. [![CAPTION](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i29.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i29.png)

If you want to add more domains to track, click **Add domain** and repeat this process.

Otherwise, you or your designated personnel can proceed to [Step 2](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389#toc_4).

[Back to Top](#top)

### Step 2: Add the JS Snippet to Your Website[](#toc_4)

There are 2 options for adding the JS snippet to your website: adding it directly to your website's code, or using Google Tag Manager.

**Direct**

Add the JavaScript snippet generated in [Step 1](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389#toc_3) to your website's code.

The snippet can either be inserted between the `head` tags of a website's HTML, or in the code for a specific page you want to track. The snippet should be included for every page that you want to track.

With the snippet added to your website, proceed to [Step 3](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389#toc_5).

**Google Tag Manager**

Helping Hand

If you have never used Google Tag Manager and need help getting started, please refer to Google's [Tag Manager documentation](https://support.google.com/tagmanager/).

To utilize Google Tag Manager to add the JavaScript snippet generated in [Step 1](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389#toc_3):

1.  Go to [Google Tag Manager](https://tagmanager.google.com/) and log in to your account. Then, select the workspace that you want to use to manage this tag.
2.  Click **Tags** **New** to add a new tag. [![Add a new tag.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i17.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i17.png)
3.  Click the pencil icon to edit the tag configuration, then select **Custom HTML** for the tag type. [![Add a Custom HTML tag.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i10.png)
4.  Paste the Apollo JS snippet into the HTML section. [![Paste the JS snippet.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i11.png)
5.  Click the pencil icon to edit the tag trigger, then choose which pages on your website should trigger the tag. Select **All Pages** to trigger the tag across your website. Then, click **Save**. [![Add a tag trigger.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i14.png)
6.  To publish the container, click **Submit**, then click **Publish**.

Your tag is now added to Google Tag Manager. With the snippet added to your website, proceed to [Step 3](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389#toc_5).

[Back to Top](#top)

### Step 3: Test the Connection[](#toc_5)

With the JS snippet added to your website, you should test the connection to ensure that Apollo is able to capture and analyze the traffic from your added domain.

To test the connection:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > **Prospecting** > [**Website visitors**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/websites).
2.  Click **Test connection** to test all of your websites. If a domain's connection is good, the status will be `Active`. [![Test your domain connections.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i30.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i30.png)

If your connection is successful, it takes up to 24 hours for data to reflect in Apollo. Then, you can start to use visitor data as accounts generate activity on your website.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Use Website Visitors Data[](#toc_6)

Check out [Use Website Visitors Data](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/26595261473805) to learn how to use website visitors data as a search filter, view visitor data as a dashboard, and build plays using the website visitors filter.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Edit Domain Information or Disable Tracking[](#toc_7)

To edit the information for a website you are tracking, or disable the tracking entirely, launch Apollo and click **Settings** > **Prospecting** > [**Website visitors**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/websites). Then, click the **pencil** icon to edit website information, or click the **trash can** icon to remove tracking for the domain.

[![Edit or delete domains.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i53.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i53.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Apollo offers 4 types of plans: Free, basic, professional, and custom/organization. If you want to experience the difference between your free plan and the features available in a paid plan, you can experiment for yourself with a free trial.

There are several advantages of an Apollo free trial:

*   Try before you buy!
*   You know exactly what you're getting and have full transparency about what is and isn't included in the new plan. This means that if you do choose to upgrade when the trial ends, you will have peace of mind from day 1.

Apollo offers 2 free trial plans for users:

*   Basic
*   Professional

Record Limits

Please note, the record selection limit remains capped at 25 for the duration of your free trial. If you choose to upgrade at the end of your trial, Apollo unlocks the higher record selection and credit limits, according to [the plan](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/plans/upgrade) you choose.

### Basic[](#toc_2)

This trial lasts for 14 days. Within this period, you have access to the features that Apollo highlights under the basic plan on [this page](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/plans/upgrade). You also have 50 free email credits with which to experiment.

### Professional[](#toc_3)

This trial lasts for 14 days. Within this period, you have access to the features that Apollo highlights under the professional plan on [this page](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/plans/upgrade). You also have 5 free mobile credits and 50 free email credits with which to experiment.

Care and Feeding of Your Custom Plan

Please note, Apollo does not offer a free trial for custom/organization plans. Contact the [Apollo Sales Team](mailto:%20sales@apollo.io) if you would like more information or to discuss the different possibilities available to you within a custom/organization plan.

Refer to the section below to find out how to access and switch to an alternative free trial, and the next steps to take once your trial ends.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Select Your Free Trial[](#toc_4)

Launch Apollo, click the profile icon on the top right, and then click **Upgrade Plan**.

[![Profile Icon-Upgrade Plan](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_free_trial/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_free_trial/i1.png)

## Overview[](#toc_0)

If you're [tracking website visitors](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20544185285389), you receive data related to the companies that visit your domains. You can view and use this data in several ways, including:

*   Viewing activity snapshots for individual company visits.
*   Viewing an analytics dashboard for data across visiting companies.
*   Building plays using website visitors data as a filter.

The following sections show how to view and use website visitors data.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Filter Companies By Website Visitor Data[](#toc_1)

Once visitor data is available in Apollo, you can use the data to filter your searches. This enables you to target companies based on the recency and volume of visitors to your tracked websites.

To filter your Apollo search results by website visitor data:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Search** > [**Companies**](https://app.apollo.io/#/companies).
2.  Click the **Website Visitors** drop-down. From here, you can filter by the time period when the website visits occurred, the level of intent, and the visited domains.
    
    Open the **Advanced** drop-down to filter by specific URLs and number of page views. To filter by a URL, you must type the URL, then press `Enter` to add it. [![Find the website visitors filter.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i33.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i33.png)
    
3.  Click the **Show new companies only** checkbox to limit your search to only companies that have visited your website within the time period you selected. For example, if you limit your search to a 1 month time period, only companies that made a first visit within the last month will be shown. If a company visited 2 months ago and again 2 weeks ago, it would be filtered out of your search results. [![Search for new visitors.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i36.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i36.png)
4.  Apply any [other filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661) that you want to add to your search. Apollo updates the search results as you change the filters. [![View your search results.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i35.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i35.png)

You have now applied the **Website Visitors** filter to a search.

To save the your search, click **Save Search**. You can also [set up alerts](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409803718669) for whenever new records match your saved search.

[Back to Top](#top)

## View Website Visitor Activity Snapshot[](#toc_2)

To review visitor data for a specific company, go to a company page, then hover on the **bar graph** icon next to a company name.

The **Website Visits** pop-up shows visitor data for the company, including the total number of visitors from the company to your added domains, the most visited pages, and the number of visits to each page.

[![View website visitor data for a company.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i41.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i41.png)

You can also view visitor data for a company by hovering over the same **bar graph** icon in search results.

[![View website visitor data for a company.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i34.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i34.png)

If a company has not visited your tracked domains, the icon will not appear.

Group Think, Not Individuals

Apollo does not collect details such as names and email addresses for individual visitors to your website. Visitors data includes contacts based on activity generated by accounts, so an individual contact might or might not have visited your websites.

[Back to Top](#top)

## View Website Visitor Dashboard[](#toc_3)

To review high-level website visitor data, launch Apollo and click [**Analytics**](https://app.apollo.io/#/analytics). Then, search for and select the **Website Visitor Trends** dashboard.

[![Find the website visitors dashboard.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i48.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i48.png)

The dashboard provides data on the total number of daily visitors to your websites, the top 10 pages by number of visitors, and the top 10 companies that visited. By default, Apollo shows the last 30 days of data in the dashboard, but you can change the date range and click **Run** to adjust the presented data.

[![View website visitors data.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i49.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i49.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Build Plays Using Website Visitors Filters[](#toc_4)

Use website visitors data as a filter for your plays to target companies that have visited your websites. When [creating plays](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4413804036109), either use a trigger event that targets companies or set the target in the **If** section to **Companies**. Then, add or edit the filters in the **If** section.

Click the **Website Visitors** drop-down. From here, you can filter by the time period when the website visits occurred, the level of intent, and the visited domains. Open the **Advanced** drop-down to filter by specific URLs and number of page views. To filter by a URL, you must type the URL, then press `Enter` to add it.

[![Use website visitors data to trigger plays.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i50.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i50.png)

Save your filter selections, then finish building your play.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Sort Companies by Visit Dates and Number of Visitors[](#toc_5)

If you've already [filtered your company searches by website visitors](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/26595261473805#toc_2), you can sort the search results by the most recent date someone from the company visited your websites and the total number of website visitors from each company.

To sort based on these factors, start by [building a custom table layout](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/15065640273165) for your search results, then add the **Website Last Visit** and **Website Total Visitors** columns to your new layout.

[![Choose the website visitors columns for your table.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i44.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i44.png)

Once you finish creating your layout, the columns related to website visitors will be available in your table. Click the up/down arrows next to the column name to sort your search results that data.

[![Sort by website visitors data.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i46.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/track_first_party_intent_data/i46.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Apollo offers several advanced security protocols to give you additional layers of security that help you keep your account and data safe:

*   IP whitelisting
*   Password policy
*   Login controls
*   Single sign-on
*   Multi-factor authentication

Blessed with Admin Powers?

Please note, you must be an admin member to access the security settings in your Apollo account. Access to the advanced security protocols also depends on your Apollo plan. Please refer to the [Apollo pricing page](https://www.apollo.io/pricing#compare) for more details.

Refer to the following sections for more information on the security protocols you can configure in Apollo to add extra security to your account.

[Back to Top](#top)

## IP Whitelisting[](#toc_2)

[![IP Whitelisting](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i1.png)

Enable IP whitelisting to restrict unauthorized access to your Apollo account. When you activate IP whitelisting in Apollo, you can choose the specific IP addresses or ranges you consider trustworthy and only give those IPs access to your account.

Apollo accepts the following IP formats:

*   Single IP Address
*   IP Range
*   Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR)

Need a helping hand?

For more information and to enable IP whitelisting for your Apollo account, follow the steps in the [Enable IP Whitelisting in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20443048122637) article.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Password Policy[](#toc_3)

[![Password policy tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i2.png)

Configure password regulations for your team to increase security and improve password strength.

There are 4 password policy components in Apollo:

*   **Password complexity**: Define the compulsory characteristics of your users' passwords to prevent the use of easy-to-hack words or phrases. Enforce a mixture of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and/or non-alphanumeric characters.
*   **Password length**: Set a minimum character length to increase password strength. You can choose anywhere between 10 and 100 characters.
*   **Password expiration**: Define the number of days a user's password can remain valid before they must change it. Select a period between 10 and 365 days.
*   **Password reuse**: Prevent your team from using the same password twice. Specify whether or not users can repeat previous passwords and set a limit of between 1 and 50.

To access the password policy settings:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Security**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/security/password-policy).
2.  Click the **Password policy** tab, configure the settings according to your preferences, and then click **Save**. [![Save button in password policy tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i3.png)

You have now configured the password policy settings for your team in Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Login Controls[](#toc_4)

[![Login controls tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i4.png)

Set login controls for your team in Apollo to determine how you approach multiple login attempts and user session duration.

There are currently 2 types of login controls that you can configure for users in your Apollo account:

*   **Session timeout**: Decide when you want Apollo to automatically log users out of your account since their last sign-in. This means they must periodically re-enter their password to get back into your Apollo instance. You can choose a session timeout period of between 1 and 30 days.
*   **Failed login settings**: Choose the number of failed login attempts a user can make within a 24-hour period. You can set the cap at anywhere between 3 and 10 attempts. If a user fails to enter the correct credentials within the given limit you set, Apollo temporarily disables their access and sends password reset instructions via email.

To access the settings for login controls:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Security**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/security/login-controls).
2.  Click the **Login controls** tab, configure the settings according to your preferences, and then click **Save**. [![Save button in login controls tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i5.png)

You have now configured login controls for your team in Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Single Sign-On[](#toc_5)

[![SSO tab in security settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i6.png)

Set up single sign-on (SSO) with Okta to empower your team to securely log into multiple apps and sites with just one set of credentials.

The Okta/Apollo.io SAML integration currently supports the following features:

*   SP-initiated SSO
*   IdP-initiated SSO

[Back to Top](#top)

## Multi-factor Authentication[](#toc_6)

Mitigate security risks and add an extra layer of verification with multi-factor authentication (MFA). If you are an admin user on an [Apollo paid plan](https://www.apollo.io/pricing#compare), you can make it mandatory for users to provide at least one extra verification method on top of their username and password to gain access to your Apollo account.

Psst...You Don't Have to Be an Admin to Stay Secure!

If you're on a paid plan but aren't an admin user, you don't have to wait for an admin to get started. To configure multi-factor authentication for your own account, head to **Settings** and click the [**Multi-factor authentication**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/security) tab in your personal profile settings to get set up right away. [![MFA set up non-admin users](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i10.png)

There are currently 2 multi-factor authentication methods which you can force your users to log in to their Apollo account with:

*   **SMS**: Users receive a code to their phone via SMS in real-time any time they try to log into Apollo.
*   **Authentication app**: Users add Apollo to their authentication app and input a verification code in real-time any time they log into Apollo.

To enable multi-factor authentication for your team in Apollo:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Security**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/security).
2.  Click the **Multi-factor authentication** tab. Then, click the checkbox(es) next to the method(s) you want to enable. [![Multi-factor authentication tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i7.png)
3.  Choose when you want to enforce multi-factor authentication and then click **Enforce MFA**. [![Enforce MFA button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i8.png)
4.  You have now successfully configured multi-factor authentication for your team. Apollo then guides users through the MFA set-up steps when they next try to log into Apollo. [![MFA set up login screen for users](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_advanced_security_protocols/i9.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

Apollo's mailbox functionality works best with Gmail, but supports a variety of other providers with the aid of a third-party provider, Nylas Mail. Currently, Nylas Mail supports:

*   Microsoft Exchange
*   Office 365
*   Outlook
*   Yahoo!
*   Custom email accounts/servers

POP/POP3 Mailboxes Are Not Supported

Nylas Mail, Apollo's third-party provider for non-Gmail email syncs, does not support connecting to mailbox accounts via POP/POP3. The vast majority of mail providers who support POP3 also support the IMAP standard and can connect to Apollo that way. Nylas Mail also supports the SMTP standard.

Nylas does not currently support Titan email servers or large transactional sending services like Mandrill or Amazon SES. For that reason, Apollo cannot support linking to those services through Nylas.

High-Volume Emails

If you need to send larger-volume emails than Apollo's recommended safe sending limits, you should integrate your linked mailbox, whether it is Gmail, Microsoft Exchange, Office 365, Outlook, Yahoo!, or a custom email account, with Sendgrid. Click [here](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4414449230093-Set-Up-Configure-and-Troubleshoot-Your-SendGrid-Account) for instructions.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

A saved search allows you to quickly access and action a group of filtered people or companies. You can [prospect from saved searches](#toc_3), [share searches with your team](#toc_2), and [set search alerts](#toc_4) to access up-to-date insights about any new people or companies that match your search criteria.

Check out the following sections to learn about saved searches and search alerts.

## Save and Share a Search[](#toc_2)

To save a search:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Search** > [**People**](https://app.apollo.io/#/people) or [**Companies**](https://app.apollo.io/#/companies).
2.  Add any filters that you want to include in your search.

Filter Finder

Check out [Search Filters Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661-Search-Filters-Overview) to learn about all the available filters, including how and when to use each one.

[![An example search is shown with job title filter set to travel agent and location set to Europe](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i25.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i25.png)

3.  Click **Save Search**.

[![An example search for travel agents in Europe is saved](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i26.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i26.png)

4.  Give the search a descriptive name.

[![An example search is saved with the name Travel agents, Europe, 3 years experience](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i27.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i27.png)

5.  Click **Public** to share the search with your teammates, or click **Private** if you don't want anyone else to have access.

[![An example saved search is set to Public visibility](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i28.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i28.png)

6.  Check **Pin saved search to the sidebar** to make it easier to access.

7.  Next, set a search alert to receive [email alerts](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409803718669-Create-and-Subscribe-to-Saved-Searches#toc_4) when new people or companies match your search criteria. You can be alerted daily, weekly, or monthly so you can follow up on new prospects.

[![A search subcription alert is set to weekly](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i29.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i29.png)

You've Got Alerts

Once a search alert is enabled, the first alert arrives in your inbox a day, week, or month later. Apollo sends alerts in the morning. You only receive alerts if Apollo finds new contacts or accounts that match your saved search criteria. You can [turn off](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409803718669-Create-and-Subscribe-to-Saved-Searches#toc_4) saved search alerts at any time.

8.  Finally, select a [search table layout](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/15065640273165-Create-Custom-Layouts-for-Your-Searches) to determine the look of search results.
9.  When finished, click **Save search**.

[![The Save search button is highlighted](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i30.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i30.png)

With your saved search, you can reach out to prospects through [sequences](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409396985741) and [emails](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/15396174946445-Use-the-AI-Writing-Assistant-in-Your-Emails), [export search results to a CSV](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409237712141-Export-Contacts-from-Apollo-to-a-CSV), or [save people and companies to a list](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4413837150605-Find-Your-Ideal-Customer-Profile-and-Push-a-List-of-Contacts-to-Your-CRM#toc_10).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Access a Saved Search[](#toc_3)

You can access your own saved searches, as well as searches that have been made public by your team.

To access a saved search:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Search** > [**People**](https://app.apollo.io/#/people) or [**Companies**](https://app.apollo.io/#/companies).
2.  Click **Saved Searches**, then choose between pinned, private, or public:

*   **Pinned**: Saved searches that have been pinned by you for easy access.
*   **Private**: Saved searches only visible to you.
*   **Public**: Saved searches visible to you and your teammates.

[![The saved search tabs are highlighted with Pinned selected](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i31.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i31.png)

3.  Search by name or browse the list, then click the saved search.

[![Sample saved searches are shown with the find saved search box highlighted](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i32.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i32.png)

4.  Apollo loads the most recent search results for your search criteria. To review any new results that fit your search criteria, click **Net New**.

With your new prospects, you can reach out to people through [sequences](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409396985741) and [emails](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/15396174946445-Use-the-AI-Writing-Assistant-in-Your-Emails), [export search results to a CSV](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409237712141-Export-Contacts-from-Apollo-to-a-CSV), or [save people and companies to a prospect list](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4413837150605-Find-Your-Ideal-Customer-Profile-and-Push-a-List-of-Contacts-to-Your-CRM#toc_10).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Set a Search Alert[](#toc_4)

When you set a search alert, Apollo sends you notifications about the newest people or companies that fit your saved search criteria. You can subscribe to daily, weekly, or monthly email alerts so you can follow up on new prospects.

Make the Most of Buying Intent

The [buying intent filter](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661-Search-Filters-Overview#h_01HV4NJR6Q8T2A53R6QCSQF13V) is a great fit for search alerts. Filter for your [buying intent](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8047704465933-Buying-Intent-Overview) criteria on a saved search, then subscribe to a search alert. Apollo will send you email notifications when new companies match your buying intent criteria. Cha-ching!

To subscribe to a search alert:

1.  Launch Apollo, and click **Search** > [**People**](https://app.apollo.io/#/people) or [**Companies**](https://app.apollo.io/#/companies).
2.  Click **Saved Searches**, then choose between pinned, public, or private to find your saved search.

[![The saved search tabs are highlighted with Pinned selected](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i31.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i31.png)

You Gotta Own It

You can only set search subscription alerts on the saved searches you own. To subscribe to another person's saved search, duplicate the search. Click **...** beside the saved search > **Duplicate**, then set an alert.

3.  Click **...** > **Search Settings** for the saved search.

[![The more button beside a saved search leads to the search settings button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i33.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i33.png)

4.  Adjust the frequency you receive notifications of new matches. To deactivate the alert, select **Turn Off**.

[![The more button beside a saved search leads to the search settings button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i29.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_saved_search/i29.png)

5.  When finished, click **Update Search**.

You will receive email alerts when Apollo detects new people or companies that match your saved search criteria.

With your new prospects, you can reach out to people through [sequences](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409396985741) and [emails](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/15396174946445-Use-the-AI-Writing-Assistant-in-Your-Emails), [export search results to a CSV](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409237712141-Export-Contacts-from-Apollo-to-a-CSV), or [save people and companies to a prospect list](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4413837150605-Find-Your-Ideal-Customer-Profile-and-Push-a-List-of-Contacts-to-Your-CRM#toc_10).

## Overview[](#toc_2)

Set Up Your Signature After Connecting a Mailbox

As a best practice, you should set up your email signature after you have connected a mailbox to your Apollo account. Apollo automatically copies over the signature from your email account when you add it to the platform. If you add a signature to your account before you connect a mailbox, Apollo will not replace it with a signature found in the settings for the mailbox you connect later.

You can set up a unique signature for each mailbox that you link in Apollo.

Multi-Signature Priority

Please note, If you configure a signature in both Apollo and your connected email account, Apollo will use the signature that you add in the application to all emails sent through an Apollo sequence.

Emails sent directly from your connected mailbox outside of Apollo will not include your Apollo email signature. They will include the email signature that you have configured in your email account's settings. 

Follow the steps below to set up your email signature.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Set Up Your Email Signature[](#toc_3)

Click **Settings**.

[![Settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i1.png)

Click **Mailboxes**.

[![Mailboxes](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i2.png)

Click the mailbox you want to configure.

[![Configure](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i3.png)

Type your signature as you would like it appear in the "Email Signature" text box. The formatting options at the bottom of the text box allow you to use rich-text formatting options, include links, add images, and format the signature using raw HTML.

[![Personalize Your Signature](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i4.png)

SPAM Filters and Links

As a best practice, you should avoid including links in your signature because they may trigger SPAM filters for new contacts that you have not emailed before.

You can also re-pull your email signature directly from Gmail if your mailbox is provided by Google.

[![Re-Pull Your Signature From Gmail](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i5.png)

When you're finished, click **Save**.

[![Save](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_your_email_signature/i6.png)

## Overview[](#overview)

A **Sender Policy Framework (SPF)** record authorizes your emails with a mail server and confirms that you're the one sending e-mail from your domain. It does this by listing a range of IP addresses that are authorized to send on your behalf. A receiving email domain will likely detect anything outside of that range as a spoofed email or SPAM.

Refer to the steps below to verify and edit your domain's **SPF** records.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Check Your SPF Record Settings[](#checkyourspfrecordsettings)

Usually, your domain's **SPF** records are set by your IT department or domain/mail administrator. You can also check these records yourself with a tool like [MX Toolbox](https://mxtoolbox.com/dkim.aspx).

Within MX Toolbox, enter your domain name in the **SPF Record Lookup** bar and click the button next to it. If your email address is `tom@jerry.com`, the domain name is `jerry.com`.

[![Jerry Search](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_spf_records_to_authorize_your_emails/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_spf_records_to_authorize_your_emails/i1.png)

This domain doesn't have an **SPF** record so the tool displays "No SPF Record found" under **Result**.

[![No record](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_spf_records_to_authorize_your_emails/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_spf_records_to_authorize_your_emails/i2.png)

Conversely, if your domain does have an **SPF** record, it displays it under **Result**.

[![Has record](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_spf_records_to_authorize_your_emails/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_spf_records_to_authorize_your_emails/i4.png)

Your **SPF** record settings are now verified. Follow the steps below to fix the record (if necessary) or to confirm the settings with your IT department or domain/mail administrator.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add or Update Your SPF Record[](#addorupdateyourspfrecord)

If you followed the steps above and found an **SPF** record, there's no need to add or update it. If the tool did not find a record, your email's DNS provider provides the criteria to fix it. Popular providers include [Google Workspace](https://support.google.com/a/answer/33786?hl=en&ref_topic=2759192&visit_id=637831405153100195-115250150&rd=1) or [Office 365](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn789058(v=exchg.150).aspx). If you use these providers, you can refer to these links to confirm the settings and add or update your **SPF** records accordingly. Your domain administrator should be familiar with the process.​

*   **Google Workspace**:

*   [Before You Set Up SPF](https://support.google.com/a/answer/10686639)
*   [Define Your SPF Record - Basic Setup](https://support.google.com/a/answer/10685031)
*   [SPF Records Technical Information](https://support.google.com/a/answer/33786?hl=en&ref_topic=10685331)

*   **Office 365**:

*   [Setting Up SPF Records in Office 365](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/set-up-spf-in-office-365-to-help-prevent-spoofing?view=o365-worldwide)

Do the Numbers Add Up?

If you're the IT or domain administrator for your organization, verify that you have the correct list of IP addresses; it's easy to switch a few numbers around accidentally. Email servers could continue to mark your emails as SPAM if you misconfigure your **SPF** record.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Fix Other Possible SPAM Issues[](#fixotherpossiblespamissues)

Correct **SPF** records are only one part of making sure your emails are delivered. You should set up [**DKIM (Domain Keys Identified Mail)**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046544644365) and [**DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance)**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046576375437) policies to further validate your organization's domain and prevent e-mail bounces.

Read the [Avoid SPAM filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409225311885-Avoid-SPAM-Filters) article for more information about other potential SPAM concerns and best practices.

[Back to Top](#top)
