## Overview[](#toc_2)

You can create a custom unsubscribe link that Apollo automatically appends after your email signature in every email you send from an Apollo sequence.

Follow the steps below to configure your unsubscribe link, and include one-click unsubscribe headers in your emails.

Top Deliverability Tips

Adding unsubscribe links and one-click unsubscribe headers in your mail is just one part of the magic, spam-free potion. For more tips and best practices to keep your mail out of the spam folder, please refer to the [Avoid Spam Filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409225311885-Avoid-Spam-Filters) article, the [Email Deliverability](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409225311885-Avoid-Spam-Filters#:~:text=email%20deliverability%20checklist) checklist, and the [Why Your emails Land in Spam](https://www.apollo.io/academy/why-your-emails-land-in-spam-and-how-to-fix-it) webinar.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Configure Your Unsubscribe Link[](#toc_3)

To configure an unsubscribe link:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Settings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/account).
2.  In the "Email Settings" panel of the **General** tab, click the toggle for **Append the following opt-out message after my signature in sequences.** [![Toggle](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i2.png)
3.  Customize your opt-out message with the copy and links you want to include. Make sure you add `<%brackets%></%brackets%>` between the words that you want Apollo to hyperlink with the unsubscribe link. [![Message](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i3.png)
4.  When you're finished, click **Save**. Apollo then works its magic on the back end to generate your unsubscribe link. [![Save](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i4.png)

47 Days Before the Link Bites the Dust!

Please note, the unsubscribe link that Apollo attaches to your emails expires 47 days after you send an email. If a **contact** attempts to click the link after 47 days, the URL will not be valid.

You have now enabled an opt-out message and unsubscribe link that Apollo automatically includes below your [email signature](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409140295949-Set-Up-Your-Email-Signature) in every email you send to contacts via your Apollo sequences.

Other Unsubscribe Options

If you prefer to keep this option disabled, you can also place an unsubscribe link in your signature or the body of an [email template](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409238165389-Create-and-Edit-Email-Templates). Just make sure you include the `{{opt_out_message}}` [dynamic variable](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409415084813-Use-Basic-Dynamic-Variables) wherever you put it.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Visualize the Unsubscribe Workflow for Recipients[](#toc_4)

When recipients click an unsubscribe link in your emails, Apollo directs them to an unsubscribe landing page. From here, recipients can then choose to continue and unsubscribe or to stay subscribed to your emails.

[![Unsubscribe landing page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i7.png)

If they click **Unsubscribe**, Apollo prompts them to provide more feedback on why they unsubscribed from your emails. Apollo then automatically removes the recipient from future steps in any sequences you've added them to. If you try to enroll a contact into a sequence after they unsubscribe, Apollo warns you that the contact has opted out of receiving your emails and prevents you from adding them to the sequence.

Recipients also have the chance to resubscribe from the landing page.

[![Unsubscribe feedback](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i8.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Include One-Click Unsubscribe Headers in Your Emails[](#toc_5)

To prevent mailbox providers like Gmail from treating your emails as spam, Apollo strongly recommends you enable one-click unsubscribe headers in all emails you send via the mailboxes you've connected to Apollo. This makes it easy for a recipient to opt out if they no longer want to receive your messages. It also ensures you remain compliant with [Google and Yahoo's email policies](https://www.apollo.io/magazine/what-mailbox-providers-new-spam-rules-mean-for-your-sales-organization) if you send large volumes of emails as part of your [sales outreach strategy](https://www.apollo.io/academy/5-best-sales-sequences).

Top Deliverability Tips

Please note, this feature is currently only available for Gmail, SendGrid, and Mailgun users.

As a best practice, Apollo still recommends that you include an unsubscribe link in your signature or the body of your email as well as in the email header.

To turn on one-click unsubscribe headers in Apollo:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Settings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/account) > **You**.
2.  From the **General** tab, enable the one-click unsubscribe headers toggle in the **Email Settings** section of the **General** tab. [![One-click toggle](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/configure_your_opt_out_unsubscribe_email_link/i5.png)
3.  When you enable the toggle, Apollo adds the one-click unsubscribe code to your headers and Google reviews the snippet. Once Google approves, the unsubscribe link appears in your email headers when you send emails via mailboxes connected to Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#overview)

**Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM)** is an authentication method that uses cryptography to add an encrypted digital signature to your organization's outgoing emails. In this method, your mail server uses a private key to encrypt the email data and receiving email servers retrieve the corresponding public key to decrypt it. This ensures that your email is genuinely sent from your domain and hasn’t been altered on its way to the recipient. It also raises your spam score, which increases the chances of your emails being delivered.

Refer to the sections below to verify and configure your **DKIM** settings.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Verify Your DKIM Configuration[](#verifyyourdkimconfiguration)

Usually, your domain's **DKIM** configuration is set by your IT rep or domain/mail administrator, but you can also check yourself using a tool such as [MX Toolbox](https://mxtoolbox.com/dkim.aspx).

In its most basic form, **DKIM** can be verified using two elements:

*   Your organization's domain name (for example, `apollo.io`)
*   A **DKIM** selector is the text added with the domain to create a unique DNS record used during **DKIM**.
    *   This allows different systems, date ranges, or third-party services to create different signatures.

DKIM Selector? Wasn't she in Sonic Youth?

If a **DKIM** selector sounds more like the bass player from an 80s indie rock band, don't fret. Your IT or domain administrator typically creates this.

Within MX Toolbox (or a similar tool), enter your domain name and the selector in the fields. Then, click **DKIM Lookup**.

[![DKIM Lookup](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_dkim_to_verify_your_emails/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_dkim_to_verify_your_emails/i1.png)

The **DKIM** status appears on the next screen.

[![DKIM Results](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_dkim_to_verify_your_emails/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_dkim_to_verify_your_emails/i2.png)

If MX Toolbox is unable to find a **DKIM** record, refer to the section below to enable **DKIM** for your domain.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Enable DKIM for Your Domain[](#enabledkimforyourdomain)

If you've followed the steps above and found a **DKIM record**, there's no need to enable DKIM. If the tool did not find a record, your IT or domain administrator can work with the domain or email provider to enable and configure it for you—they should be familiar with the process.

Some popular providers are [Google Workspace](https://support.google.com/a/answer/180504#turn-on-dkim) and [Microsoft Office 365](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/use-dkim-to-validate-outbound-email?view=o365-worldwide). If you use these providers, you can refer to these links to confirm the settings and enable DKIM.

*   Google Workspace:
    *   [Before You Set Up DKIM](https://support.google.com/a/answer/174126)
    *   [Turn on DKIM for Your Domain](https://support.google.com/a/answer/180504)
    *   [Troubleshoot DKIM Issues](https://support.google.com/a/answer/11612790)
*   Office 365:
    *   [Use DKIM to validate outbound email sent from your custom domain](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/use-dkim-to-validate-outbound-email?view=o365-worldwide)

Google, DKIM, and You

If you're using Google Workspace for your domain, Google creates a **DKIM** key for you and puts it in your DNS records once your site is created. All you need to do is follow the steps in the "[Turn on DKIM for Your Domain](https://support.google.com/a/answer/180504)" article to configure your domain for **DKIM**.

Return to Sender

If you're the domain administrator, be extremely careful when you configure your **DKIM** method. Incorrect configurations can lead to your mail becoming undeliverable!

[Back to Top](#top)

## Fix Other Possible SPAM Issues[](#fixotherpossiblespamissues)

**DKIM** configuration is only one way to confirm your emails get delivered. You should also set up [**SPF (Sender Policy Framework)**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046457454861-Set-Up-Sender-Policy-Framework-SPF-Records-to-Authorize-Your-Emails) records and [**DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance)**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046576375437) policies to further validate your organization's domain and prevent e-mail bounces.

Read the [Avoid SPAM Filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409225311885-Avoid-SPAM-Filters#toc_3) article for more information about potential SPAM concerns and best practices.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#overview)

**Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC)** is a standard email authentication method that helps you prevent hackers from spoofing your organization for malicious purposes and allows you to limit sent emails to those authenticated by your organization. **DMARC's** most basic function is to tell receiving email servers what to do with outgoing messages from your domain that don’t pass the [Sender Policy Framework (SPF)](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046457454861) or [Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM)](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046544644365) checks. Setting up **DMARC** also allows you to generate reports to make sure your emails aren't being spoofed.

Refer to the sections below to verify and configure your **DMARC** settings.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Verify DMARC Configuration[](#verifydmarcconfiguration)

Usually, your domain's **DMARC** policies are set by your IT rep or domain/mail administrator, but you can also check them yourself with a tool like [MX Toolbox](https://mxtoolbox.com/dkim.aspx).

Within MX Toolbox, enter your domain name in the search bar and click **DMARC Lookup**.

[![DMARC Lookup](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_dmarc_to_authenticate_your_emails/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_dmarc_to_authenticate_your_emails/i1.png)

The **Result** column shows your current **DMARC** configuration.

[![DMARC Results](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_dmarc_to_authenticate_your_emails/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_dmarc_to_authenticate_your_emails/i2.png)

You have now verified your **DMARC** configuration.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Enable DMARC for Your Domain[](#enabledmarcforyourdomain)

If you've followed the steps above and found a **DMARC record**, there is no need to enable or configure it any further. If the tool did not find a record, refer to the steps below to enable **DMARC**.

Enabling **DMARC** for your domain ultimately depends on your domain or email provider. Some popular providers include [Google Workspace](https://support.google.com/a/answer/10032674?hl=en) and [Microsoft Office 365](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/use-dmarc-to-validate-email?view=o365-worldwide). If you use either of these providers, you can refer to links below to confirm the settings and enable **DMARC**.

*   Google Workspace:
    *   [Before You Set Up DMARC](https://support.google.com/a/answer/10032674)
    *   [Define your DMARC Policy](https://support.google.com/a/answer/10032169)
    *   [Add Your DMARC Record](https://support.google.com/a/answer/2466563)
    *   [Tutorial: Recommended DMARC Rollout](https://support.google.com/a/answer/10032473)
    *   [DMARC Reports](https://support.google.com/a/answer/10032472)
    *   [Troubleshoot DMARC](https://support.google.com/a/answer/10032578)
*   Office 365:
    *   [Use DMARC to validate email](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/use-dmarc-to-validate-email?view=o365-worldwide)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Fix Other Possible Spam Issues[](#fixotherpossiblespamissues)

**DMARC policies** are only one part of making sure your emails are being delivered. You should also set up [**Sender Policy Framework (SPF)**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046457454861-Set-Up-Sender-Policy-Framework-SPF-Records-to-Authorize-Your-Emails) records and [**Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM)**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5046544644365) to further validate your organization's domain and prevent email bounces.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Plan Availability

Please note, this feature is only available for [**Professional**](https://www.apollo.io/pricing/) and [**Custom**](https://www.apollo.io/pricing/) plans.

You can create **tasks** in Apollo sequences for manual tasks like phone calls, follow-up emails, and action items. Each **task** reminds you of the manual steps you need to take once the parameters—a timeframe or engagement criterion—are met.

## Create Tasks in Apollo[](#toc_2)

### Automatically Create Tasks With Trigger Events[](#toc_3)

Trigger events automatically create a task when a contact reaches certain engagement criterion. From your chosen sequence, click **Settings**.

[![Settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_task/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_task/i7.png)

Scroll to the "Triggers" section.

[![Triggers](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_task/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_task/i8.png)

Click the checkbox for **Create a phone call task if an active contact opens an email at least \[ # \] times.** Set the number of email opens you would like.

[![Opens](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_task/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_task/i9.png)

Click **Save Changes** at the top of the "Settings" page.

[![Save](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_task/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_task/i10.png)

Changing Trigger Settings

Please note, you can change the criteria for trigger events or disengage them at any time.

### Create Tasks in a Sequence[](#toc_4)

Create a Sequences

For more information about how to create a sequence, please see the [Create a Sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409231193101-Create-a-Sequence) article.

From your chosen sequence, click **More** to access the drop-down and then click **Add Step**.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Task priority helps you (or members of your team) to better plan your day and stay focused on the tasks that are most important first. You can mark steps in a sequence with a priority to provide ease of sorting in your daily task lists. 

Daily task lists, which are found on the "Home" screen and on a sequences and "Tasks" tab, are organized by calls, manual emails, and action items. You can sort task lists based on priority in either descending or ascending order.

[![Sort by Priority](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i5.png)

Refer to the sections below to better understand how and where you can change or assign a priority for a task.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Set Priority for Tasks in Sequences[](#toc_2)

Launch Apollo and then click **Engage**.

[![Engage](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i1.png)

Open an existing sequence or click **\+ New Sequence** to build out a new one with tasks.

[![Sequence](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i2.png)

Within your built-out sequence, click the additional options button next to any step and then click **Edit**.

[![Edit](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i3.png)

[![Priority](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_task_priority/i4.png)

No Priority Settings for Automatic Emails

Please note, "Automatic Email" tasks do not have a **Priority** dropdown since they do not require any interaction from an Apollo user before they send.

When you're finished, click **Save**.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Set up look-alike domains to protect your primary domain and improve email deliverability when you reach out to contacts via [Apollo sequences](https://app.apollo.io/#/sequences).

A look-alike, or cousin, domain is not the same as your company's primary operating domain. Automated systems do not see it as a match. Nonetheless, it is a domain that most casual observers affiliate with your primary domain. For example, if `apollo.io` is Apollo's primary domain, Apollo might choose to create a cousin domain like `heyapollo.io` or `meetapollo.io`.

When you send cold emails from a look-alike domain, you help protect the sending reputation of your primary domain and eradicate the risk of negatively impacting the deliverability of your company's regular operational email.

Refer to the following sections for the recommended steps when setting up look-alike domains for your cold outreach in Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 1: Set Up a New Domain[](#toc_2)

To set up a new look-alike domain:

1.  **Set up a new domain with your domain provider**:  
    Every domain provider has a different domain management interface. If you need help setting up a new domain, visit your domain provider's knowledge base.
    
    Here are some popular domain provider resources for guidance:
    
    *   [Amazon Web Services (AWS)](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codeartifact/latest/ug/domain-create.html)
    *   [GoDaddy](https://www.godaddy.com/help/domains-1000003)
    *   [Namecheap](https://www.namecheap.com/support/knowledgebase/category/34/domains/)
2.  **Create a new email address**: When you have set up a new domain, you need to create a professional email address with your mailbox provider (MBP) using your new domain. For further guidance, please refer to your MBP's knowledge base.
    
    Here are some popular MBP help centers for support:
    
    *   [Microsoft 365](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us)
    *   [Google Workspace](https://knowledge.workspace.google.com/)
3.  **Finalize the setup**: Head to your domain provider and configure the settings to finalize the setup process.

Now that you have a new look-alike domain, follow [best practices](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/25265069912717-Set-up-Lookalike-Domains-to-Protect-Your-Primary-Domain#toc_3) to set your team up for success.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 2: Follow Setup Best Practices[](#toc_3)

Before you link your mailbox to Apollo and begin your cold outreach, there are certain best practices to follow. Although a look-alike domain isolates your primary domain from the damage that poor targeting, content, and sending practices can have on your sending reputation, you should still follow best practices with your look-alike domain. It takes very little time to burn a sending reputation, and recovering or rebuilding it on another domain is a slow process.

To protect the reputation of your look-alike domain and optimize your sending efforts:

1.  **Do not use more domains than necessary**:  
    When an MBP sees the same message coming from many different domains, it looks like [snowshoe spamming](https://www.techopedia.com/definition/1713/snowshoe-spamming). This is where a spammer spreads sends across multiple domains and IPs to avoid being caught.
2.  **Allow your new domain to age**:  
    Spammers often register new domains and immediately start spamming through them. Almost all filtering systems will flag a domain as potential spam if it is less than a month old. Wait 30 days before you send any emails from this domain, and then begin sending emails slowly. Start by sending 10 emails daily and monitor [open](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4410838798349-Open-Tracking-Overview) and [click](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409803614093-Click-Tracking-in-Apollo) rates. After a few weeks, if your emails are performing well, slowly increase the number of emails you send. Remember not to exceed Apollo's [recommended sending limits](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409233349005-Email-Sending-Limits-Overview#toc_6) per mailbox.
3.  **Publish a website on your domain**:  
    A simple landing page will suffice. Filters do automated vetting on a domain, including looking for a website.  
    
    Play It Safe
    
    Please note, Apollo recommends that you don't forward traffic from your landing page to your main corporate site. You should also avoid including links or images that direct users back to your main domain. These tactics tie your domain reputations together and counteract the purpose of creating a look-alike domain for your cold outreach efforts.
    
4.  **Avoid using DNS privacy**:  
    It's common spammer practice to hide behind anonymized registrars. As a result, if you register your domain with anonymized contact information, servers are more likely to treat you as a spammer.
5.  **Follow domain authentication best practices:**  
    *   Whitelabel everything to ensure all URLs in your messages and on your landing page link back to the look-alike domain and not your main domain.
    *   Use a custom tracking link at the domain.
    *   Set up SPF, DKIM, and DMARC for the domain and ensure all links run through it.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 3: Link Your New Mailbox to Apollo[](#toc_4)

When you've set up your new look-alike domain, [link the associated mailboxes to Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409127806093-Link-Your-Mailbox-to-Apollo-io) and follow the mailbox configuration steps.

[![View all search filters.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_lookalike_domains/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_lookalike_domains/i1.png)

When you link the mailbox(es), make sure you configure:

*   [Your email signature](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409140295949-Set-Up-Your-Email-Signature).
*   [Sending limits](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409233349005-Email-Sending-Limits-Overview).
*   [Opt-out](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409140379661-Configure-Your-Unsubscribe-Email-Link) and [open tracking](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4410838798349-Open-Tracking-Overview).
*   [Domain authentication](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409225311885-Avoid-Spam-Filters#toc_5).

Now you're ready to [create](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409231193101-Create-a-Sequence) and [enroll contacts](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409396985741-Add-Contacts-to-a-Sequence) into your Apollo sequences. Just make sure you adhere to the following [best sending practices](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/25265069912717-Set-up-Lookalike-Domains-to-Protect-Your-Primary-Domain#toc_5) when you do so.

[Back to top](#top)

## Step 4: Follow Sending Best Practices[](#toc_5)

When you build your sequences in Apollo, follow best sending practices to optimize your campaigns for engagement.

1.  **Don't link back to your primary domain from within your emails**:  
    Avoid linking to or including images hosted at your main corporate site. You must isolate the reputation of the look-alike domain from your primary domain. You don’t want automated link followers to add your main corporate domain to the reputation that the sends from your look-alike domain generate.
2.  **Use different email templates for each domain**:  
    If you set up several look-alike domains and use the exact same messaging across each one, you risk aggregating your sending reputation across domains. This is because servers apply fingerprinting tactics to evaluate how recipients treat your messages. Data points include your domain and IP, the URLs in your messages, and the general structure of the messages you send. When you send the same message across multiple domains, you also risk being flagged for snowshoe spamming.
3.  **Avoid "batch and blast" messages**:  
    Optimizing for engagement is key. Follow [email best practices](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4415045401485-How-Do-I-Write-Effective-Sales-Emails) and avoid [the common mistakes of inauthentic personalization](https://www.apollo.io/academy/how-to-write-cold-emails-anyone-will-respond-to?videoId=wx04ee9o8d). Resist the temptation of gathering a large list and bulk-sending all your contacts the same generic message. Instead, focus on clearly identifying your [Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4416471135245-Identify-Your-Ideal-Customer-Profile-ICP), using [search filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661-Search-Filters-Overview) to segment your contacts, and enrolling them into sequences with highly targeted messaging that speaks to their specific goals and needs.
4.  **Auto-assign emails in a sequence to increase your daily reach**:  
    When you [add contacts to a sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409396985741-Add-Contacts-to-a-Sequence#toc_3), select the auto-assign email toggle to rotate between the mailboxes you use to send your emails. [![View all search filters.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_lookalike_domains/i2.png) ](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_lookalike_domains/i2.png)Apollo then dynamically manages which email you send a message from based on the sending limits and availability of the selected mailboxes at the time of sending.
    
    Don't Mix and Match!
    
    For each sequence, you should only select mailboxes from the same look-alike domain to avoid aggregating sending reputation across your domains.
    

[Back to Top](#top)

## Watch the Video[](#toc_0)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Territories help you set clear guidelines and rules that restrict which contacts and accounts each user on your team can prospect. This helps you to better organize your sales team so they only engage with the specific contacts you assign to them.

You can use territories to filter and segment lists in numerous ways, not just to apply geographic restrictions. Refer to the following sections to create and assign territories.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add New Territories[](#toc_2)

To add a new territory:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Territories**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/prospect-territory).
2.  Click **New Territory**. [![Add New Territory](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i30.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i30.png)
3.  Name the territory and assign it to a user group. If you choose the **Specific users** button, you need to select the users that you want to assign to the territory. [![Name and assign territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i31.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i31.png)
4.  Click **Add filters for people and companies**. [![Add filters.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i32.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i32.png)
5.  To define the territory, add as many [search filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661) as you need. Then, click **Save filters**. [![Define the territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i33.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i33.png)
6.  Click **Save** to activate the territory. [![Save the new territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i34.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i34.png)

You have now applied the newly created territory to your assigned audience. Repeat these steps to create more territories. There is no limit to how many you can create.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Search Using Territories[](#toc_3)

When you assign territories to users in your Apollo account, they cannot see, search, or access any contacts that fall outside the rules of those territories.

When a user searches for new contacts or accounts in Apollo, the **Territories** search filter shows the territory you've assigned to them. Only Apollo admins can edit or delete this filter.

[![View assigned territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i40.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i40.png)

Contact Restrictions

If users search for a particular record in Apollo and can't see it, it's most likely because a territory restricts their view. To give them access to additional contacts that fall outside of their territory, you can either [edit the rules for the territories](#toc_7) assigned to them, or [update their permission profile](#toc_6).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Restrict Prospecting by Account Owner Status[](#toc_4)

If you only want users at your company to prospect contacts from accounts they have been assigned, restrict their prospecting activities using territories. As an Apollo admin, build a territory that automatically applies to all of your assigned users and restricts their search in Apollo to the accounts they own, rather than building separate territories for each individual user.

Start by [adding a new territory](#toc_2) and assigning it to a user group. When you select filters for the territory, click the **Owner** filter. Then, select `Current User` from the **Account owner** drop-down.

[![View assigned territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i45.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i45.png)

When users with the [assigned territory search for contacts](#toc_3), they will only see contacts from their own accounts.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Restrict Prospecting Using Custom Fields[](#toc_5)

If you assign account owners in Salesforce or HubSpot and sync that data to Apollo, use custom field entries to restrict prospecting activities by territory. This ensures users only prospect the accounts in Apollo that you have assigned to them in your CRM.

Create a Lookup - User Field

Start by [adding a new territory](#toc_2) and assigning it to a user group. When you select filters for the territory:

1.  Click the **Custom Fields** filter and then click the **Contact** tab. Select **Add Custom Field Filter** and choose a custom field. The field must be a `Lookup - User` type field. [![View assigned territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i43.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i43.png)
2.  For **Value**, click the **Is any of** checkbox, then select the users from the drop-down. Make sure you add the same users that you assigned to the territory. [![View assigned territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i44.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i44.png)
3.  Click **Save filters** and finish creating the territory.

You have now restricted prospecting with custom fields. When users with the [assigned territory search for contacts](#toc_3), they will only see the records where the custom field you selected has a value that matches the user.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Edit Permission Profiles for Territories (Admins Only)[](#toc_6)

If you are an Apollo admin, you can edit permission profiles to add or remove user territory permissions. This enables you to control which users at your company can add new territories and prospect outside of their assigned territories.

To edit permission profiles, launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Permission Profiles**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/permissions-profiles). Then, follow the steps in [Create and Assign Permission Profiles](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409154208269).

In the **Prospecting** permissions section, click the following checkboxes to give users more flexibility when prospecting:

*   **Can add or edit Territories & Territory Rules**: This enables users to add and edit territories.
*   **Can prospect outside of assigned territories**: This enables users to search for new contacts and accounts outside their assigned territories.

[![Apply territories permissions to your Apollo users.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i41.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i41.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Edit Existing Territories[](#toc_7)

To edit an existing territory:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Territories**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/prospect-territory).
2.  Find the territory and click **...** **Edit**. [![Edit the territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i35.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i35.png)
3.  From here, you can change the name, assigned users, and search filters that define the territory. [![Update the territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i42.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i42.png)
4.  Click **Save** to update the territory.

You have now edited an existing territory.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Clone Territories[](#toc_8)

If you want to create a new territory based on an existing one, you can clone the original one. This enables you to assign a territory with some of the same characteristics to different audiences, such as sales reps that target the same persona across different locations.

To clone an existing territory:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Territories**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/prospect-territory).
2.  Find the territory you want to clone, then click **...** > **Duplicate**. [![Clone the territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i36.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i36.png)
3.  Name the new territory and assign it to a user group. If you choose the **Specific users** button, you need to select the users that you want to assign to the territory. [![Name and assign the new territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i37.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i37.png)
4.  The filters from the cloned territory are still active. To update the [search filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661) that define the territory, click **Add filters for people and companies**, then add and remove filters as needed. [![Update the filters.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i38.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i38.png)
5.  Click **Save** to create the new territory.

You have now activated your new territory.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Delete Territories[](#toc_9)

To delete a territory:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Territories**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/prospect-territory).
2.  Find the territory you want to delete, then click **...** > **Delete**. [![Clone the territory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i39.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_edit_and_prospect_with_territories/i39.png)
3.  Click **Delete** again to confirm your decision.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Custom fields allow you to capture individualized research about a contact, account, or user and leverage them in Apollo sequence email templates for open-time personalization. **Custom User** fields allow you to specify person-specific information on the **General** information tab for each user in your account.

Refer to the section below for additional details about how to create custom fields for users.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Create a Custom User Field[](#toc_2)

Launch Apollo and then click **Settings**.

[![Settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i1.png)

Click **Users**.

[![Users](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i24.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i24.png)

Click **Custom Fields**.

[![DESCRIPTION](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i25.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i25.png)

Click **\+ New Field**.

[![New Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i26.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i26.png)

On the "Add Custom User Field" modal, type a descriptive name in the **Name** text-box.

[![New Field]](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i27.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i27.png)

Select the field **Type** from the drop-down.

[![Field Types](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i28.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i28.png)

The available field types include:

| Field Name | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Single-line text | Allows you to include a single line of text for the field. You must specify the maximum number of characters for the field. |
| Multi-line text | Allows you to include a string of text that spans multiple lines. You must specify the maximum number of characters for the field. Line breaks count against the total character count. |
| Number | Allows you to include a number with or without decimals. You cannot use non-numeric characters. |
| Date | Allows you to type a date in the format of `Day/Month/Year` or select a date with the calendar widget. |
| Date/Time | Allows you to type a date in the format of `Day/Month/Year` or select a date with the calendar widget. Allows you to select a time in half-hour increments from the drop-down. |
| Checkbox | Allows you to specify either `True` or `False` within the field's drop-down |
| Picklist | Allows you to include an existing picklist or create a new picklist with defined values. You can only select one value from the picklist. For additional information about creating picklists, please see [Create Global Picklists.](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412498624269) |
| Picklist (Multi-Select) | Allows you to include an existing picklist or create a new picklist with defined values. You can only select multiple values from the picklist. For additional information about creating picklists, please see [Create Global Picklists.](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412498624269) |
| Lookup-User | Allows you to specify a user from your account via a drop-down |

No Type Changes After Creation

Please note, once you create a custom field you cannot change the type.

If you select **Picklist** or **Picklist (Multi-Select)** for the field type, add the options that you would like to appear in the user's profile.

[![Picklist Options](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i29.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i29.png)

After you finish configuring the custom **User Field**, click **Save**.

[![Global Picklist Name](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i30.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i30.png)

Your new custom **User Field** is now editable on the **General** tab in the user's profile.

[![Completed Custom Contact Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i32.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i32.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

It Depends on Your Plan

Playbooks are only available on certain plans. For a breakdown of the features available in each Apollo plan, please refer to [the pricing page](https://www.apollo.io/pricing#compare). If you want to upgrade your plan to access playbooks, please reach out to the friendly [Apollo sales team](https://apollo.na.chilipiper.com/router/sales_router?leadsource=Inbound&lead_source_details__c=KnowledgeBase) for further assistance.

Please note, this feature is also currently in **beta** development and may exhibit unexpected behavior. Take care to make sure your playbooks are operating the way you want them to!

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Playbooks are engagement tools you use to group accounts through an ordered series of steps that must be completed during the engagement process. You can think of playbooks like [sequences](https://app.apollo.io/#/sequences) but for accounts instead of contacts. You can also have multiple playbooks operating simultaneously.

Playing With Playbooks vs. Stepping Through Sequences

If you want to engage clients at the contact level instead of the account level, refer to the [Sequences Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409237165837-Sequences-Overview) article.

[Back to Top](#top)

## The Playbooks Page[](#toc_2)

[![Playbooks Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i1.png)

The [**playbooks**](https://app.apollo.io/#/playbooks) page contains all of your playbooks. From this page, you can also:

*   Add new playbooks to the page.
*   Turn playbooks on and off.
*   Star (favorite), archive, clone, or edit playbooks.
*   Move playbooks to folders to organize them.
*   Add or remove tags from playbooks for labeling purposes.
*   Search or filter playbooks to easily find the ones you want.

Each playbook has four sub-pages: Overview, accounts, playbook tasks, and settings. You can perform several actions for each playbook. These include:

*   Star (favorite) your playbook.
*   Turn the playbook on and off.
*   Add accounts for the playbook.
*   Archive or clone the playbook.
*   View the playbook's settings.

Read the following sections for further information on the playbook sub-pages.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Overview Page[](#toc_3)

[![Overview Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i2.png)

The overview page displays the individual steps of your playbook at a glance. This can help you understand what actions are in your playbook.

This page also allows you to perform the following tasks for your playbook:

*   Add steps, including "Research Fields," "Add People," and "Do Action Item."
*   Edit, clone, rearrange, and remove steps.
*   View sequences tied to each playbook step.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Accounts[](#toc_4)

[![Accounts Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i3.png)

The accounts page shows you the accounts that you target in the playbook. You can filter your list with the sidebar to the left.

Apollo also organizes the records by status. Click each type to sort by these statuses. Please note that you can scroll to the right to see more statuses.

[![Records Statuses](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i3f.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i3f.png)

The following tasks are available for you on this page:

*   Mark the playbook as finished.
*   Pause the playbook.
*   Resume the playbook.
*   Remove the account from the playbook.
*   Edit the playbook stage, owner, or custom field.

You can click the **Additional Options (...)** button for the playbook to expand the menu for more actions.

[![Additional Options](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i3b.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i3b.png)

You can also perform the following actions for each account:

*   Call the contact listed on the account.
*   Go to the Salesforce record of the account.
*   Add or remove the account from a list.

To expand the menu for more actions, click the **Additional Options (...)** button for each account.

[![More Options](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i3d.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i3d.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Playbook Tasks[](#toc_5)

[![Tasks Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i4.png)

The playbook tasks page lists all the accounts with tasks to complete. You can filter your list with the sidebar to the left.

You can also perform the following functions on multiple playbook tasks from this page:

*   Skip tasks.
*   Reschedule tasks.
*   Reassign tasks to another team member.
*   Set the task's priority level (high, medium, or low).

Click the right-hand side of an individual task to mark it as complete or skip it entirely.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Settings[](#toc_6)

[![Settings Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i5.png)

The settings page allows you to adjust various aspects of your playbook. This page is separated into two sections: Basic info and playbook rulesets.

[Back to Top](#top)

#### Basic Info[](#toc_7)

[![Basic Info](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i2.png)

The basic info section allows you to perform the following tasks:

*   Rename your playbook.
*   Assign a team member to a playbook and grant them permissions.
*   Move the playbook to a folder.
*   Apply or remove tags.

[Back to Top](#top)

#### Playbook Rulesets[](#toc_8)

Playbook rulesets allow you to save the people settings and safeguards you choose. You can then use them for other playbooks.

You can adjust the people settings options to perform the following actions:

*   Automatically add prospects to playbooks or review them before you add them.
*   Have Apollo prompt you to skip tasks when there are no suggested contacts or leave the tasks active and add the contacts manually.
*   Select the field that determines from which user you send emails and assign tasks to (account owner or custom field).
*   Determine which linked email account Apollo should use to send emails when you add a contact to a sequence.

[![People Settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i3.png)

The safeguards setting only has two options:

*   Do not suggest contacts in the following stages.
*   Mark account as finished in the playbook if the account stage changes.

[![Safeguards Settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i4.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Available Steps in a Playbook[](#toc_9)

You can perform the following steps in a playbook:

*   Add people.
*   Research fields.
*   Do action item.

Refer to the sections below for more information on each step.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Add People[](#toc_10)

People Come First!

You should start your playbooks with the "Add People" step, as it provides a more natural flow and will allow you to target your tasks to the correct contacts for your accounts.

This step allows you to add contacts to your sequences, which will be used in your playbooks. You can filter characteristics for your contacts and choose to add from:

*   Net New contacts.
*   Saved contacts.
*   Both net new and current contacts.
    
    [![Add People](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i6.png)
    

[Back to Top](#top)

### Research Fields[](#toc_11)

This step allows you to fill in the data for any accounts added to your playbook. This is helpful for account-based [**custom fields**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412498754445-Create-Custom-Account-Fields).

[![Research Fields](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i7.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Do Action Item[](#toc_12)

This step creates a task that reminds you to complete actions that may be relevant when doing account-based sales. This is good for personalizing your interactions.

[![Action Item](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/playbooks_overview_beta/i8.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#overview)

Bear With Us, It's in Beta!

**Playbooks** are in **Beta** development, and may exhibit unexpected behavior. For more information about **Playbooks**, refer to the [Playbooks Overview (BETA)](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/LINK%20GOES%20HERE) article.

**Playbook Rulesets** allow you to target your **Playbooks** more efficiently and intelligently. **Playbook Rulesets** allow Apollo to handle more repetitive tasks targeted to your **accounts** and **contacts**, as well as grant you more control over how your **Playbooks** operate.

Refer to the steps below to create a **Playbook Ruleset.**

## Create a Playbook Ruleset[](#createaplaybookruleset)

Launch Apollo and click **Settings**.

[![Settings Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i5.png)

Click **Playbook Rulesets (Beta)** on the left.

[![Playbook Rulesets](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i6.png)

Click **\+ Add** in the top-right corner. Apollo displays a new page for you to configure your settings.

[![Add Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i7.png)

Under the **Basic Info** section, click the field under **Playbook Ruleset Name** and enter a name for your **Playbook Ruleset**.

[![Ruleset Name](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i8.png)

Click the **Playbook Ruleset Owner** drop-down and select an owner.

[![Ruleset Owner](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i9.png)

In the **People Settings** section, enter a number to set the maximum number of **contacts** per **account** that you want to be active in a **sequence** at any given time.

[![Max Contacts](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i10.png)

Under **Automatically Add Contacts or New Prospects to Playbooks?**, click the radio button next to your preferred choice. You can either review each **contact** before you add them to a **Playbook** or have Apollo add **contacts** automatically.

Credit Where Credit is Due

Please note, if you allow Apollo to automatically add **contacts**, Apollo may prospect people on your behalf. This can potentially cost you lead credit.

[![Automatically Prospect](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i11.png)

Under **What should Apollo do when there are no suggested contacts in your ICP?**, click the radio button next to your preferred choice. You can leave the **account** in the **Playbook** so you can add new **contacts** or finish and remove the **account** from the **Playbook**.

[![Suggested Contacts](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i12.png)

Under **Which field should be used to determine which user to send emails from & assign tasks to**, click the radio button next to your preferred choice. You can assign this to the **account owner** or someone else with a **custom field**.

[![Select Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i13.png)

Under **If not specified, which email account should Apollo use to send emails when a Contact is added to a sequence?**, click the radio button next to your preferred choice. You can send only from the default email account of the **account owner** or randomly send emails from all linked email accounts of the **account owner**.

[![Specify Email](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i14.png)

In the **Safeguards** section, under **Do NOT suggest contacts in the following stages** you can select the stage(s) you want to have Apollo ignore for suggesting contacts. Click the drop-down and select the stage(s) you want this to apply to. You can select as many stages as needed.

[![Ignore Stage](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i15.png)

Also optionally, under **Mark account as finished in playbook if account stage changes to any of the following:** you can select the stage(s) to have Apollo marked your **Playbook** as finished. Click the drop-down and select the stage(s) to which you want this to apply.

[![Mark Finished](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i16.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i16.png)

Click **Save** when you're done.

[![Save Preferences](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i17.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i17.png)

You have now created a **Playbook Ruleset**.

[Back to Top](#top)

Launch Apollo and click **Settings**.

## Clone a Playbook Ruleset[](#cloneaplaybookruleset)

Refer to the steps below to clone your **Playbook Ruleset**.

Launch Apollo and click **Settings**.

[![Settings Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i5.png)

Click **Playbook Rulesets (Beta)** on the left.

[![Playbook Rulesets](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i6.png)

Apollo displays a new page with the cloned settings of your **Playbook Ruleset**. Adjust the name and settings to your liking, and click **Save** when you're done.

[![Save Clone](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i24.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_configure_delete_playbook_rulesets/i24.png)

You have now cloned a **Playbook Ruleset**.

## Overview [](#toc_0)

Email templates help consolidate the content that you and your team send to contacts. Templates also enable your team to collaborate and share resources.

The following sections outline how to create email templates and use those templates in your sequence steps.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Create a New Email Template[](#toc_1)

To create a new email template:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Emails** > [**Templates**](https://app.apollo.io/#/templates).
2.  Click **New Template**. [![Create a new template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i1.png)
3.  Name your email template and assign an owner. To store the template in a specific folder, click **Browse** and select a folder. Add tags to categorize the template and make it easier to find in searches. [![Name and assign template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i2.png)
4.  Enter a subject line and body for your email template. [![Name and assign template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i3.png)
5.  Click **{}** to add dynamic variables to the subject line and body of your email. Variables pull in dynamic text and help you better cater your emails to your audience. [![Add variables to the template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i4.png)
6.  Review the real-time preview of your email. Click **Send Test Email to Me** to receive a test version of the email in your inbox. [![Preview the email.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i5.png)
7.  When you finish editing your template, click **Save**.

Your email template is now ready to use.

For more information about dynamic variables, refer to [Use Basic Dynamic Variables](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409415084813), [Use Advanced Dynamic Variables](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409735256845), and [Use Custom Dynamic Variables](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409494161677).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Edit a Template[](#toc_2)

To edit an existing email template, launch Apollo and click **Emails** > [**Templates**](https://app.apollo.io/#/templates). Then, click the template you want to edit.

[![Edit a email template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i6.png)

Make the necessary changes, then click **Save**. The template updates immediately and Apollo reflects your edits in any sequence step that uses it.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Save Email Templates from Sequences[](#toc_3)

When [creating or editing a sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409231193101), you can save any email as a template. This enables you and your team to use the email again across Apollo.

To save an email in a sequence as a template, click the **Save as a new template** checkbox. Then, name the template and click **Save**.

[![Save an email in a sequence as a template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i7.png)

You've now saved the email template and can use it in other sequences.

Find Your Saved Templates

Click **Emails** > [**Templates**](https://app.apollo.io/#/templates) to find any email template you save from a sequence.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add an Email Template to a Sequence[](#toc_4)

Use existing email templates in your sequences to streamline email content creation and share your [most effective messaging tactics](https://www.apollo.io/academy/how-to-write-cold-emails-anyone-will-respond-to) with your team.

When you [create or edit a sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409231193101), add a step for an automatic or manual email. Then, when editing the template, click the **Load templates** icon and select the one you want to use for the sequence step.

[![Add a template to a sequence step.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i8.png)

You can either clone the template or link to the template.

[![Link or clone the template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i9.png)

*   **Clone**: Click **Clone** to make a new copy of the selected email template. If you edit the cloned template, it does not impact the original version.
*   **Link**: Click **Link** to use the selected email template across multiple sequences. If you edit the linked template, Apollo applies your changes to the original version, including in any sequence steps that feature the template.

If you choose to link the template, Apollo informs you if the template is shared across sequences. Either use the template in its existing form or click the links in the warning message to unlink or edit the template.

[![Edit or unlink the template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_templates/i0.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Custom fields allow you to capture individualized research about a contact, account, or user and leverage them in Apollo sequence email templates for open-time personalization. **Custom Contact** fields allow you to capture information about individual people so you can easily re-use it in a template.

Refer to the section below for additional details about how to create custom fields for contacts.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Create a Custom Contact Field[](#toc_2)

Launch Apollo and then click **Settings**.

[![Settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i1.png)

Click **Contacts**.

[![Contacts](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i2.png)

Click **Custom Fields**.

[![Contacts](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i3.png)

Click **\+ New Field**.

[![New Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i4.png)

On the "Add Custom Contact Field" modal, type a descriptive name in the **Name** text-box.

[![New Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i5.png)

Select the field **Type** from the drop-down.

[![Field Types](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i6.png)

The available field types include:

| Field Name | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Single-line text | Allows you to include a single line of text for the contact field. You must specify the maximum number of characters for the field. |
| Multi-line text | Allows you to include a string of text that spans multiple lines. You must specify the maximum number of characters for the field. Line breaks count against the total character count. |
| Number | Allows you to include a number with or without decimals. You cannot use non-numeric characters. |
| Date | Allows you to type a date in the format of `Day/Month/Year` or select a date with the calendar widget. |
| Date/Time | Allows you to type a date in the format of `Day/Month/Year` or select a date with the calendar widget. Allows you to select a time in half-hour increments from the drop-down. |
| Checkbox | Allows you to specify either `True` or `False` within the field's drop-down. |
| Picklist | Allows you to include an existing picklist or create a new picklist with defined values. You can only select one value from the picklist. For additional information about creating picklists, please see [Create Global Picklists.](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412498624269) |
| Picklist (Multi-Select) | Allows you to include an existing picklist or create a new picklist with defined values. You can only select multiple values from the picklist. For additional information about creating picklists, please see [Create Global Picklists.](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412498624269) |
| Lookup-User | Allows you to specify a user from your account via a drop-down. |

No Type Changes After Creation

Please note, once you have created a custom field you cannot change the type.

Once you have defined the field **Type**, if you have connected Salesforce to your account, you can select a **Salesforce Contact Field** and/or a **Salesforce Lead Field**. Both of these are optional fields.

[![Salesforce Fields](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i7.png)

Use the checkbox below the Salesforce options to mark this **Contact Field** as read-only. This means that Apollo will only pull data directly from the mapped Salesforce fields but will not push data to Salesforce.

[![Read Only](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i8.png)

If you have selected **Picklist** or **Picklist (Multi-Select)** for the field **Type**, you have 2 options:

*   Select a previously created **picklist value set**. Click the drop-down for your available options.

[![Previous Picklist Options](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i35.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i35.png)

*   Create a new **picklist value set** and add the options that you would like to appear in the contact's profile.
    
    [![Picklist Options](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i9.png)
    

Click **Save**.

[![Save](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i36.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i36.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Edit a Custom Contact Field[](#toc_3)

Launch Apollo and then click **Settings**.

[![Settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i1.png)

Click **Contacts**.

[![Contacts](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i2.png)

Click **Custom Fields**.

[![Contacts](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i3.png)

Click the **Custom Field** you want to edit.

[![Custom Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i37.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i37.png)

If you would like to re-use a newly created **Picklist** in other fields, click the **Promote to Global Picklist Value Set** link.

[![Global Picklist](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i10.png)

In the "Promote to Global Picklist Value Set" modal, give the picklist a **Name** and then click **Continue**.

[![Global Picklist Name](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i11.png)

When you finish editing the custom **Contact Field**, click **Save**.

[![Global Picklist Name](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i12.png)

Your new custom **Contact Field** is now usable in a contact's profile.

[![Completed Custom Contact Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i33.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_and_edit_custom_fields/i33.png)

## Overview[](#overview)

Bear With Us, It's in Beta!

**Playbooks** are in **Beta** development, and may exhibit unexpected behavior. For more information about **Playbooks**, refer to the [Playbooks Overview (BETA)](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/6985034817677) article.

**Playbooks** are tools you can use to group **accounts** through an ordered series of engagement steps. You have the ability to create your own **Playbooks**.

Refer to the steps below to create a **Playbook**.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Create a Playbook[](#createaplaybook)

Launch Apollo and hover over **Engage** in the navbar, then click **Playbooks (beta)**.

Click **+Add Playbook**.

[![Add Playbook](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i2.png)

Enter the name of your **Playbook**.

[![Playbook Name](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i3.png)

Click the **Playbook Ruleset** drop-down menu and select the ruleset you want to apply to your **Playbook**.

[![Playbook Rulesets](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i4.png)

Alternatively, you can click the **+New Folder** button to create a new folder for your **Playbook**.

[![New Folder](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i6.png)

Click the **X** to close the window and apply your change.

[![Close Window](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i6a.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i6a.png)

You can type phrases in the **Tags** textbox, then click "Create new tag" below them to add new tags.

[![Create Tags](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i7a.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_a_playbook_beta/i7a.png)

Click "Create."
