## FAQ: How Do I Change the Default Delimiter on My Computer?[](#toc_8)

Apollo supports the following delimiters:

*   Comma (,)
*   Semicolon (;)
*   Colon (:)
*   Pipe (|)

If you encounter any formatting issues when you upload your file, you likely need to change your default settings. Follow the instructions below to update your settings. Then, try to upload the CSV file again.

It's Out of Our Hands!

Please note, the following steps refer to services outside of Apollo's control. If you have any questions about these instructions, please reach out to [Apple](https://support.apple.com/mac) or [Microsoft](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us) for further assistance.

**Mac**

To change the default delimiter on your Mac:

1.  Close the Excel application and click the **Apple** icon.
2.  Click **System Settings** > **General** > **Language and Region**.
3.  Scroll to **Number format** and change the decimal separator to one of the supported delimiters.
4.  Re-attempt the CSV upload in Apollo.

**PC**

To change the default delimiter on your PC:

1.  Launch the Windows **Start Menu** and click **Control Panel**.
2.  Click **Regional and Language Options** > **Regional Options** > **Customize/Additional settings** (Windows 10).
3.  Change the delimiter in the **List separator** section to one of the Apollo-supported characters.
4.  Click **OK** twice to confirm the change.
5.  Restart your machine. Then, re-attempt the CSV upload in Apollo.

Need a Helping Hand?

Have you already updated the default delimiter on your computer and are still having trouble with your CSV upload? Reach out to our friendly [technical support team](https://www.apollo.io/contact-us) for further guidance.

## Overview[](#toc_0)

Once you have [connected your calendar and configured your default meeting settings](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8792552682125), you can access the Apollo Meetings dashboard. From here, you can:

*   Create, edit, and activate meeting types.
*   Access your meeting schedule links.
*   View your scheduled, past, and canceled meetings.
*   Amend your default settings.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Create and Edit Meeting Types[](#toc_1)

Create meeting types to distinguish between the meetings you host and remain in control of who can book you, when prospects can schedule meetings, and for what purpose.

You can edit the existing default meeting types or create new ones. There are 3 different types of meetings that you can create:

*   **Single-host**: This meeting type only ever has one host. Single-host meetings should be used for one-on-one discussions with your prospect.
*   **Multi-host**: This meeting type has multiple hosts that co-host the meeting. When a prospect schedules a meeting of this type, all hosts must be available at the same time for the calendar slot to be available.
*   **Round robin host**: This meeting type rotates between different hosts each time it is used to schedule a meeting. Round-robin meetings should also be used for one-on-one discussions. You can choose to rotate hosts based on either the availability of hosts for certain time slots or the equal distribution of hosts so that each host is booked as part of a rotation one by one.

Different Plan, Different Possibilities

If you are on a free Apollo plan, you can activate up to 6 meeting types at a time.

However, if you are on a paid plan, the world is your oyster! You can create and activate as many meeting types as you like.

### Step 1: Create a New Meeting Type[](#toc_2)

This process walks you through the specifics of creating a new single-host meeting type, but multi-host and round-robin host meeting types are created in a similar way. To learn about the small differences when creating those meeting types, refer to the [Create Multi-Host and Round Robin Host Meeting Types](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173#toc_8) section of this article.

To create a new single-host meeting type:

Launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/meeting-types). Click **Create**, then choose the **Single-host** option.

[![Create New Meeting Type](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i6.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Step 2: Add the Meeting Type Details[](#toc_3)

First, name your meeting type. This will make it easier for your prospects to identify if they are booking the right type of meeting.

[![Meeting Type Name Text-Box](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i44.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i44.png)

Then, click 1 of the **Meeting duration** options to specify how long you want this type of meeting to last.

[![Duration Radio Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i45.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i45.png)

To personalize the link for this meeting type, edit the text in the **Meeting link** text box. Click the **Copy** icon on the right to copy the link.

[![Edit and Copy Link in Meeting Link Text-Box](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i46.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i46.png)

It Can Always Wait!

If you are not ready to copy the link right away, fear not! When you finish creating the new meeting type, you can access and copy the link from the **Meeting Types** tab at any time.

[![Copy Link Button in Meeting Type Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i5.png)

Click the meeting location drop-down and choose which video conference platform will host your meetings: **Google Meet**, **Zoom**, or a **Custom meeting link**.

[![Video Conference Link Text Box](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i47.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i47.png)

Add a description in the **Meeting Description** text box to give guests more context about the purpose of this meeting type.

[![Description Text Box](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i48.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i48.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Step 3: Set Your Availability[](#toc_4)

Now you are ready to set your availability for this meeting type.

Apollo automatically adds your default timezone to this meeting type. If you want to make any changes, click the **Current timezone** drop-down on the right and select the timezone of your choice.

[![Time-Zone Drop-Down on Create New Meeting Type Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i49.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i49.png)

Click the checkboxes next to the days you want to appear available to guests for this type of meeting. Then, set your open time slots using the drop-down options on the right of each day.

[![Open Time Slots Section of Create New Meeting Type Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i50.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i50.png)

As Easy As Pie

Apollo displays the default time slots you configured in the settings during the initial set-up. Only follow the steps to change your open time slots if you want to customize your availability for this specific meeting type.

Click the **+** button on the right to create additional time slots per day. Then, use the drop-down to amend the times according to your availability. You can add as many extra time slots per day as you like.

[![+ Button on Right of Time Slots](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i51.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i51.png)

If you want to replicate your availability for other days of the week, click the **Copy** icon. Then, click the checkbox next to the days for which you want to enable the same open time slots. When ready, click **Apply**.

[![Copy Open Time Slots Icon](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i52.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i52.png)

Click the **trash can** icon to delete an additional time slot.

[![Trash Can Icon on the Right of Time Slot](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i53.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i53.png)

Next, set your meeting buffers. This option ensures that you cannot be booked for a certain amount of time you set before and/or after a meeting.

[![Set your meeting buffers.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i54.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i54.png)

Set a minimum schedule notice to prevent guests from scheduling last-minute meetings with you. Set a maximum number of meetings to prevent overbooking your calendar during certain periods.

[![Minimum Schedule Notice Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i55.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i5.png)

You can also set a maximum date range to ensure your guests don't schedule time with you too far into the future.

[![Maximum Date Range Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i56.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i56.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Step 4: Choose Your Intake Form Questions[](#toc_5)

By default, your intake form requires prospects to enter their name and email address. You cannot edit or remove these fields from your form.

To add more questions to your form:

Click **Add a question**.

[![Add a new question.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i57.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i57.png)

Choose from standard options such as company size and phone number, or create a custom question with your own input types.

[![Choose your question.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i31.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i31.png)

If you choose **Single-select** or **Multi-select** as your input type for a custom question, you need to provide answers that the prospects can select.

[![Provide answers for certain question types.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i58.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i58.png)

By default, Apollo sets added questions as optional. This means that the prospect does not need to answer them to schedule a meeting. Click the **Set as required** checkbox if you want to make a question mandatory. Then, click **Save**.

[![Make a question mandatory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i59.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i59.png)

To sort your questions in a different order, drag and drop the question you want to move using the icon on the left side.

[![Sort your questions.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i60.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i60.png)

To edit a question, click the **pencil** icon on the right side of it. To delete the question from your form, click the **trash can** icon.

[![Edit or delete an added question.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i61.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i61.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Step 5: Add an Email Reminder[](#toc_6)

To ensure that a prospect remembers to attend a meeting they booked with you, set up an automatic email reminder for them. You can skip this step if you prefer not to send a reminder.

To set up an email reminder:

Toggle the **Inactive** option to **Active**.

[![Edit or delete an added question.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i62.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i62.png)

You can keep or edit the default email subject and text Apollo provides. To edit the text field, use the options along the edit bar at the bottom of the field. You can insert links, images, [dyanmic variables](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409415084813), and [snippets](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/11509551262093).

[![Edit or delete an added question.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i63.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i63.png)

To preview your email, click the **eyeball** icon at the top left. If you want to preview the email in an inbox, click **Send test email to me**. Apollo then sends the preview to the default email inbox connected to your Apollo account.

[![Preview your email reminder.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i64.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i64.png)

In the timing section, choose when you want to send your email reminder. If you want to send multiple reminders, click **Add timing**. You can add up to 3 reminders.

[![Add an email reminder.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i66.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i66.png)

When you have added all details for this single-host meeting type, click **Create meeting**.

[![Finish creating your meeting type.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i67.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i67.png)

You have now created a new single-host meeting type.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Create Single-host Meeting Types for Other Users (Admins Only)[](#toc_7)

If you are an Apollo admin for your organization, you can create single-host meetings that other users host. This option enables you to apply standard templates to different types of meetings, such as demo meetings, and add or remove hosts as needed.

The steps you as an admin follow to create these meeting types are similar to [single-host meetings](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173#toc_3). The most significant difference is that you need to choose the hosts for the meeting type.

Host Your Own Meetings

If you are an Apollo admin and want to create a single-host meeting type that only you can use, only add yourself as a host when creating the meeting type.

When choosing hosts, click **All hosts** to make the meeting type available to everyone, or click **Select individual hosts or teams** to add specific members of your organization as hosts.

[![Choose the meeting hosts.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i20005.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i20005.png)

You also need to use an [intake form template](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/17919970244109#toc_2) rather than adding intake form questions for a single meeting type.

As you create single-host meetings for your organization, you should educate potential meeting hosts on how to find and use these meeting types. To find these single-host meetings, users should launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/meeting-types). The admin-created meetings show a special icon in place of the activation slider.

[![Find these meeting types.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i20006.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i20006.png)

As an admin, you can also add a link for the single-host meeting type to a [sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409237165837) in Apollo that can be used by the hosts of the meeting. The link includes a [variable](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409415084813) that populates information specific to each meeting host.

To copy this link, launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/meeting-types). Then, click **additional options** > **Copy Link** for the single-host meeting type that you created.

[![Copy meeting type link.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i73.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i73.png)

When you paste the link into an email within a sequence, the preview shows how the variable will populate for the hosts you assigned to the meeting type.

[![Variable populates.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i74.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i74.png)

To manage the single-host meetings you create, launch Apollo and click **Meetings** > [**Admin console**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/meeting-types). Then, access the **Team's Meeting** tab.

[![Admin Console Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/apollo_meetings_overview/i20002.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/apollo_meetings_overview/i20002.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Create Multi-Host and Round Robin Host Meeting Types[](#toc_8)

The steps you follow to create these meeting types are similar to [single-host meetings](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173#toc_3). There are currently a few slight differences:

The number of meeting types that you can create is also restricted if you are on a free Apollo plan:

*   For free plans, individual users can create up to 6 single-host and multi-host meeting types. Also, teams can create up to 6 round-robin meeting types.
*   For paid plans, you can create an unlimited number of meeting types.

All other steps are the same. Follow the instructions [**in the sections above**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173#toc_2) to create multi-host or round robin meeting types.

Inbound Routers Bring More than Meeting Routing

Apollo admins can add an intake form to the scheduling process for all meeting types by [creating an inbound router](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/17919970244109)! This enables admins to add more questions to intake forms, and route prospects to different meeting types based on their answers.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Edit an Existing Meeting Type[](#toc_9)

To edit a meeting type:

Launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/meeting-types). Click the **Additional Options (...)** button on the top right of the meeting type you want to edit, then click **Edit**.

[![Additional Options Button on Meeting Type Block](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i2.png)

Make edits to the meeting type details and then click **Save changes**.

[![Submit Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i69.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i69.png)

You have now edited an existing meeting type.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Access Your Meeting Schedule Links[](#toc_10)

Now that you have created or edited your meeting types, you can copy the meeting schedule links and then share them with your future guests.

To access the link:

Launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/meeting-types). Click the **Meeting Types** tab. Then, click **Copy link** under the meeting type you want to share with a prospect.

[![Copy Link Button in Meeting Type Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i5.png)

You have now copied the unique meeting schedule link for a specific meeting type.

### Preview the Guest Scheduling Workflow[](#toc_11)

To gauge your guests' scheduling experience and ensure you have configured the details of each meeting type correctly, you can access a preview of the guest scheduling workflow.

Launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/meeting-types). Then, click **Preview** on the bottom-right of the meeting type you want to edit.

[![Additional Options Button on Meeting Type Block](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i70.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i70.png)

Apollo directs you to the same scheduling process as the one prospects will follow for that meeting type. Click through the workflow to visualize the steps they will take to book time on your calendar.

[![Meeting Schedule Preview Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i23.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i23.png)

To edit the workflow, return to the **Meeting Types** tab in Apollo. Then, follow the steps in the [Edit an Existing Meeting Type](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173#toc_9) section of this article.

[Back to Top](#top)

## View Your Scheduled Meetings[](#toc_12)

To view your scheduled meetings:

Launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/meeting-types). Then, click the **Scheduled Meetings** tab.

[![Scheduled Meetings Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i24.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i24.png)

Click **Upcoming** to view the meetings in your pipeline. From here, you can view the date, time, and duration of your upcoming meetings.

[![Upcoming Meetings Tab in Meetings Dashboard](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i25.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i25.png)

Click the guest name to access more information about the contact that scheduled time with you.

[![Contact Profile Info Modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i27.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i27.png)

Click **Pending** to view meetings that have not been booked yet. This tab tracks the specific times you set aside for prospects [when adding meeting links in Gmail](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409227868301) via the Apollo Chrome extension. When a prospect books a time, you can find the meeting information in the **Upcoming** tab.

[![View your pending meetings.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i43.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i43.png)

Click **Past** to view the meetings that you have already attended.

[![Past Meetings Tab in Meetings Dashboard](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i28.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/manage_your_meetings_in_apollo/i28.png)

## Overview[](#toc_0)

With the [Apollo Chrome extension installed](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/apolloio-find-b2b-contact/alhgpfoeiimagjlnfekdhkjlkiomcapa), you no longer need to jump between your Google Calendar and LinkedIn account to research your meeting guests. Get to know your prospects from one centralized location.

To research contacts directly in your Google Calendar:

1.  Go to your Google Calendar, then create a new meeting or open an existing meeting.
2.  Click the Apollo icon next to an invitee. [![Meeting](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/google_calendar_integration/i17.png)](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/NEED%20IMAGE)
3.  The Chrome extension opens on the right side. Access the following tabs to learn more about a contact and their company. • **Overview**: This tab provides all the available data Apollo has for the contact's company.  
    • **Insights**: This tab shows [signals](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/13152837789837) related to the company, along with information about the company's technologies, hiring trends, and funding rounds.  
    • **Colleagues**: This tab shows information about the company's employees. Use filters to find prospects by factors such as job title, or search for them directly. You can also save a contact directly from this tab.  
    • **Activities**: This tab shows previous interactions that you and your team have had with the company. You can also log new activities such as notes or tasks directly to Apollo.  
    [![Details](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/google_calendar_integration/i19.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/google_calendar_integration/i19.png)

Extend Yourself to Gmail

If you use Google Calendar, you probably also use Gmail. And guess what? Apollo's Chrome extension can also be used in Gmail! Refer to [Use the Apollo Chrome Extension in Gmail](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409227868301) for more details.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_0)

Use the Chrome Extension to add Apollo functionality to your Gmail mailbox and:

*   Use your Apollo templates and snippets in emails.
*   Set nudges to remind yourself to follow up on emails.
*   Add meeting links to emails so prospects can easily schedule meetings with you.
*   Sync your email interactions from Gmail to Salesforce.

[![The Chrome extension in Gmail.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i25.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i25.png)

The following sections detail how to use the added Apollo functionality in your Gmail mailbox.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Use Templates and Snippets in Gmail[](#toc_1)

To load your Apollo [email templates](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409238165389-Create-and-Edit-Email-Templates) and [snippets](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/11509551262093-Create-and-Edit-Snippets):

1.  Launch the Gmail mailbox that you have synced with Apollo, and then create a new email.
2.  Click **Templates** or **Snippets**. [![Add a template or snippet.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i26.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i26.png)
3.  In the pop-up, click an existing template or snippet to load it. If you prefer to create a new template or snippet, click **Create new**. [![Choose the template or snippet to add.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i27.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i27.png)
4.  With the template or snippet loaded, make any edits to your email and then click **Send**. [![Send your email.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i28.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i28.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add Follow-up Reminders in Gmail[](#toc_2)

Nudges push email chains back to the top of your Gmail mailbox. This ensures that you always remember to follow up on important emails at the right time.

To set a nudge for your email:

1.  Launch your connected Gmail mailbox. Then, create a new email.
2.  Click **Nudge**. [![Add a nudge.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i39.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i39.png)
3.  In the pop-up, choose whether you still send a follow-up email if the recipient does not reply. Then, set a time for the follow-up email to send. [![Choose your nudge settings.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i29.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i29.png)
4.  Confirm the timing of the nudge. Then, click **Schedule a nudge**. [![Schedule your nudge.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i30.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i30.png)
5.  The **Nudge** icon changes to show a checkmark when Apollo adds a nudge to your email. [![The checkmark means your nudge is set.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i31.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i31.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Provide Meeting Links in Gmail[](#toc_3)

Gmail is a One-on-One Game

Single-host meeting links are currently available to use in Gmail. This meeting type is used for one-on-one meetings with prospects.

If you want prospects to meet with you and your teammates, refer to [Manage Your Meetings in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173) to learn how to create and provide links for multi-host meeting types.

When adding meeting links in Gmail, you have 2 options:

*   Provide a meeting link that allows prospects to choose any available time. The available time slots are based on your meeting settings.
*   Choose specific times when prospects can book meetings. You can also block off your chosen times on your own calendar.

To provide a meeting link with general availability:

1.  Launch your connected Gmail mailbox, and then create a new email.
2.  Click **Meetings**. [![Add meeting links.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i40.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i40.png)
3.  In the pop-up, hover over the meeting type you want to use. Then, click the **link** icon. If you prefer to create a new meeting type, click **Create new**. [![Generate a general link.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i32.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i32.png)
4.  Apollo inserts the link into your email body. Make any final edits, then click **Send**. [![Send your email.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i33.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i33.png)

To choose specific times that your prospect can schedule:

1.  Launch the connected Gmail mailbox, and then create a new email.
2.  Click **Meetings**. [![Add meeting links.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i40.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i40.png)
3.  In the pop-up, hover on the meeting type you want to use, then click the **calendar** icon. [![Choose specific meeting times.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i34.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i34.png)
4.  Click the times on the calendar that you want to make available to the prospect. To prevent anyone else from booking those times on your calendar, toggle on the **Reserve time slots** option. [![Select the available times.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i35.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i35.png)
5.  Click **Insert selected slots**.
6.  Apollo inserts the links to your chosen times in your email body. Make any final edits to your email, then click **Send**. [![Send your email.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i36.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i36.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Sync Email Interactions to Salesforce[](#toc_4)

Integration Required

To log emails in Salesforce, you must enable Apollo's integration with Salesforce. If you haven't already integrated, refer to [Connect Apollo to Your Salesforce Account](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4414356051725) to set up the integration.

To log email interactions in Salesforce:

1.  Launch your connected Gmail mailbox and create a new email.
2.  Enter an email address. Then, click **Salesforce**. [![Sync emails to Salesforce.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i38.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i38.png)
3.  To automatically track future interactions with this email address, toggle on the **Log this email to Salesforce** option.
4.  If a Salesforce lead or contact matches the email address you entered, Apollo auto-populates them.
    
    If there is no match, search for and select the Salesforce lead/contact you want to use to log this email exchange. [![Add the Salesforce lead or contact.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i41.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i41.png)
    
5.  (Optional) To track the email exchange in a [Salesforce opportunity](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4415294726029) too, search for and add the opportunity in the same way.
6.  A green checkmark confirms that you have successfully selected the Salesforce lead/contact. Click **Log email**. [![Confirm email sync.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i42.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_the_apollo_chrome_extension_in_gmail/i42.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_0)

Standard Features for Everybody!

All users across [all plans](https://www.apollo.io/pricing) can access analytics features such as email tracking and Apollo-provided reports and dashboards for email messaging, deal metrics, and more. If you require customizable reports and dashboards, work with your Apollo representative or contact the [Apollo sales team](mailto:%20sales@apollo.io) to move to a Custom plan.

Analytics provide you with actionable data you can use to transform your company's sales efforts. One facet of the analytics suite is the reports feature. Reports provide you with a means of aggregating in-app metrics into various visualization types while using specific filters to refine the visualizations.

Refer to the sections below to learn how to create a report and better understand the various components you have at your disposal.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Access Reports in Apollo[](#toc_1)

To access reports, launch Apollo and click **Engage** > [**Analytics**](https://app.apollo.io/#/analytics). Then, click the **Reports** tab.

[![Reports](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i53.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i53.png)

Any previously created reports are available in the **All reports** section.

[![View all of the previously created reports.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i54.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i54.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Create a New Custom Report[](#toc_2)

Launch Apollo and click **Engage** > [**Analytics**](https://app.apollo.io/#/analytics). Then, go to the **Reports** tab and click **Create report**.

There are 5 main configuration components of any custom report: metrics, dimensions, filters, visualization, and date range. The sections below outline how to configure each of these custom report components.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Configure Metrics[](#toc_3)

From the new custom report, click the **Metrics** tab.

[![Metrics](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i51.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i51.png)

Metrics define what you want to measure. You can include as many metrics as you need in each custom report.

Apollo groups metrics into 9 top-level categories:

| Category | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Calls | Metrics related to the performance and status of calls made with the Apollo **Dialer** |
| Emails | Metrics related to the performance of emails sent through sequences. |
| Tasks | Metrics related to the creation and completion of tasks in Apollo. |
| Linkedin Tasks | Metrics related to the creation and completion of tasks created from the Apollo extension on LinkedIn. |
| Account | Metrics related to the interactions with accounts in Apollo. |
| Contact | Metrics related to the interactions with contacts in Apollo. |
| Deal | Metrics related to the performance of deals in the Apollo platform. |
| Person | Metric related to the number of net new people saved as contacts in Apollo. |
| Company | Metric related to the number of net new companies saved as accounts in Apollo. |

Click the relevant metrics that you want to include in the custom report. Apollo adds the selected metrics as columns in the table.

[![Metrics Example](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i6.png)

Metrics Per Report

To gain optimal results, limit yourself to less than 25 metrics per report. For the clearest results, start with the most important metrics and add additional fields only if necessary.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Configure Dimensions[](#toc_4)

From the new custom report, click the **Dimensions** tab.

[![Dimensions](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i7.png)

Dimensions define the data that you want to use to measure your metrics. Apollo groups dimensions into 7 categories:

| Category | Description |
| --- | --- |
| User | Dimension related to the specific individual(s) taking the action in Apollo. |
| Date | Dimensions related to the time period of the action taken in Apollo. For example, day, hour, month, year, etc. |
| Contact/Person | Dimensions related to the information about the individuals contacted from Apollo. For example, their persona type, their location, their stage in the sales pipeline, etc. |
| Account/Company | Dimensions related to the information about the companies contacted from Apollo. For example, the account name, the number of company employees, the industry, related keywords, etc. |
| Deal | Dimensions related to the deals in Apollo. For example, the deal owner, the current stage of the deal, etc. |
| Email | Dimensions related to the type of emails sent from Apollo. For example, email subject and template used can be dimensions. |
| Phone Call | Dimensions related to the purpose and disposition of the phone calls made from Apollo. |
| Sequence | Dimensions related to the name of the sequence or the specific step that was used to engage with the prospects in Apollo. |

Dimensions Per Report

You might notice some overlap between specific items in the metrics and dimensions lists. This is because you can use many types of data as either a metric or dimension.

Click the relevant dimension(s) that you want to include in the custom report. You can add a maximum of 2 dimensions per report. If you add a persona as a dimension, data will be grouped by active personas, and [inactive personas](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/6128371592845) will not appear in your reports.

Apollo adds the selected dimensions as rows in the table.

[![Dimensions Example](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i8.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Configure Filters[](#toc_5)

From the new custom report, click **Filters**.

[![Filters View](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i9.png)

Click **Add Filter**.

[![Add Filters](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i12.png)

Filters are specific subsets of data that you want to visualize in your report. You can add as many filters as you need in each custom report. Apollo groups filters into the same categories as those in the [Dimensions](#15) section.

Click **Select Filter** to choose the filters to include in the custom report. Then, click the **Select** drop-down to include or exclude additional metrics of your choice.

[![Filter Examples](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i21.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i21.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Configure Date Range[](#toc_6)

The date range defines the timeframe of the data included in the custom report.

From the new custom report, click **Filters**. Then, click the date range drop-down and select either a pre-defined date range or a custom range.

[![Choose a different date range.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i52.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i52.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Configure Visualization[](#toc_7)

From the new custom report, click **Visualization**.

[![Visualization View](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i15.png)

The visualization options enable you to change how Apollo displays the custom report data. You can choose from a variety of pre-configured types.

*   Table ![Table](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i32.png)
*   Column ![Column](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i33.png)
*   Bar ![Bar](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i34.png)
*   Line ![Line](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i35.png)
*   Area ![Area](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i36.png)
*   Pie ![Pie](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i37.png)
*   Heatmap ![Heatmap](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i38.png)

Click the visualization you want to use for the custom report.

[![Visualization Options](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i16.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i16.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Run the Custom Report[](#toc_8)

After you have finished configuring the custom report, click **Run**.

[![Run Report](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i18.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i18.png)

To finalize your work, enter a name for the report, select the folder where it will live, and then click **Save & Finish**.

[![Save Report](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i19.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/analytics_overview_custom_reports/i19.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

To access these pre-built reports, launch Apollo and click **Engage** > [**Analytics**](https://app.apollo.io/#/analytics). Then, click the **Reports** tab and access the **Created by Apollo** folder.

Change It Up!

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Analyze the performance of your emails to gain valuable insights about your target audience. The more you evaluate what works and what doesn't, the more you can test and improve your **Sequences** to increase engagement.

Refer to the sections below for more information about the **Email Analytics** you can access in Apollo.

## Access Apollo Email Analytics[](#toc_2)

When you send emails in Apollo, you can track your **Open**, **Click**, and **Response** rates. You can access this data from within a **Sequence**, from a **Contact's** profile page, or from the **Analytics** page.

### Access Campaign-Specific Email Data from a Sequence[](#toc_3)

Launch Apollo and click **Engage**.

[![Engage](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i6.png)

For a holistic view of all email data, click the **Emails** tab.

[![Analytics](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i7.png)

If you want to see the data for a specific **User**, **Email**, **Sequence**, or **Contact**, use the **Filters** on the left. Then, hover your mouse over the **Status** icons on the right to view more specific email insights.

[![Emails Tab Filters](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i8.png)

You can also view email data from the **Sequences** tab.

[![Sequences Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i9.png)

To review the data from a specific **Sequence**, use the **Filters** on the left. Apollo displays the overall stats on the right.

[![Sequence Stats](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i10.png)

Click a **Sequence** to see more in-depth statistics for it.

[![More Sequence Stats](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i11.png)

To take full advantage of **Apollo Analytics**, please refer to the [Build and Access Reports in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4410826842381-Build-and-Access-Reports-In-Apollo)" article.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Access Contact-Specific Email Data from a Contact's Profile Page[](#toc_4)

Launch Apollo, click **Search**, and then click **People**.

[![People Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i1.png)

Use the **Search** bar to find a specific **contact**.

[![Search Bar Filter](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i2.png)

Click the **contact's** name to open their profile page.

[![Click on Contact](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i3.png)

Click **Show Activities**.

[![Show Activities](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i4.png)

Scroll through the **Activities** and hover your mouse over the **Email Status** icons to view the time and date that the contact **Received**, **Opened**, **Clicked**, or **Replied** to your email.

[![Email Status Icons](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i5.png)

The Click Track Dilemma

Please note, in order to view whether a **contact** has clicked on any links that you have shared in your emails, you need to enable **Click Tracking**; however, you should use this super power wisely! **Click Tracking** doesn't always play nicely with SPAM filters. For more information, please refer to the "[Click Tracking in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409803614093-Click-Tracking-in-Apollo-)" article.

If you want to track who clicks and watches your **Vidyard** videos, it is much safer for you to do so with **Vidyard** Analytics instead. Refer to the "[Access Vidyard Analytics](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423013995405-Access-Vidyard-Analytics)" article for further details.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

The Apollo Chrome extension enables you to automate your follow-up process within Gmail so that you can keep on top of your pipeline, reduce manual tasks from your workflow, and focus your time on the interactions that matter.

When you send an email in Gmail, you can schedule a follow-up sequence for multiple recipients within the same email thread.

Refer to the section below for more information about the steps to take to enroll your email recipients in a follow-up sequence within Gmail.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add Contacts to A Follow-Up Sequence Within an Email Thread[](#toc_2)

Launch Gmail and open the email to which you want to schedule a follow-up cadence. Then, click **Add to follow-up sequence**.

[![Add to follow-up sequence button in Gmail](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i1.png)

Click the **Select a follow-up sequence** drop-down to choose the appropriate sequence, and then click **Continue**.

[![Follow-up sequence drop-down and continue button in modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i2.png)

A Handy Tip or Two!

Please note, Apollo recommends that you tailor your follow-up messages to the specific needs and pain points of the email recipients. For example, if you have just had a demo with a team and are following up to try and close the deal, your messaging should differ greatly from if a contact has been ghosting you for the past 2 weeks. For the steps to create new sequences, refer to the [Create a Sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409231193101-Create-a-Sequence) article. If you're looking for some helpful tips to create powerful messaging for your sequences, hop into the [Craft Killer Sales Email Messaging](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5120329878669-Build-an-Outbound-Sales-Process-Craft-Killer-Sales-Email-Messaging) article.

To view a brief outline of the steps in the selected sequence, click **See steps**.

[![See steps button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i3.png)

Click **View sequence in Apollo** if you want to take a closer look at the sequence or make any edits before enrolling the contacts from your email.

[![View sequence in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i4.png)

Apollo populates your default mailbox in the **Send emails from:** drop-down. To make changes, click the drop-down and select an alternative mailbox.

[![Send emails from drop-down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i5.png)

In the Mood for More Mailboxes?

Wondering how to connect additional mailboxes? Jump on into the [Link Your Mailbox to Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409127806093-Link-Your-Mailbox-to-Apollo-io) article for more details. However, please note that you can only connect more than 1 mailbox per user if you are on a Professional or Custom Apollo plan.

If you have multiple recipients in the email, you can choose who you make the **Primary** contact.

Hold the Phone—What Does That Mean?

When you add multiple recipients to a follow-up sequence, only the primary contact appears in the "contact" and "email" tabs within the sequence in Apollo. [![Email tab on sequence page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i6.png) ](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i6.png)But don't panic—the other recipients are still within sight! Apollo displays the email in the activity feed on a contact's profile page. [![Activities card on profile page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i7.png) ](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i7.png)Apollo also uses the primary contact at the sequence ruleset level. For example, if you set the sequence to finish when a contact responds, Apollo only stops the sequence if the primary contact responds. For more information about how sequence rulesets work, please refer to the [Create a Sequence Ruleset](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409396858509-Create-Sequence-Rulesets) article.

To change the primary contact, hover your mouse over the contact name. Then, click **Set primary**.

[![Set primary button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i8.png)

One at a Time, Folks!

Please note, you cannot set the same primary contact in more than one email thread per sequence. You also cannot add the same email thread to more than one follow-up sequence at a time.

If you want to remove any recipients from the follow-up sequence, click the checkbox to the left of a contact's name. You cannot uncheck the primary contact.

[![Checkboxes next to recipient names](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i9.png)

Click **Set follow-up** to enroll the contacts in the follow-up sequence immediately.

[![Set Follow-Up Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i10.png)

Alternatively, click **Schedule follow-up** if you want to schedule the sequence for later.

[![Schedule follow-up button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i11.png)

Then, click the radio button next to your preferred scheduled time or manually select a custom date and time for the follow-up sequence to begin.

[![Schedule add to sequence modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i12.png)

Click **Schedule**.

[![Schedule button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i13.png)

You have now added the recipients from your email into a follow-up sequence.

[![Success Modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i14.png)

If the first step in your follow-up sequence is an automatic email, Apollo sends the message within the same email thread in Gmail.

[![Follow-up messages in thread Modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i15.png)

Watch Your Step!

Please note, if the first step in your follow-up sequence is any other task, such as a manual email, LinkedIn task, or call, Apollo displays the next steps in your Apollo tasks. Please check the **Tasks** tab in the Apollo app to continue with the next steps in the follow-up sequence. [![Tasks tab in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i16.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/send_follow_up_messages_in_gmail/i16.png)
