## Overview[](#toc_0)

Scorecards enable your sales leaders and teams to provide detailed feedback on [recorded conversations](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9632855570701) in Apollo. When you create scorecards with questions to assess video calls, leaders can use scorecard ratings to identify training opportunities for their sales teams.

The following sections share how to build and submit scorecards on conversations.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Create Scorecards[](#toc_1)

Admins Only

Only Apollo admins can create scorecards. If your team wants to use scorecards but doesn't have the necessary permissions, contact an Apollo admin in your organization.

To create a scorecard:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/conversations/recordings).
2.  Click **Scorecards**, then click **Create scorecard**. [![Create a scorecard.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i1.png)
3.  Name the scorecard. To build from a template, choose from the **Start with a template** drop-down. To build from scratch, leave the drop-down blank.
    
    Apollo provides 2 scorecard templates: **Discovery** and **Demo**. Each template includes several questions that are targeted to either discovery or demo conversation types. You can customize templates as needed to build a scorecard. [![Choose a template or build from scratch.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i2.png)
    
4.  Click **Build scorecard**.
5.  In the **Build** section, add, remove, and edit questions, and preview the scorecard in the **Preview** section. If you're building from a template, the scorecard is pre-populated with questions. [![Preview the scorecard.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i3.png)
6.  Toggle **Set as required** on or off to change whether the user submitting the scorecard must address a question. [![Require an answer.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i4.png)
7.  To add a question, click **Add question**, then choose the type of question you want to add. Refer to the [Understand Scorecard Question Types](#toc_4) section for more information about each question type. [![Add a question.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i5.png)
8.  To remove a question, click **Delete**. [![Delete a question.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i6.png)
9.  To rearrange the order of questions, click and drag the handle at the top-left of a question. [![Reorder questions.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i7.png)
10.  When finished, click **Publish**. Confirm that you want to make the scorecard available to use. [![Activate the scorecard.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i8.png)

The scorecard is now live and available to use to [rate conversations](#toc_2).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Submit a Scorecard for a Conversation[](#toc_2)

To submit a scorecard for a conversation:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations/recordings). Then, click the conversation that you want to rate.
2.  Click **Scoring**, then select the scorecard that you want to use to rate the conversation. [![Choose a scorecard.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i9.png)
3.  Answer each question, then click **Submit scorecard**. Click **Add comment** to add more context for an answer. [![Submit your answers.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i10.png)

Your scorecard responses are now submitted. The user that you scored will receive an email notifying them that their conversation has been scored.

The **Responses** tab displays all of the scorecards that have been submitted for a conversation. Click **View** to review a scorecard's answers.

[![View scorecard responses.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i11.png)

Looking for more opportunities to measure and train your sales teams? Check out [Set and Track Team Goals in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20676039270541) to learn how to set goals for your team based on a variety of metrics.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Request Feedback[](#toc_3)

Ensure you receive the feedback that you need to improve by requesting scores for your conversations. After submitting a scoring request, your chosen evaluators will receive an email notifying them to submit a scorecard for your conversation.

To request an evaluation of your conversation:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations/recordings). Then, click the conversation that you want scored.
2.  Click **Scoring**, then click **Request score**. [![Request a score.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i20.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i20.png)
3.  Select the evaluator you want to score your conversation and the scorecard you want them to use. Then, click **Request**. [![Request a score.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i18.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/scorecards_conversations/i18.png)

After you submit your request, Apollo sends an email to notify the evaluator. You will receive an email notification when the evaluator submits the scorecard.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Understand Scorecard Question Types[](#toc_4)

By default, scorecards include an overall rating that requires the submitter to rate the conversation on a 1-5 scale. This question cannot be edited or removed.

You can also add several types of questions to scorecards, including:

[Back to Top](#top)

[![Build an Outbound Sales Process: Craft Killer Sales Email Messaging](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i1.png) ## Setting the Scene[](#toc_1) [![Setting the Scene](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/i1.png) Today, there are a number of tools and technologies that exist to help you become a more efficient and effective salesperson. These tools, however, do little to help you craft the right messaging to paint your product or service in the right light. This is still largely a manual, hands-on activity that requires careful planning and consideration. Despite the fact that there are, to date, no technologies to create an effective email message automatically, there are a number of tried and true methods, structures, and best practices for doing this more effectively. In his article “[**How To Write Killer Sales Emails… At Scale**](https://winningbydesign.com/how-to-write-killer-sales-emails-at-scale/),” Jacco van der Kooij of [Winning by Design](https://winningbydesign.com/) outlines the [**Research, Reference, Reward, and Request**](https://winningbydesign.com/how-to-write-killer-sales-emails-at-scale/) method—a means of creating winning email messages. We can apply this methodology to our outbound sales process and leverage the tools in the Apollo platform to make sure that we deliver personalized and relevant email messages at scale. [Back to Top](#top) ### The RRRR Method[](#toc_2) As we mentioned above, the RRRR method focuses on 4 primary functions: * Research * Reference * Reward * Request Each of these component pieces will help you to craft a personalized, relevant email message for your customer segments. In his article, van der Kooij is quick to point out that you cannot “sell over email.” **This is absolutely vital to remember.** Email is just one facet of a multi-touch outreach campaign; however, it is something that you need to get right if you want to get your foot in the door. Let’s take a look at the first stage of customer outreach—**Research**. [Back to Top](#top) #### Do Your Research![](#toc_3) Most businesses receive multiple emails each day from contacts who attempt to gain their business. It is no longer a simple matter of personalizing your outreach with a recipient’s name or company name. Outreach emails also need to be relevant. That means that you need to do your due diligence in trying to find as much information about each contact before you reach out to them. LinkedIn and the Apollo database both provide a lot of great information about contacts, but it may be worthwhile for you to dig a little deeper. Search the web for any recent publications that the contact may have. Find out what their alma matter is and what role they currently have. This information helps you to craft a strong opening line and shows your recipient that you have done some research so that your outreach doesn’t feel entirely cold. Once you have completed your research, don’t forget to fill in your **Product Market Fit** **Canvas**. Conducting this analysis will provide you with the context and purpose you need to write poignant messages that resonate with your target personas. | | A | B | | --- | --- | --- | | Who: Company | SMB Startups | YC Startups in Current batch | | Who: Titles | Founders | Founders | | Problem | * Need more opportunties
* Hard to build outbound system from scratch | * Generates as much revenue as possible pre-demo, but hard to set up | | Solution | * All in One
* 200M Contact Database
* Emailing Engine | * All in One sales platform for generating opportunities with 200M contacts
* Emailing Engine | | Value Prop | * Build a best-practice outbound engine in minutes | * Build a best-practice outbound engine in minutes | | Impact/Benefits | * Generate hundreds of qualifeid sales meetings | * Generate hundreds of qualified sales meetings and hit their Demo Day goals | | Proof Points | 5,000 SMB startups like XYZ do ABC | Hundreds of other YC startups like XYZ do ABC | Know Your Prospects Remember, the more specific and targeted your research is, the better chance you have of establishing a rapport with your prospects. When you do this at scale, you’ll need a place to store all of this information as it relates to specific contacts. This will make it easier for you to reference in your emails. Apollo allows you to store contact-specific research directly in a [**custom field**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412498825869-Create-Custom-Contact-Fields) that’s available on each **contact’s** profile. [![Profile](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i2.png) You can create custom fields to store research for **Accounts** in Apollo: [![Accounts](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i3.png) [Back to Top](#top) #### Determine Appropriate References[](#toc_4) References help to demonstrate to your email recipient that you understand what their pain points are and that you’ve worked with other customers who had the same set of problems or needs. You may be able to draw these conclusions by analyzing the details your research provides. For example, from the information available about a company’s technology stack or a contact’s vertical or role at an organization. In some ways, the references you make are related to your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP) and the problems that they need to solve. These companies are the ones who have benefited most from your product. If you need a refresher about what an ICP is and how to assemble it, check out this infographic: [![ICP](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i4.jpg)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i4.jpg) [Back to Top](#top) #### Describe The Reward[](#toc_5) This is your opportunity to further entice your email recipient and build credibility with them. Is there a resource that you can share with them from your company’s blog that gets to the heart of their pain points? Even better, are there any thought leadership materials that you created yourself that you can link to? Anything you can provide that indicates you are a worthwhile connection and that your organization is a trusted leader can help you to initiate that all-important first meeting. Forget the Attachments Remember to link to any resources you provide—attachments in first-contact emails can trigger SPAM blocking. For more information about avoid SPAM filters, check out the “[**Avoid SPAM Filters**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409225311885-Avoid-SPAM-Filters)” article. [Back to Top](#top) #### Formulate Your Request[](#toc_6) A well-formed call-to-action is a great way to close out your email. Without this, a recipient has no idea what you want from them or why you’ve contacted them in the first place. Even if you’ve crafted an email that is well-researched with amazing references and a great reward, the conversation stops here without a **Request**. Keep in mind what we mentioned earlier—you aren’t going to close a sale through email. Your request should be focused on setting up a call or meeting with the recipient. [Back to Top](#top) ### Put It All Together[](#toc_7) Remember, the goal of using the **RRRR Method** in outreach campaigns is to create a formula for crafting relevant and personalized email messages at scale. The people you are reaching out to are just as busy as you are—they don’t have time and won’t read something that doesn’t immediately grab their attention or apply to them. Subject lines are vitally important to grab a potential customer’s attention right away. In fact, 35% of email recipients open an email based on the [subject line alone](https://www.convinceandconvert.com/convince-convert/15-email-statistics-that-are-shaping-the-future/) and 69% of email recipients [report email as spam based solely on the subject line](https://www.invespcro.com/blog/email-subject-lines-statistics-and-trends/). In the example below, we’ve used 3 of the 4 components to create our subject line, **Research**, **Reference**, and **Request**. [![RRR](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i5.png) This subject matter makes a clear reference to the content of the email—“Salesforce/Adoption issues.” It also includes a strong call-to-action for the recipient—”Talk on Friday?” If the person who receives this email is a Salesforce user who has had difficulty adopting the platform at their organization, this should at least pique their interest enough to get them to open the email. Keep it Tight. Keep it Focused. This tried and tested tactic only works if you stay true to the company segments you have built out in your **Product Market Fit Canvas**. The **Reference** in your subject line absolutely should match the painpoints for the specific contacts who open it. In the case of our example above, we may have a killer subject line, but if we send a message with the same subject line to non-Salesforce users, we’re fighting a losing battle. Next, let’s take a look at how to craft the body of the message. The image below shows a breakdown of how each component should inform the contents of your email. [![RRR Components](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i6.png) Here’s how we applied each of those recommendations to the body copy of our own email message: [![RRR Email](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i7.png) Let’s analyze each individual component. We address the recipient by name; Jennifer. You can easily accomplish this at scale in Apollo with **[Basic Snippets](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409415084813-Use-Basic-Snippets)**. Then, we transition to the **Research** portion of the body copy. Your Linkedin profile shows that you led the Salesforce Implementation at Acme. Here, we’ve established that we know who we are talking to and what function or responsibilities they hold at their company. Next, we move on to the **Reference** portion of the body copy: Your peer at \_\_\_\_\_\_ experienced the exact same challenge. I wanted to share a link that shows how he solved the Salesforce Integration that resulted in increased adoption and made their reps more productive. In this part of the body copy, we have likened the pain points experienced by the recipient to a company that they might be familiar with. Additionally, we’ve provided some details around how they addressed these pain points and turned them into a positive. This helps to create rapport with our recipients and demonstrates that they aren’t the only person or business. Finally, we move on to the **Request** portion of the body copy: Jennifer, is this relevant for you? Here, our call-to-action comes in the form of a question. We’ve asked something specifically of our recipient in the hope that she will respond. In this instance, an affirmative answer is just as valuable as a negative one. This is because it allows us to continue the conversation, either specifically with Jennifer or we can follow up again to ask if there is someone else that we should talk to instead. If Jennifer does respond after a few follow-up emails, we may want to shift our focus to someone else in the organization if this account is a strong match for our **Product Market Fit Canvas**. [Back to Top](#top) ## Use Apollo To Create An Outreach Campaign and Follow Up With Your Prospects[](#toc_8) [![Apollo Example](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/i2.png) Remember, an outreach campaign requires multiple touches and interactions. In an average outreach campaign, we would recommend you follow up with someone between at least 2 and 5 times. The email that we dissected in the section above is an example of an introductory email, but you may need to send follow-up emails, schedule calls, and participate in other tasks before you can close a deal. Apollo **Sequences** allow you to create outreach campaigns at scale. In the [Build an Outbound Sales Process: Target Real Buyers](https://www.notion.so/Build-an-Outbound-Sales-Process-Target-Real-Buyers-4afe69595a264905bd37d922fddd97f0) article, we found real people to reach out to and saved them to a list. We can use that list along with the email messaging we worked on in this article to [create an Apollo **sequence**.](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409231193101-Create-a-Sequence) [![Sequence](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/build_an_outbound_sales_process_craft_killer_sales_email_messaging/i8.png) A typical outreach campaign may take many different forms. Below, we have outlined 3 potential options for you to consider when you structure your campaign/**sequence**. Each of these consists of 2-4 email steps. ### Option A[](#toc_9) This option starts with a well-crafted introductory email. It also includes 3 additional emails with a “Just following up” email message. These types of email campaigns are relatively low touch and may not result in as much success. ### Option B[](#toc_10) This option is a bit more time-consuming as it requires you to follow up with more contact-specific information. You’ll start your outreach with a well-crafted introductory email, but each subsequent follow-up should utilize new talking points, different problems, solutions, value propositions, impacts, and proof points. The table below shows an example of what this might look like: | | General (A.1.1) | Email 2 (A.1.2) | Email 3 (A.1.3) | Email 4 (A.1.4) | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Who: Company | YC Startups in Current Batch | YC Startups in Current Batch | YC Startups in Current Batch | YC Startups in Current Batch | | Who: Titles | Founders | Founders | Founders | Founders | | Problem | Generate as much revenue as possible before Demo day | HArd to find leads at scale for outbounding | HArd to set up outbound systems from scratch | Access to good databases are expensive, sometimes more than $20,000 per year | | Solution | All in one outbound sales platform for generating opportunities with 200 million contacts and an email engine | 200 million contact database with emails | All-in-one system cthat combines data with email automation best practices | Turnkey soltuion with unlimited leads for a small flat rate fee | | Value Prop | Build best-practice outbound engine in minutes | Set more meetings by 5x the number of people you can reach out to | Save time and get better results | Save money | ### Option C[](#toc_11) This technique is a hybrid approach of Options A and B and is the most extensive of all 3 options. Apollo generally recommends using Option C. An example might look like this: 1. Value Prop 1 (new thread) 2. "Just following up" (reply to the thread) 3. Value Prop 2 (new thread) 4. "Just following up" (reply to the thread) 5. Value Prop 3 (new thread) 6. "Just following up" (reply to the thread) In this instance, the initial email follows a similar structure to Option A and B and lays out your initial value proposition. The second email in the campaign is a reply to the initial email and follows the “Just following up” email structure. The third email starts a brand new thread and lays out a new set of problems, solutions, and value propositions. Email 4 is a follow-up to the third email thread. Email 5 starts a brand new thread and provides yet another set of problems, solutions, and value propositions. Finally, email 6 concludes with a “Just following up” response to email 5. If at this point, the contact still has not engaged with you, they likely aren’t going to. Our own testing at Apollo has shown that these follow-up emails can be vital to your success. They may even lead you to book 4 times the amount of meetings you might otherwise book. [Back to Top](#top) ## Practical Exercise[](#toc_12) [![Practical Exercise](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/i3.png) Finish filling out your **Product Market Fit Canvas** with the relevant details for **Problem**, **Solution**, **Value Prop**, **Impact/Benefit**, and **Proof Points**. You can use a combination of information from your ICP research as well as the information in your company’s business plan to fill it out. This will give you a leg up when you begin to perform individualized research for your potential contacts. If you get stuck, revisit the **Do Your Research!** section for a quick refresher. Once you’ve completed that research, create **contact** and **account** custom fields to store it in Apollo. [Back to Top](#top) ## Next Steps[](#toc_13) [![Next Steps](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/academy/i4.png) Once you’ve finished filling out your **Product Market Fit Canvas** and you’ve built and deployed an **Outbound Sales Process** of your own, you should stay focused on your goal metrics and continuously revise and iterate on your process. Head over to the "[**Build an Outbound Sales Process: Analytics**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5120295465357-Build-an-Outbound-Sales-Process-Monitor-Your-Analytics)" article to get started. ## Overview[](#toc_1)

If your team uses a video communications tool for sales or recruitment calls, you can integrate your Apollo instance with your Zoom, Google Meet, or Microsoft Teams account. Use Apollo conversations to access your video call recordings and leverage important meeting insights from within Apollo.

There are several benefits of integrating your communications tool with Apollo, including:

*   More effectively managing and analyzing your team’s video call recordings.
*   Playing your call recordings, accessing high-accuracy transcripts and call clips, leveraging AI-written call summaries, and uncovering account and attendee data from each call.
*   Coaching and scaling successful conversations to increase call conversions.

The following sections detail how to set up conversations and configure the related settings.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 0: Link Your Mailbox to Use Conversations[](#toc_2)

Apollo only pulls in recordings from the meetings you schedule via the mailboxes you've connected to Apollo. If you haven't already, [connect your mailboxes](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409127806093) to gain full conversations functionality.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 1: Add Integrations[](#toc_3)

Apollo supports 3 communication platforms for conversations:

*   Zoom
*   Google Meet
*   Microsoft Teams

To access call recordings and utilize conversations functionality, you need to integrate Apollo with at least 1 of these platforms. If you use multiple communication platforms, you can add multiple integrations.

Got Admin Superpowers?

Only Zoom and Apollo admins can integrate a Zoom Pro, Business, Business Plus, or Enterprise account with Apollo. If you are not an admin for either account, please contact a team member with the necessary permissions to set up the integration. For more information on permission profiles in Apollo, refer to [Create and Assign Permission Profiles](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409154208269). To find your Zoom permissions, check out Zoom's [user types & roles](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201363173-Zoom-user-types-roles#:~:text=You%20can%20find%20which%20role,Meeting%20Connector%2C%20and%20App%20Marketplace) help article.

To set up the Apollo integration with your Zoom Pro, Business, Business Plus, or Enterprise account:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations).
2.  Click **Get Started**. [![Get started button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i2.png)
3.  Click **Connect** for Zoom. [![Zoom Connect Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i21.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i21.png)
4.  Click **Pro, Business, Business Plus, or Enterprise**. [![First button for Zoom account](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i22.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i22.png)
5.  Enter the credentials for your Zoom admin account and click **Sign In**. [![Zoom Credentials Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i3.png)
6.  Review the installation details and permissions you are granting to Apollo. Then, click **Allow** to proceed. [![Allow Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i4.png)

You have now connected Apollo to your Zoom account. If you want to integrate with other communications platform, follow the steps in the **Multiple Video Conferencing Platforms** tab. Otherwise, proceed to set your team's permissions.

Living Life in the Present

Apollo pulls all new calls that your team records after you connect Apollo with your communications platform. Apollo does not display the previous conversations you recorded before you set up the integration.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 2: Set Your Team's Permissions[](#toc_4)

Apollo records meetings for users that have view and record permissions.

To add or remove permissions, click or unclick the checkbox next to the teams you want to include or exclude. Then, click **Continue**.

[![Permissions checkboxes](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i26.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i26.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 3: Add Trackers[](#toc_5)

Trackers are sets of keywords that Apollo detects in your recordings to help you identify and surface the most important parts of each call.

[![Trackers page in setup](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i29.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i29.png)

Click the **Edit** icon next to a prebuilt tracker to make any changes.

[![Edit icon next to a tracker](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i30.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i30.png)

Click any keywords you want to delete. Apollo then removes them from the list.

[![Keywords text box in tracker settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i31.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i31.png)

Type any additional keywords into the **Keywords** text box and click enter to add them to the list.

[![Adding keywords](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i32.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i32.png)

Click the **Track when mentioned by** drop-down to set whether you track keywords from internal, external, or all participants.

[![Track when mentioned by drop-down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i33.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i33.png)

Then, click **Save tracker**.

[![Save tracker button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i34.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i34.png)

To create your own tracker, click **Add trackers**.

[![Add trackers button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i35.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i35.png)

Then, click **Prebuilt** or **New Trackers**.

[![Create trackers modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i36.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i36.png)

If you select **Prebuilt**, click a template on the left. Then, make any edits you need and click **Save tracker**.

[![Prebuilt template](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i37.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i37.png)

If you select **New tracker**, give your tracker a name, type your keywords into the text box, add the type of participants you want to track, and then click **Save tracker**.

[![New tracker modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i38.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i38.png)

To delete a tracker, click the **trash can** icon.

[![Trash can icon](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i39.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i39.png)

Then, click **Delete tracker** to confirm your decision.

[![Delete confirmation modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i40.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i40.png)

Click **Finish** to finalize the setup process.

[![Finish button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i41.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i41.png)

You have completed the setup. If you want to make any changes to the settings, follow the steps in the section below.

Too Much, Too Soon?

All this tracker talk left you feeling overwhelmed? Fear not, you can add and edit your trackers at any time.

To do so, launch Apollo and click **Settings** [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/conversations). Then, click the **Trackers** tab.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Configure Recording Settings[](#toc_6)

Now that you have set up conversations, you are ready to configure your conversation settings. You can only make changes to the conversation settings if you are an admin or have permission to edit the conversation settings.

[![Can edit conversations permission](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i48.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i48.png)

To change the recording settings for conversations:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/conversations).
2.  Choose whether to record all conversations or only conversations that include a participant from outside your organization. [![Record all conversations or only conversations with external participants.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i2.png)
3.  To avoid recording calls that involve certain organizations, enter their domain names and press enter. For example, if you add `acmecorp.com` to your exclusion list, Apollo will not record a conversation that involves a participant with a `acmecorp.com` email address. [![Exclude domains from being recorded.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i3.png)
4.  Enter the minimum number of minutes you want your calls to last for Apollo to process the meeting in conversations. Apollo does not save or pull a meeting into conversations if it lasts less than the call duration you set here. [![Set a minimum recording duration.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i4.png)
5.  If you connected a Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, or Zoom (not Zoom Pro+) account, Apollo's [recording bot](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/18637632165645) needs to join your meeting to enable recording.
    
    If you want to change the recording bot's default name, enter a new name. Be mindful that all meeting participants will see the bot name. [![Change recording bot name.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i5.png)
    
6.  Click **Save** to update the settings.

Let's Get Creative!

Want the flexibility to record some internal calls, but not all? Consider creating a waiting room in your communications platform. The host can decide whether to admit the bot and record a call or not!

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add Recording Consent Message[](#toc_7)

In many countries and US states, you need permission from all participants before you can record calls. To inform participants that a call will be recorded, Apollo enables you to send email notifications prior to the call, and make an audio announcement during the call.

To add recording consent messages:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/conversations).
2.  Toggle the **Recording announcement** slider on to make an audio consent announcement at the beginning of a call. Then, choose when the audio announcement will happen and message language. [![Change recording bot name.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i10.png)
3.  Toggle the **Email notifications** slider on to send a email to participants prior to the call. Choose the time when the email will be sent to internal and external participants. Then, you can either use the default notification message by not editing it, or enter your own custom message. [![Change recording bot name.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i12.png)
4.  Click **Save** to add your recording consent messages.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Record Conversations[](#toc_8)

Depending on the video conferencing platform, Apollo records meetings in 1 of 2 ways:

*   **Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, and Zoom (not Zoom Pro+)**: Apollo's recording bot joins the meeting. Depending on your video conference platform settings, the bot can either auto-join your calls or you can choose to allow the bot into the meeting each time. Either way, you need to make sure that the recording bot is in your meeting.
*   **Zoom Pro+**: The platform records the meeting, and then Apollo imports that cloud recording. No recording bot joins your meetings.

To ensure a future call is set to record, launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations). Then, access the **My upcoming meetings** tab and confirm the recording status of your upcoming calls.

If you are using a platform other than Zoom Pro+, Apollo needs at least 30 minutes to analyze your inbox and find the meetings that need the recording bot. If you schedule a last-minute meeting that is less than 30 minutes in the future, Apollo might not have enough time to analyze your inbox, so the recording bot will not know to join the meeting.

To manually send the recording bot to your meeting, click **Record now** and add the meeting URL. The Apollo recording bot then joins your call when the meeting starts.

[![Record an ad-hoc conversation.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_conversations/i13.png)

Check the Settings

You can use the recording bot to manually record your calls even if you haven't linked your mailbox or connected your conferencing platform.

If you don't have access to the **Record now** button, ask your Apollo admin to update your conversations settings. Admins can update the [recorded user settings](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/conversations/users) to determine which team members can record calls with the recording bot.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Access Your Recorded Conversations[](#toc_9)

To access your team's recorded conversations, including key insights and transcripts, launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations).

For more information about how to take advantage of conversations, please refer to the [Access Your Conversations in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9632855570701). If your run into issues with your recordings, check out the guidance in [Troubleshoot Conversations](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/18637632165645).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Stop Recording Conversations in Apollo[](#toc_10)

If you are an admin, you can disconnect your communications platform from Apollo and stop recording video calls at any time.

You can also reconnect at any time. However, Apollo does not pull in any historical data. When you reconnect, Apollo does not display any calls that your team recorded when the integration was disconnected.

To disconnect an integration and stop recording conversations in Apollo:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** [**Integrations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/integrations).
2.  In the **Connected integration**, click **Disconnect** for the integration you want to remove. [![Disconnect Button on Integrations Page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i13.png)
3.  Click **Disconnect CI** to confirm your choice.

You have now disconnected your account from Apollo. If you want to set up the integration again, follow the steps in the [Add Integrations](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8274034041997-#toc_2) section.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

If you want to access your Zoom call recordings and leverage important meeting insights from within Apollo, you first need to set up Conversations.

There are 2 ways that you can execute the setup to ensure full functionality between Zoom and Apollo Conversations:

*   Enable the required Zoom admin settings from within Zoom
*   Connect your Zoom account to Apollo and enable the settings directly from within your Apollo instance

Follow the steps below if you want to execute the setup and connect or disconnect Apollo from your Zoom account. Alternatively, refer to the steps in the "[Set Up Conversations in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8274034041997)" article if you want to enable the settings and connect or disconnect the platforms directly within Apollo.

Got Admin Superpowers?

Please note, if you have a Zoom Pro or above plan, only members with Zoom and Apollo admin access can integrate Zoom with Apollo. If you are not an admin for either account, please share this article with a team member that has the necessary permissions to follow the steps below.

## Enable Zoom Admin Settings Within Zoom[](#toc_2)

Before you begin with the setup, [click here](https://marketplace.zoom.us/apps/fukGmgh7RxSjt9VIcJlyIw) to preauthorize the installation of the Apollo Zoom app from within the Zoom Marketplace. This gives Apollo the necessary access to record through Zoom so that you can view and analyze your call recordings within **Apollo Conversations**.

When ready, launch Zoom and click the **Account Management** drop-down under the **Admin** section.

[![Admin Account Management](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i1.png)

Click **Account Settings**.

[![Account Settings Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i2.png)

Then, click **Recording**.

[![Recording Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i3.png)

Scroll to **Cloud Recording** and enable the toggle on the right to ensure that every member of your organization can record their calls.

[![Cloud Recording Toggle](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i4.png)

Click the **lock** icon to save this setting for all users within your company.

[![Lock Icon](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i5.png)

Let's Get Specific!

Please note, if you want to enable group-specific settings, follow the instructions in the "[Managing User Groups and Settings](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/204519819-Group-Management-)" article in the Zoom Knowledge Base.

As you will be able to access all your recordings from Apollo, you may also want to auto-delete cloud recordings in Zoom.

To do so, enable the **Auto delete cloud recordings after days** toggle and then click the **lock** icon to save this setting for all users.

[![Auto Delete Cloud Recordings Setting](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i6.png)

Walking on a Cloud of Zoom Knowledge!

For more information about how Cloud Recording works in Zoom, please refer to the "[Starting a Cloud Recording](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/203741855-Cloud-Recording)" article in the Zoom Knowledge Base.

Then, to ensure you and your team stays compliant when recording calls, scroll to **Recording notifications** and click the radio button for **Show a disclaimer to participants when a recording starts**. You can choose to enable this setting for all participants or just for guests.

[![Show a disclaimer to participants when a recording starts radio button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i7.png)

Read All About It!

For more information on Zoom Recording Notifications, please refer to the "[Modifying Recording Notifications](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/360000486746-Recording-Notifications)" article in the Zoom Knowledge Base. For additional information on how to customize your recording disclaimer with pop-up language and a hyperlink to your privacy policy, please refer to the "[Customizing the Recording Consent Disclaimer](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/360026909191-Customizing-the-recording-consent-disclaimer)" article in the Zoom Knowledge Base.

Click the **Automatic recording** toggle if you want your team to automatically record meetings at the start of each call.

[![Automatic Recording Toggle](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i8.png)

Don't Lock it Down!

Please note, each user in your team can switch the setting on and off at any time. However, be careful with your admin superpowers! If you click the **lock** icon for this setting, you will disable all recording functionality.

You have now enabled the necessary permissions from the **Recordings** tab. Next, click the **Meetings** tab.

[![Meetings Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i9.png)

Click **In Meeting Advanced** and then click the **Allow live streaming of meetings** toggle.

[![Allow live streaming of meetings toggle](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i10.png)

Finally, click the checkbox for **Custom Live Streaming Service** and then click the **lock** icon to save the setting for all users.

[![Custom Live Streaming Service Checkbox](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_your_zoom_account/i11.png)

No Extra Info Needed

Please note, when you enable the **Custom Live Streaming Service** checkbox, you do not need to enter any additional information in the text box that appears.

You have now enabled the necessary settings in Zoom.

One More Small Step for the Integration, One Giant Leap for Your Conversations!

Just one more step to go to access important insights from your conversations! Launch Apollo and refer to the information in [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9632855570701) to start leveraging your Zoom conversations within Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Disconnect Apollo in Zoom[](#toc_3)

You can disconnect Apollo from your Zoom account at any time.

Spoilt For Choice

You don't have to enter Zoom to disconnect Apollo. You can also disconnect the integration from within Apollo directly. For more information on the steps to take, refer to the "Disconnect Zoom in Apollo" section of [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8274034041997-#toc_8).

Launch Zoom, click **Solutions**, and then click **Marketplace**.

[![Zoom Marketplace Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/zoom_integration_overview/i15.png)

Click **Manage** at the top right of your screen.

## Overview[](#toc_0)

Conversations provide easy access to your team's video call recordings within Apollo. Beyond providing the ability to watch recordings of your meetings, conversations enables you to access AI-generated call summaries, comment on recordings, and submit scorecards to assess and train sales teams.

Zoom Your Way Through These Steps First

Before you can access conversations in Apollo, you need to follow the instructions in [Set Up Apollo Conversations](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8274034041997).

When you finish the set-up process, Apollo starts to pull all new calls that your team records after you connect Apollo with your communications platform. Apollo does not display the previous conversations you recorded before you integrated the 2 platforms. When you finish hosting a meeting, Apollo needs a moment to process and upload a recording. You'll see new recordings in Apollo as soon as the magic finishes!

The following sections detail how to search and view call recordings, access a variety of call insights, share recordings, and read call transcripts.

[Back to Top](#top)

## View and Sort Your Conversations[](#toc_1)

Launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations/recordings). From this page, you can view all the calls you and your team have recorded since connecting your account with Apollo.

Click the **Sort by** drop-down to sort your team's call recordings in order of the recorded date or duration. Changing the sort order affects only your view of conversations, not your teammates. Then, click **Apply** to save your changes.

[![Sort By Drop-Down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i1.png)

Browse through all the recordings, or [apply filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9632855570701-Access-Your-Conversations-in-Apollo#toc_2) to find specific calls.

[![Conversation Filters](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i17.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i17.png)

To delete a specific recording, click **...** > **Delete Conversation**.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Use Filters to Find Conversations[](#toc_2)

You can use the following filters to find specific conversations. Click a tab to learn more about each filter.

To search call recordings, enter any keywords from the meeting title into the **Search** bar. Then, press enter to load all related calls. [![Title Search Bar in Filters](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i2.png)

  
[Back to Top](#top)

## Tag Call Recordings[](#toc_3)

Tags enable you and your team to categorize call recordings based on the custom tags that your admins create. Then, anyone across your organization can [use filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9632855570701-Access-Your-Conversations-in-Apollo#toc_2) to easily find tagged recordings. To apply a tag to a recording:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations). Then, click a recording tile to access it.
2.  On the recording's page, click **Add tags**. [![Add tags to a call recording.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i11.png)
3.  If the tag you want to use already exists, select it. [![Choose a pre-existing tag.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i12.png)
4.  To create a new tag, enter a name, then click **Create new tag**. [![Create a new tag.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i13.png)

Apollo adds your tags to the recording. You can [use conversation filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9632855570701-Access-Your-Conversations-in-Apollo#toc_2) to find recordings based on tags.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Access Conversation Insights[](#toc_4)

Now that you have applied filters to find your conversations in Apollo, click a recording to access your call insights. If a video call meeting lasts more than 8 hours, Apollo still uploads the recording, but meeting insights will not be available. [![Access a recording.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i18.png) ](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i18.png)The following conversation tabs provide different details and actions related to the recording.

  
[Back to Top](#top)

## View Participant Activity[](#toc_5)

You Have to Speak to Be Heard

Apollo only generates insights for participants that speak for at least 10% of the overall call recording.

Below the recording, Apollo summarizes the participants' activity throughout a call. Here you can see the specific moments when a participant spoke during the call.

To move to a section of the recording where a specific participant speaks, click a section of that participant's activity bar.

[![Participant Activity Bar](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i14.png)

By default, Apollo shows the activity of all participants. To show or hide activity by specific participants, click the **Listening to** drop-down. Then, click a participant's checkbox to enable or disable their activity bar.

[![Listening To Drop-Down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i15.png)

If Apollo can't identify a participant, their display name will be **Unknown Participants**.

[![Others Drop-Down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i16.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i16.png)

Apollo also displays the specific moments when participants shared their screens throughout the call via the **Screen Share** activity bar.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Share Call Recordings[](#toc_6)

To share an entire call recording with others, click **Share call**, then choose to **Share internally** or **Share with anyone**.

[![Share an entire call recording.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i35.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i35.png)

To share only a portion of a recording, click the **scissors** icon. Then, click and drag the yellow bars to select a portion of the call.

[![Share a portion of a call.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i38.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i38.png)

To share internally, select the users you want to receive the recording, set an expiration date for the link, and click **Share**. Apollo emails a link to the selected users.

[![Share conversation internally.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i39.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i39.png)

To share the recording outside your company, set the link settings and expiration date, choose whether you want to validate anyone that accesses the link, then click **Copy link**. You can share the link manually.

[![Share conversation with anyone.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i36.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i36.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Set Your Privacy Settings[](#toc_7)

To apply privacy settings to the call recordings for the meetings you host in Apollo:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Settings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/account). Then, scroll to the **Conversations** section and toggle **Enable Private Conversations** on. [![Enable private conversations.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i20.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i20.png)
2.  Choose whether you apply the privacy settings to future conversations only or past conversations too. Click **Done** to save your changes. [![Past and future recordings.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i19.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i19.png)

You have now set your privacy settings for the individual recordings you host in Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add Conversations to Your Deals[](#toc_8)

[Deals](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4415062467725) helps you track the activities associated with winning and renewing accounts. Apollo automatically associates conversations to your deals if the the company for both the conversation and deal matches. This makes conversations easily accessible to you and your team, and ensures that your deals include this critical activity.

There are also 2 ways to manually associate a conversation with a deal. To add a conversation from a deals page:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Deals**](https://app.apollo.io/#/opportunities). Then, click a deal name to access its page. [![Access the deal.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i10.png)
2.  In the **Activity** section, click the **Conversations** tab. Then, click **Add conversation**. [![Add a conversation](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i12.png)
3.  Select the conversation you want to associate to the deal, then click **Save**. [![Choose the conversation to add.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i13.png)

To add a conversation from a conversation page:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations). Then, click a conversation that has been recorded to access its page. [![Access the conversation.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i1.png)
2.  Click **Associate deals**. [![Add a deal.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i1.png)
3.  Select the deal you want to associate with the conversation, then click **Apply**. [![Choose a deal.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i3.png)

Regardless of the path you take, information for the conversation is added to the **Activity** section of the deal's page. You can click the conversation to access the full details for it, including the recording, insights, transcripts, and analytics.

[![Find your added conversation on the deals page.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i14.png)

The conversation is also added to the activities timeline for the deal.

[![The conversation is also added to deal activites.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/add_conversations_to_deals/i15.png)

Apollo displays the call transcript for a recording to the right of the video player. Enter keywords into the search bar and press enter to view all the moments when participants spoke those particular words.

[![Search a recording transcript.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i21.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i21.png)

To watch a specific portion of the recording, click a spot in the transcript. Apollo highlights the portion of the transcript prior to the spot, and the video player moves to the same corresponding point.

[![Move to a spot in the transcript.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i22.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i22.png)

If you are listening to a call while browsing through the transcript, click **Sync back to time** to return to the point in the transcript that's currently playing.

[![Sync back to time.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i23.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i23.png)

## Access Conversations Analytics[](#toc_10)

To view analytics related to your team's conversations, launch Apollo and click [**Conversations**](https://app.apollo.io/#/conversations). Then, click the **Stats** tab to view your team's activity and interaction analytics.

[![Stats tab in conversations.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i24.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_conversations_recordings_insights/i24.png)

Click the **Timeframe** drop-down and select the period or dates in which you want to view your team's data.

[![Timeframe drop-down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_your_zoom_conversations_in_apollo/i70.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_your_zoom_conversations_in_apollo/i70.png)

Click the **Users** drop-down to select the specific teams for whom you want to view the data. To deselect individuals within a team, click the **Arrow** icon and then click the checkbox next to the user's name.

[![Users drop-down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_your_zoom_conversations_in_apollo/i71.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_your_zoom_conversations_in_apollo/i71.png)

From the **Activity** tab, you can view the average:

*   Total and weekly call volume.
*   Call duration.
*   Total and weekly time spent on calls.

From the **Interaction** tab, you can view the average:

*   **Talk ratio**: The average time a user spoke across all calls during the selected period.
*   **Longest customer story**: The duration of the longest customer monologue.
*   **Patience**: The average amount of time between a customer talking and a team member taking over.
*   **Question Rate**: The number of questions a team member asks per hour of conversation.

Click on an activity or interaction to view a bar chart breakdown of the results per user.

[![Bar chart breakdown](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_your_zoom_conversations_in_apollo/i72.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_your_zoom_conversations_in_apollo/i72.png)

## Overview[](#toc_0)

Conversations enables you to easily record your team's meetings to be analyzed in Apollo. You can play the recorded meeting, filter meetings, access and search transcripts, and share and comment on recordings.

To start using conversations in Apollo, refer to [Set Up Conversations in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8274034041997). Then, review [Access Your Conversations in Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9632855570701) to learn how to find and use your team's recorded meetings.

Paid Plans Only

This feature is only available with paid Apollo plans. If you are on a free plan but are interested in leveraging Apollo Conversations in your day-to-day workflow, please refer to Apollo's [pricing page](https://www.apollo.io/pricing) or contact the [Apollo sales team](mailto:%20sales@apollo.io) to discuss your options.

If your meetings are not recording in Apollo, please review the following sections in this article to learn more about the recording process and find answers to FAQs.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Understand How Recordings Work in Apollo[](#toc_1)

Apollo's recording settings are based on several factors, including:

*   Who is being recorded in the meeting.
*   Your company-wide recording settings.
*   What might happen during the meeting, such as the recording bot being removed.

Depending on the video conferencing platform, Apollo records meetings in 1 of 2 ways:

*   **Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, and Zoom (not Zoom Pro+)**: Apollo's recording bot joins the meeting. Depending on your video conference platform settings, the bot can either auto-join your calls or you can choose to allow the bot into the meeting each time. Either way, you need to make sure that the recording bot is in your meeting.
*   **Zoom Pro+**: The platform records the meeting, and then Apollo imports that cloud recording. No recording bot joins your meetings.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_0) Plays is an end-to-end workflow automation tool that helps you reduce manual tasks, increase efficiency, and drive more pipeline. Create plays in Apollo to automate time-consuming manual actions and connect with your ideal customers at scale. Use plays to automate fundamental steps in your sales workflow, including adding or removing contacts from a [sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409237165837) or list, scheduling tasks for your reps, and updating contact job changes. You can also configure alerts to remind you when you need to take manual actions. The following sections detail the key benefits of plays by role and provide example use cases from the play templates library. [Back to Top](#top) ## Understand Benefits of Plays for Your Role[](#toc_1) Different roles experience distinct advantages when leveraging plays in Apollo, including: | Role | Benefits | | --- | --- | | Sales Development Reps (SDRs) and Account Executives (AEs) | * Automate your prospecting activities to book more meetings and generate more revenue.
* Reduce arduous manual tasks and spend more time in meetings with your ideal prospects. | | Sales Leaders | * Improve your team's efficiency and establish best practices that help you scale the end-to-end workflows that drive the highest impact.
* Automate successful go-to-market strategies that enable your reps to dedicate more time to the activities that generate the most revenue.
* Increase and improve pipeline by creating automated, repeatable, and scalable processes that work. | | Founders and CEOs | * Improve team efficiency and automate tedious tasks that help your team focus on the most impactful activities that lead to consistent growth.
* Automate your entire lead generation and talent recruitment process in one platform to scale your business effectively as your team closes more and more deals.
* Empower your team to generate more pipeline and automate the entire go-to-market workflow; from lead generation to prospecting to booked meetings and beyond. | | Demand Gen | * Automate lead generation and increase overall [TAM](https://www.apollo.io/blog/tam-sam-som-framework/) coverage with Apollo's B2B data and automation.
* Improve efficiency across teams and automate manual tasks and CRM syncs to ensure no marketing leads fall through the cracks when you pass them over to sales. | [Back to Top](#top) ## Create Plays[](#toc_2) When you [create a play](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4413804036109), use templates from Apollo to quickly generate new pipeline, secure more meetings, retain existing business, and automate several other parts of the sales workflow. Alternatively, build plays from scratch that run based on a variety of triggers and automated actions. [![Build plays using templates.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/plays_overview/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/plays_overview/i2.png) [Back to Top](#top) ## Run Account-based Sales Motions[](#toc_3) Use plays to more effectively target high-priority accounts. A successful account-based sales motion relies on your team consistently finding the right contacts at your high-priority accounts, and that often means manual prospecting and messaging. To avoid those tedious manual tasks, follow Apollo's [example account-based play](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/25983156332557) to automatically surface the right contacts and add them to sequences. [![Queue contacts from your priority accounts.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/plays_overview/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/plays_overview/i6.png) [Back to Top](#top) ## Receive Slack Notifications for Plays[](#toc_4) [Set up the Apollo-Slack integration](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/22464817775117) to receive plays-related alerts in Slack. Use Slack notifications to inform yourself or other members of your team that a play ran in Apollo, or that they need to take a manual action in Apollo such as calling a contact or adding an account to a list. Also, add a priority status to notifications so that team members can easily determine how quickly they need to take action in Apollo. [![Receive plays notifications in Slack.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/plays_overview/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/plays_overview/i4.png) [Back to Top](#top) ## Prepare for Plays Success[](#toc_5) If you've just started exploring plays, [take steps to better leverage plays](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/14062758984717) when automating your sales workflow.
