## Import a New Vidyard Video into an Apollo Email[](#toc_2)

First, follow the steps in the "[Link Vidyard to Apollo](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423006498189-Link-Vidyard-to-Apollo) " article. Then, open the email to which you want to add a video and click the **Vidyard** icon.

[![Vidyard Icon](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i1.png)

Lights, Camera, Action!

If you're all about that video-in-message flex, you're in the right place. You can access Vidyard from within any email you send from Apollo. If you want to add a video to an isolated email for one specific **contact**, you can do so from the **contact's** profile. For more information about how to access a **contact's** profile, please refer to the "[Contact and Account Profile Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412576856973-Contact-and-Account-Profile-Overview)" article.

If you want to add a video to an email in a **Sequence**, navigate to that **Sequence** and open the respective email. For more information about how to access **Sequences**, please refer to the "[Sequences Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409237165837-Sequences-Overview)" article. Now, best change out of your PJs—you've got engaging videos to make.

Click **New Video** and choose one of the 3 options: **Camera Recording**, **Screen Recording**, or **Upload Video**.

[![New Video Options](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i2.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

### Create a Camera Recording[](#toc_3)

To record a new video in which you can talk directly to your **contacts**, click **Camera Recording**.

[![Camera Recording](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i3.png)

Permissions Settings

Only you have got the power to get a video rolling. The first time you use this feature, you need to configure your permission settings before you can start to record. Click **Allow** to give Apollo the proper permissons.

[![Allow](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i6.png)

Click the camera selection drop-down to choose your video input.

[![Camera Drop-Down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i7.png)

Then, click the microphone selection drop-down to choose your audio input.

[![Mic Drop-Down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i8.png)

When you are ready to record, click **Start Recording**.

[![Start Recording](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i9.png)

Use the control buttons on the bottom left of the "Insert Video" modal to **Pause** and **Resume** or **Stop** recording.

[![Pause/Resume + Stop Buttons](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i10.png)

Use the button on the bottom-right to record and replace your existing video.

[![Record Again Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i11.png)

After you click the **Stop** button, wait a moment for Vidyard to compress and save your video. Watch the video to confirm you are happy with how it came out. Then, name the file and click **Share** to add the video to your email.

[![Share Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i12.png)

If you want to remove the video, click the **Delete** icon on the top right of the modal.

Then, click **Delete**.

[![Confirm Delete](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i14.png)

To edit the video, click **Edit Video in Vidyard**.

### Create a Screencast[](#toc_4)

To record a video of your screen, click **Screen Recording**.

[![Screen Recording](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i4.png)

First, you need to enable the Vidyard Chrome extension. Apollo automatically prompts you to install the Vidyard Chrome extension if you don't already have it.

Skip It If You Got It

Please note, if you already have the Vidyard Chrome extension, you won't be prompted to install. Skip ahead a few steps, you dynamo.

Click **Install Vidyard Chrome Extension**.

[![Vidyard Chrome Extension](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i15.png)

Click **Add to Chrome**.

[![Add to Chrome](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i16.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i16.png)

Then, click **Add Extension**.

[![Add Extension](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i17.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i17.png)

Head back to the tab where your Apollo instance is open and continue with the steps below.

Lights, Camera, Permissions Settings?

Before you clean up your tabs and put on your Sunday best, you need to enable your camera, screen, and microphone permissions so that you can record a video. Click **Allow** to give Apollo the proper permissions.

[![Allow](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i6.png)

If you encounter any issues with screen share recording, take a peek at your **System Preferences** and make sure Chrome has permission to record your screen.

Click the camera selection drop-down to select your video input.

[![Camera Drop-Down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i18.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i18.png)

Then, click the microphone drop-down to select your audio input.

When you are ready to record, click **Start Recording**.

[![Start Recording](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i20.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i20.png)

Select the screen, window, or tab that you want to display in the video and then click **Share**.

[![Select Screen Modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i21.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i21.png)

Use the control buttons on the bottom-right of the modal to **Pause** or **Resume**, **Stop**, or **Re-record** the video.

[![Pause/Resume, Stop + Re-do Buttons](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i22.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i22.png)

Click **Stop Sharing** or the **Stop** button to end the recording.

[![End Recording](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i23.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i23.png)

Wait a moment for Vidyard to compress and save your video. Watch the video to confirm you are happy with how it came out. Then, name the file and click **Share** to add the video to your email.

[![Share Button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i24.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i24.png)

If you want to remove the video, click the **Delete** icon on the top right.

Then, click **Delete**.

To edit the video, click **Edit Video in Vidyard**.

## Import an Existing Video into an Apollo Email[](#toc_6)

Open the email in which you want to add a video and click the **Vidyard** icon.

[![Vidyard Icon](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i1.png)

Click the checkbox for the video that you want to import. Then, click **Share**.

[![Click Checkbox and Share](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i29.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i29.png)

Fewer Links, More Delivery, Please.

Include too many links in your emails and you can land yourself in the not-so-spectacular SPAM club. Cue the sad trombone. To increase your chances of delivery, remove the automatically generated link below the video you imported before you send the email. The recipient can still access the video by clicking the image. Presto, you're one link lighter and less likely to upset the SPAM gods. For more tips and tricks to avoid the dreaded SPAM designation, feast your eyes on this "[Avoid SPAM Filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409225311885-Avoid-SPAM-Filters)" article.

To edit or delete a video from your Vidyard library, click the additional options **(...)** button next to the video and select the appropriate option.

[![Edit or Delete Video](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i30.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/import_vidyard_videos_into_apollo_emails/i30.png)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Analyze the performance of the **Vidyard** videos in your emails to gain valuable insights about your target audience. The more you evaluate what works and what doesn't, the more you can test and improve your approach to increase engagement.

Refer to the sections below for more information about the video analytics you can access in Vidyard.

## Access Vidyard Analytics[](#toc_2)

For more specific data about the Vidyard videos you send within your Apollo emails, you can check the statistics available within the Vidyard platform. To see whether your contacts have viewed your video and how many times they have done so, navigate to your Vidyard library and scroll through the videos. On the right-hand side of each video, Vidyard displays the number of views that the video has recieved.

[![Check Vidyard Views](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i12.png)

Vidyard creates a unique URL for each video that you embed in an email. This means that if you have a **Pro**, **Team**, **Business**, or **Enterprise** Vidyard account, you can access further **contact-level insights** per view.

[![Contact Level Insights](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i13.png)

To access these insights, click the additional options **(...)** button next to the video that you want to review in your Vidyard library. Then, click **Video Insights**.

[![Video Insights](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i14.png)

From the **Insights** page, you can view key data points like which email address watched the video, at what time, and how much of the content they viewed.

[![Video Insights Broken Down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/access_vidyard_analytics/i15.png)

For more information about the insights available in Vidyard, refer to the following articles from the Vidyard Knowledge Base:

*   [How to see who has viewed your video](https://knowledge.vidyard.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404674907931-How-to-see-who-has-viewed-your-video)
*   [Review your video analytics in the insights dashboard](https://knowledge.vidyard.com/hc/en-us/articles/360022095093-Review-your-video-analytics-in-the-Insights-Dashboard)
*   [Types of video analytics in the insights dashboard](https://knowledge.vidyard.com/hc/en-us/articles/360022082294-Types-of-video-analytics-in-the-Insights-Dashboard)
*   [How to measure engagement with your videos actions CTAs](https://knowledge.vidyard.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404312314011-How-to-measure-engagement-with-your-videos-Actions-CTAs-)

Analyze to Your Heart's Content!

Please note, we'd never leave our favorite people stranded! You don't have to depend solely on **Vidyard** analytics. When you include videos in your Apollo emails you can also track your **Open**, **Click**, and **Response** rates in Apollo. This can help you to analyze the performance of the content you share. Refer to the "[Access Apollo Email Analytics](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4425592135821-Access-Apollo-Email-Analytics-)" article for more information. You can also try running "[A/B tests](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4410749683597-Add-an-A-B-Test-to-an-Email-Step-in-a-Sequence)" to experiment with different techniques that help you improve your video emails.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Zapier is designed to connect with key web applications in your workflow so that you can sync data between them. Apollo integrates with all Zapier-supported apps, including Slack, Google Sheets, Typeform, Pipedrive, Zoho CRM, among others.

Zapier Integrations

For a comprehensive list of all the integrations that you can create through Zapier, refer to the ["Apollo Integrations"](https://zapier.com/apps/apollo/integrations) article in the Zapier Knowledge Base.

For more information about the Apollo-based events that you can use to connect with Zapier apps, refer to the sections below.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Key Apollo Integration Features[](#toc_2)

Zapier uses **Zaps** to connect apps and services together. Every **Zap** includes a trigger step and at least one action step. A trigger is an event that kick-starts a **Zap**. An action is an event that a **Zap** carries out. When you turn a **Zap** on and a trigger event takes place, Zapier automatically completes the related action steps for you.

The **Apollo-Zapier Integration** includes the following Apollo-based events that you can use to connect Apollo with any Zapier-supported app(s):

### Supported Trigger Steps[](#toc_3)

The supported trigger steps for Apollo include:

| Trigger | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Account Updated | This triggers when you update an existing account in Apollo. |
| New Account | This triggers when you create a new account in Apollo. |
| Contact Updated | This triggers when you update an existing contact in Apollo. |
| New Contact | This triggers when you create a new contact in Apollo. |

[Back to Top](#top)

### Supported Action Steps[](#toc_4)

The supported action steps for Apollo include:

| Action | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Create Account | This action creates a new account record in Apollo. |
| Create Contact | This action creates a new contact record in Apollo. |
| Create Opportunity | This action creates a new opportunity record in Apollo. |
| Create Task | This action creates a new task in Apollo. |
| Update Account | This action updates an existing account record in Apollo. |
| Update Contact | This action updates an existing contact record in Apollo. |
| Update Opportunity | This action updates an existing opportunity record in Apollo. |
| Find Contact | This action allows you to find a contact in your Apollo instance using email. If you have multiple contacts with the same email address, the search returns the contact that you created first. |
| Find or Create Contact | This action allows you to find a contact in your Apollo instance using email and will create the contact if it don't exist. If you have multiple contacts with the same email address, the search returns the contact that you created first. |

[Back to Top](#)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Zapier uses **Zaps** to connect apps and services together. Every **Zap** includes a trigger step and at least one action step. A trigger is an event that kick-starts a **Zap**. An action is an event that a **Zap** carries out. When you turn a **Zap** on and a trigger event takes place, Zapier automatically completes the related action steps for you.

Apollo-Based Events

## Overview[](#toc_1)

It Depends on Your Plan

Please note, you can only connect Greenhouse with Apollo if you are on a basic, professional, or custom plan. Users on a free plan do not have access to the Greenhouse integration. Users on a basic plan only have access to pull settings. Want to upgrade to activate the full functionality of the integration? Refer to our [pricing page](https://www.apollo.io/pricing/) for further information or contact a member of our [Apollo Sales Team](mailto: sales@apollo.io) to discuss your options.

If you are a recruiter that uses Greenhouse to track and manage candidate workflows from end-to-end, you can integrate your Apollo instance with your Greenhouse account.

The benefits of this integration include:

*   **Unified Candidate Data**: Find and save your ideal candidates, then push Apollo contacts directly into Greenhouse
*   **Efficient Engagement**: Deploy your Greenhouse candidates into your Apollo sequences
*   **Streamlined Workflow**: Remove unnecessary steps when you work between Apollo and Greenhouse
*   **Automatic Synchronization**: Contacts you push to and pull from Apollo will automatically sync in Greenhouse

Refer to the sections below for the steps to connect Apollo to Greenhouse, configure your integration settings, view your contact sync history, and disconnect Greenhouse from Apollo.

Admin Only

With great power comes great responsibility. You can only make changes to Greenhouse settings in Apollo if you are an admin or a user with permission to edit the CRM/ATS integration settings. Please refer to the [Create Permission Profiles](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409154208269-Create-Permission-Profiles) article for more information about permission settings.

To connect and disconnect Apollo with your Greenhouse account, you must be an admin in both Apollo and Greenhouse. If you are not an admin, please ask an admin to follow the steps in this article.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Connect Apollo to Greenhouse[](#toc_2)

Launch Apollo, and click the **Integrations** icon.

[![Integrations in Apollo settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i1.png)

Is This the Only Way?

We're all about making your workflow as dreamy as your dream candidates! If you are already on a contact's profile page, click the **CRM/ATS** drop-down and then click **Connect Greenhouse**. [![ATS drop-down button on a contact's profile page in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i2.png) ](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i2.png)Apollo directs you straight to the integrations page. Then, follow the instructions below to continue with the connection process.

Scroll to Greenhouse and click **Connect**.

[![Greenhouse connect button on integrations page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i3.png)

One at a Time, Folks!

Please note, you can only connect 1 ATS or CRM to Apollo at a time. For example, if you connect your Salesforce account to Apollo, you cannot connect your Greenhouse account. It's not because we're stingy. It's because we care about your data. Our integrations are bi-directional. This means that if you connect more than one CRM or ATS at once, you could get caught in an infinite data loop between the 3 platforms. And that's not fun for anyone.

Click **Connect integration**.

[![Connect integration on the Greenhouse settings page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i4.png)

Read the details and then click **Continue** in the Greenhouse authentication modal.

[![Continue button in Greenhouse authentication modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i5.png)

Permission to Please

Please note, we treat your permission with the utmost care and respect! When you grant Apollo access, you can easily sync data between Apollo and Greenhouse, automatically push and pull records, and streamline how you find and connect with candidates. Apollo only requests the necessary permissions that Greenhouse requires so that you can gain full functionality of the integration.

Enter your Greenhouse API key and then click **Submit**.

[![Submit button in Greenhouse authentication modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i6.png)

Lost your key?

Can't find that safe place you hid your key because it's Just. Too. Safe? We're not judging—we've all been there! Hop on into the [Generate an API Key for Greenhouse Recruiting](https://support.greenhouse.io/hc/en-us/articles/202842799-Generate-an-API-key-for-Greenhouse-Recruiting) article for the steps to create a new API key.

Click **Continue**.

[![Continue button in Greenhouse authentication modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i7.png)

Then, click **Finish setup**.

[![Finish setup button in Greenhouse authentication modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i8.png)

You have now connected your Greenhouse account with your Apollo instance.

## Configure Greenhouse Settings[](#toc_3)

Now that you have connected Greenhouse with Apollo, there are 3 important settings to keep in mind:

*   Add Your Greenhouse Subdomain
*   Push Contacts to Greenhouse
*   Pull Contacts from Greenhouse

### Add Your Greenhouse Subdomain[](#toc_4)

To ensure the candidate info in Greenhouse syncs correctly with your contacts in Apollo, you must add your Greenhouse subdomain.

Log into your Greenhouse account and copy the app URL from the search bar.

[![Greenhouse URL](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i10.png)

Launch Apollo, click the **Integrations** icon, and then click **View** in the Greenhouse section.

[![Integrations page in Apollo settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i9.png)

Scroll to the **Greenhouse subdomain** section and paste the Greenhouse URL you copied into the **Greenhouse subdomain** bar. Then, click **Save**.

[![Greenhouse subdomain field in Greenhouse integration settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i11.png)

Apollo can now successfully link your synced contacts in Apollo with your synced candidates in Greenhouse.

[Back to top](#top)

### Push Contacts to Greenhouse[](#toc_5)

Launch Apollo, click the **Integrations** icon, and then click **View** in the Greenhouse section.

[![Integrations page in Apollo settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i9.png)

Click the **Push contacts** toggle to automatically push into Greenhouse any new contacts you save in Apollo.

[![Push contacts toggle in Apollo integrations settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i12.png)

Good Things Come to Those Who Wait

Please note, Apollo automatically conducts an initial pull when you first connect Greenhouse. You can only enable the automatic push toggle once the initial pull finishes.

When you enable automatic pushing, any time you add or delete a contact's information in Apollo, the change automatically updates in Greenhouse. For more details on how to edit data in Apollo, refer to the [Edit Profile Data](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5995459280525-Contact-Profile-Overview#toc_13) section of the Contact Profile Overview article.

Refreshment Time!

Already have Greenhouse open in another tab? Please note, if you add or delete the contact details in Apollo of a candidate you are already viewing in Greenhouse, remember to refresh the page in Greenhouse to view the latest updates.

If you do not want to activate automatic pushing, do not enable the **Push contacts** toggle. In this case, you need to manually push the records you save one at a time or in bulk.

To manually push all your Apollo contacts to your Greenhouse account, click **Push all Apollo contacts to Greenhouse**.

[![Push all Apollo contacts to Greenhouse button in the push settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i13.png)

If you only want to push a select number of contacts, launch Apollo, click **Search**, and then click **People**.

[![People tab on the Search page in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i14.png)

Apply [filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661-Search-Filters-Overview) to narrow your search. Then, click the checkboxes on the left of the contacts you want to add to Greenhouse. Click the **Greenhouse** drop-down and then click **Push to Greenhouse**.

[![People search in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i15.png)

Spoilt for Choice!

You can also manually push a contact to Greenhouse from their profile page in Apollo. Click the **More** drop-down under the contact's name card and then click **Push to Greenhouse**. [![More drop-down on the contact profile page in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i16.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i16.png)

You have successfully pushed the contact(s) to your Greenhouse account.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Pull Contacts from Greenhouse[](#toc_6)

You do not need to take action to activate pull settings in Apollo. When you integrate the two platforms, Apollo automatically initiates the first pull. Then, Apollo pulls any subsequent Greenhouse updates you make into your Apollo instance within 2 hours of an update.

What's Taking So Long?

Noticed a slight delay? It can take up to 24 hours to update a record in Apollo when you delete it in Greenhouse. So bear with us—we're on the case! Apollo completes all other pull jobs within 2 hours.

If time is of the essence and you want to ensure an update in Greenhouse reflects in Apollo without delay, you can initiate a manual pull.

Launch Apollo, click the **Integrations** icon, and then click **View** in the Greenhouse section.

[![Integrations page in Apollo settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i9.png)

Click **Pull all Greenhouse contacts into Apollo**.

[![Pull all Greenhouse contacts in Apollo button in Apollo settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i22.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i22.png)

Click **Pull now** to confirm the request. Apollo then pulls all updates to your records in Greenhouse into Apollo.

[![Pull now button in settings modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i23.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i23.png)

You have successfully pulled all the information on your Greenhouse candidates into Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## View Greenhouse Sync History[](#toc_7)

Launch Apollo and navigate to a contact's profile page to view their sync history.

Lost Your Way?

Need a helping hand to get where you want to go? Follow the instructions in the [Access Contact Profiles](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5995459280525-Contact-Profile-Overview#toc_2) section of the "Contact Profile Overview" article for the steps to take to get to the right spot.

Click the **More** drop-down and then click **CRM sync history**.

[![CRM sync history option on contact's profile page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i17.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i17.png)

Apollo displays all your sync history for the contact.

[![CRM sync history modal on contact's profile page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i18.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i18.png)

You can also go straight to the contact's profile in Greenhouse. Click the **Greenhouse** icon. Apollo then redirects you to the right candidate in Greenhouse.

[![Greenhouse icon on contact's profile page in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i19.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i19.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Disconnect Greenhouse from Apollo[](#toc_8)

To disconnect the two platforms, launch Apollo, click the **Integrations** icon, and then click **View** in the Greenhouse section.

[![Integrations page in Apollo settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i9.png)

Click **Disconnect integration**.

[![Disconnect integration button in settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i20.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i20.png)

Then, click **Disconnect** in the warning modal that appears.

[![Disconnect button in warning modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i21.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/integrate_apollo_with_greenhouse/i21.png)

Whoops!

Made a mistake and need to reconnect? Fear not, young padawan. Reconnect at any time you can! Follow the steps in the "[Connect Apollo to Greenhouse](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/13396898202765-Integrate-Apollo-with-Greenhouse#toc_2)" section above.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

It's Not For Everyone

Please note, you must be an admin member to access the IP whitelisting settings in your Apollo account. Access to this feature also depends on your Apollo plan. Please refer to the [Apollo pricing page](https://www.apollo.io/pricing#compare) for more details.

Enable IP whitelisting to restrict unauthorized access to your Apollo account and only give access to the specific IP addresses or ranges you consider trustworthy.

Apollo accepts the following formats:

*   Single IP Address
*   IP Range
*   Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR)

IP 101

Feeling a little lost? Here's a quick summary of what these terms mean:

*   **An Internet Protocol (IP) address**: This is a unique number assigned to your device or network to help identify it on the internet. There are 2 types of IP addresses—dynamic, which change automatically as you connect or disconnect from a network—and static, which always remain fixed. Note that if you enable whitelisting and users with dynamic IP addresses try to connect to Apollo after their IP address changes, they cannot access Apollo unless you add the new IP address or range to your whitelist.
*   **An IP Range**: This is a set of consecutive IP addresses within a local network or assigned to a subnet. If you or your team uses a VPN, contact your IT administrator for guidance on adding your IP range.
*   **[Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR)](https://aws.amazon.com/what-is/cidr/)**: Otherwise known as supernetting, this is an IP assigning system used by many organizations to increase the efficiency of IP address allocation.

Refer to the following sections to enable or deactivate IP whitelisting, and add or delete IPs from your Apollo whitelist.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Enable IP Whitelisting[](#toc_2)

To enable IP Whitelisting in Apollo:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Security**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/security/ip-whitelist).
2.  Enter the IP addresses, ranges, and CIDRs that you want to whitelist in the **IP address whitelist** field.
3.  Make sure you add a comma after each IP address or range that you want to whitelist and then click **\+ Add**. [![IP whitelisting field in IP whitelisting tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i1.png)
4.  Apollo adds the IP addresses to your whitelist and informs you if any other users in your team may lose access. To view any potentially affected users, click the word **user**. [![Blocked users warning banner](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i2.png)
5.  Apollo then displays the details of any users that may be blocked if you don't add them to your whitelist. [![Blocked users warning pop-up](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i3.png)
6.  To add missing IPs, click the **Copy** icon, then paste them into the **IP address whitelist** field and click **\+ Add**. [![Copy icon](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i4.png)
7.  To search for an IP address on your whitelist, type the IP into the **IP address search bar**. [![IP whitelist search bar](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i5.png)
8.  Click the **trash can** icon next to an IP address or range that you want to delete. Then, click **Delete** in the warning pop-up to continue. [![Trash can icon](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i6.png)
9.  When you're ready to activate IP whitelisting in Apollo, click the **Enable IP whitelisting** toggle. [![Enable IP whitelisting toggle](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i7.png)
10.  Apollo warns you if it detects any users that may lose access when you enable IP whitelisting. To continue, click **Enable**. [![Enable button in warning pop-up](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i8.png)

You have enabled IP whitelisting in Apollo. Only users who try to access your account from one of the whitelisted IP addresses, ranges, or CIDRs can now successfully enter Apollo.

If you are an admin, repeat the steps above any time you want to add or delete IPs from your whitelist.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Deactivate IP whitelisting[](#toc_3)

To deactivate IP whitelisting for your Apollo account:

1.  Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Security**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/security/ip-whitelist).
2.  Click the **Enable IP whitelisting** toggle in the **IP whitelisting** tab. [![Enable IP whitelisting toggle](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i7.png)
3.  Click **Disable** to confirm your choice. [![Disable button in warning modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/enable_ip_whitelisting_in_apollo/i9.png)

You have now deactivated IP whitelisting in Apollo.

If you experienced unexpected behavior or errors in Apollo, a few troubleshooting steps can help resolve the problem.

Check out the following sections to troubleshoot unexpected behavior in Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Refresh Your Browser[](#toc_1)

Refresh your browser to clear the cache for a specific page. On Mac, press `Command+Shift+R`. On PC, press `Ctrl+F5`.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Update Your Browser[](#toc_2)

Check to see if your browser is up-to-date:

1.  If you use Google Chrome, type `chrome://settings/help` in the **Search** bar. Check if the browser is up-to-date.
2.  If your browser isn't up-to-date, update it and then relaunch the browser.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Restart Your Browser[](#toc_3)

If your browser is up-to-date, and refreshing doesn't resolve the issue, restart the browser.

Save your work before you close the browser.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Check for Duplicate Tabs[](#toc_4)

Double-check that there is only one Apollo instance running in your browser. If you have more than one Apollo tab open, try closing all but one.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Check Browser Extensions[](#toc_5)

There may bea a issue between Apollo and another extension on your browser. The following extensions are known to interfere with Apollo:

*   Ghostery
*   Grammar.ly
*   CirrusInsights
*   Salesforce IQ
*   Outreach.io
*   Persist IQ

Compatibility Issues

If you experience compatibility issues with an extension, we recommend that you temporarily turn off or remove the extension. Alternatively, you can use Apollo in a separate browser profile that doesn't include the extension.

You can test each extension that you're running to identify if there's an issue:

1.  Open Chrome and type `chrome://extensions` into the **Search** bar.
2.  Click **Details**.
3.  Scroll to Allow in Incognito and click to enable the toggle.
4.  Open [Apollo](https://app.apollo.io/#/login?redirectTo=https%3A%2F%2Fapp.apollo.io%2F%23%2F) in a new **incognito** window and log in.
5.  Sign in to your Gmail account or your CRM. If it works, one of your other Chrome extensions is likely causing the issue.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Contact Apollo[](#toc_6)

If none of the steps above resolve the issue, [reach out to Apollo support](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/25851069527693-Reach-out-to-Apollo-Support).

Speed Up the Troubleshooting Process

Take a screenshot of any errors you encounter in Apollo. You can also check for errors in Google Chrome's JavaScript Console. When you're on the page with unexpected behavior, open the console with `Command+Option+J` on Mac or `Shift+CTRL+J` on PC. Click **Console** and take a screenshot. Include your screenshots when you reach out to Apollo support.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Single sign-on (SSO) is an authentication method that allows you and your team to securely log into multiple apps and sites with just one set of credentials. If your team uses SSO authentication, you can configure the settings to set up SSO for your Apollo account.

Got Admin Superpowers?

Please note, only users with Okta and Apollo admin access can set up the SSO integration. If you are not an admin for either account, please share this article with a team member who has the necessary permissions to follow the steps below.

### Supported Features[](#toc_2)

The Okta/Apollo.io SAML integration currently supports the following features:

*   SP-initiated SSO
*   IdP-initiated SSO

For more information on the listed features, visit the [Okta Glossary](hhttps://help.okta.com/en-us/Content/Topics/Reference/glossary.htm).

Supported Identity Providers

Please note, Apollo currently only supports SAML integrations via Okta. If you use another identity provider to manage SSO authentication, stay tuned for further updates as we continue to improve our SSO integration.

Refer to the sections below for the steps to configure your SSO settings, assign users to Apollo in Okta, and then log into Apollo via SSO.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Configure the Single Sign-on Settings[](#toc_3)

It's the SSO Way or the Highway!

Please note, when you configure SSO, you and your team can only log into Apollo via SSO. If you try to log in via another method, Apollo redirects you to the SSO sign-in modal.

Launch Apollo, click **Settings**, and then click **Integrations**.

[![Integrations page in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i10.png)

Scroll to **Single Sign-On** and click **Connect**.

[![Connect SSO button on integrations page](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i11.png)

Select **Okta** in the **Identity provider name** drop-down.

[![Identity provider name drop-down](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i31.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i31.png)

Copy the Apollo entity ID and Single Sign-on URL.

[![Apollo entity ID and SSO URL](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i13.png)

**Keep this tab open** and launch Okta in another tab. Click **Applications**, and then click **Browse App Catalog**.

[![Applications tab in Okta](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i32.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i32.png)

Search for Apollo.io and click on it.

[![Apollo.io app in Okta search bar](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i33.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i33.png)

Then, click **Add Integration**.

[![Add integration button in Okta](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i34.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i34.png)

Customize the name if you want to and then click **Done**.

[![Done button in Okta](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i35.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i35.png)

Next, click the **Sign On** tab in the Apollo.io SAML app.

[![Sign-on tab in Okta](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i36.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i36.png)

Scroll down to **Advanced Sign-on Settings** and paste the "Apollo entity ID" that you copied in Apollo earlier into the **SP Entity ID** field.

[![SP Entity ID field in Okta](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i37.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i37.png)

Scroll to **Credentials Details** and click the **Application username format** drop-down. Then, select **Email** and click **Save**.

[![Application username format drop-down in Okta](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i38.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i38.png)

Scroll to **Metadata details** and copy the text in the **Sign on URL** and **Issuer** fields.

[![Metadata details in Okta](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i39.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i39.png)

Then, click **Download** to download and copy the **Signing Certificate** text.

[![Download button next to signing certificate](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i40.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i40.png)

Switch back to Apollo and paste the **Sign on URL** you copied in Okta into the **Identity provider single sign-on URL** field in Apollo.

[![Identity provider single sign-on URL field in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i41.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i41.png)

Next, paste the **Issuer** text you copied in Okta into the **Identity provider entity ID** field in Apollo.

[![Identity provider entity ID field in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i42.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i42.png)

Then, paste the text from the **Signing Certificate** you downloaded and copied in Okta into the **Identity provider certificate** field in Apollo.

[![Identity provider certificate field in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i43.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i43.png)

Click **Save & Enforce SSO**.

[![Save and enforce SSO button in Apollo](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i44.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_single_sign-on_(sso)/i44.png)

You have now configured your SSO settings in Apollo. Follow the steps below to finalize the process in Okta.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

When you set up SCIM user provisioning for your Apollo account, you can streamline the way you manage users between Okta and Apollo.

### Supported Provisioning Features[](#toc_2)

The Okta/Apollo.io SAML integration currently supports the following provisioning features:

*   **Create users:** Assign Okta users to Apollo.io and automatically add them as users in your Apollo account
*   **Update users:** Automatically push user updates made in Okta to Apollo
*   **Deactivate users:** Remove and deactivate Apollo.io users in Okta and automatically reflect the deletion in your Apollo account

The Exception to the Rule

Please note, if you need to change or edit a user's **primary email address**, you must unassign the user from Apollo first and then re-assign them to the Apollo.io app in Okta with the updated email. For more information on how to assign users, refer to the [Assign Users in Okta](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/12667892496141-Set-Up-Single-Sign-On-SSO-for-Your-Apollo-Account#toc_4) article.

A Pinch of Okta Wisdom

For more information about how to add or update users in Okta, hop into the [Manage Users Guide](https://help.okta.com/en-us/Content/Topics/users-groups-profiles/usgp-people.htm) in the Okta Knowledge Base. Refer to the [Deactive User Account Section](https://help.okta.com/en-us/Content/Topics/users-groups-profiles/usgp-deactivate-user-account.htm) if you want to deactivate or delete user accounts in Okta.

Follow the steps below if you want Apollo to automatically reflect the changes for your Apollo users any time you create, update, or deactivate users in Okta.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Apollo is committed to protecting [your privacy](https://www.apollo.io/company/privacy-center), maintaining security compliance, and keeping your sensitive data safe. As a result, Apollo automatically redacts sensitive information when you view email correspondence within Apollo.

This means that if you or your recipients share sensitive information via a mailbox you've connected to Apollo, Apollo masks that content.

[![PII redaction in an email](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/pii_redaction/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/pii_redaction/i1.png)

Only in Apollo

Please note, Apollo's redaction of sensitive information only applies to the emails you view from within Apollo. If you need to access the sensitive information Apollo has redacted, please view the email correspondence directly from the inbox of your connected mailbox.

Refer to the following section for more information on the specific data types Apollo redacts.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Redacted Information in Apollo[](#toc_2)

Apollo's advanced algorithm uses pattern and keyword matching to identify any email content in the subject and body of [your emails](https://app.apollo.io/#/emails) where sensitive data is present.

There are three types of sensitive information that Apollo redacts:

*   ID Numbers.
*   Account Numbers.
*   Technical Information.

See below for a breakdown of the specific information that Apollo redacts when you view your emails within Apollo.

Apollo currently supports redaction for the following types of ID numbers in the US, the UK, Canada, and India:

*   Passport numbers from the US, the UK, and Canada.
*   Social security numbers from the US.
*   Social insurance numbers from Canada.
*   National insurance numbers from the UK.
*   National health service numbers from the UK.
*   Driver's license numbers from the UK.
*   Aadhar numbers from India.
*   Voter Numbers from India.
*   Individual taxpayer identification numbers from the US.
*   Unique taxpayer reference numbers from the UK.
*   Permanent account numbers from India.

Don't see your country on the list? Drop [the Apollo support team](https://www.apollo.io/submit-a-request) a note to let us know if you're interested in ID number redaction for another region.

All Great Things Come in Secure Packages!

Want to apply other security protocols to your workflow in Apollo? Sneak a peek at [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20439872853645-Configure-Advanced-Security-Protocols-For-Your-Team-in-Apollo) for a breakdown of the security features you can apply to keep your Apollo account extra safe.

If you want to learn more about Apollo's commitment to data privacy and security, dive into the [Apollo trust center](https://trust.apollo.io/) for more details.

Some common reasons that customers lose access to their accounts include:

## Overview[](#toc_1) Data is the bread and butter of business at Apollo. As a result, Apollo takes data privacy and compliance very seriously and strives to be fully transparent about how it sources, collects, verifies, and maintains the Apollo database. At Apollo, data isn't single-sourced. The combination of its multiple data sources, proprietary algorithms, and data network of over 2 million contributors allow Apollo to provide the best-in-class data coverage and quality. Refer to the following FAQs for more information about data sharing when using the Apollo services. Please note that this article primarily covers data sharing with Apollo’s contributor database of business contact information, which is accessible by all Apollo users. For more information about Apollo’s other data collection practices, please refer to Apollo’s [terms of service](https://www.apollo.io/terms) and [privacy policy](https://www.apollo.io/privacy-policy). Looking For More? Have additional data questions running through your mind? Hop into the [Apollo Data Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/19331318468621-Apollo-Data-Overview) article for FAQs on all things data at Apollo. [Back to Top](#top) ## Data Sharing Deep-Dive[](#toc_2) | What Apollo Does Do | | --- | | Apollo _does_ leverage its large network of over 2 million contributors to improve the scope and accuracy of its database of business contact information and run verification checks that result in a better user experience for its entire customer base. Most of the data we collect from our Apollo users simply forms part of our verification system to check and confirm existing information in the Apollo database. | | Apollo _does_ verify data against multiple data sources before adding new information to its database of business contact information. | | Apollo _does_ make the most of its powerful engagement tools to collect and verify valid emails against invalid ones to improve the database of business contact information for all. | | Apollo _does_ take user privacy extremely seriously and is constantly working to [uphold compliance](https://www.apollo.io/company/privacy-center), [protect privacy](https://www.apollo.io/privacy-policy), and offer [advanced security protocols](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/20439872853645-Configure-Advanced-Security-Protocols-For-Your-Team-in-Apollo) for user accounts. | | What Apollo Does Not Do | | --- | | Apollo _does not_ read the content of email communications or manually collect any data from customer systems. | | Apollo _does not_ leverage user data for any purpose other than to provide services to the user and to improve our services (including the contributor database) for the benefit of all customers. | | When Apollo adds any new contact data from its database of business contact information, it _does not_ associate the data with any specific customer. | [Back to Top](#top) ## How Frequently Does Apollo Update Its Terms of Services?[](#toc_3) Apollo values its customers and strives to uphold market standards and exceed client expectations as it grows. As a result, Apollo updates its [terms of service](https://www.apollo.io/terms) as necessary with any core releases that impact its product offering, or whenever privacy or other regulations change and necessitate an update. By doing so, Apollo ensures that it accurately reflects its services as it introduces innovative new products into its prospecting and engagement suite. Apollo encourages you to regularly check its [terms of service](https://www.apollo.io/terms) to stay current on the latest terms that are broadly applicable to all Apollo users. [Back to Top](#top) ## What Data Do I Share When I Use Apollo's Services?[](#toc_4) There are a few ways in which you share data with Apollo when you use our services, including: * When you [integrate your CRM](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/integrations) or [upload a CSV of contacts](hhttps://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409161532045-Upload-a-CSV-of-Contacts-to-Apollo). * When you [link your mailbox](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/account/mailboxes), including when you [connect your calendar](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/apolloio-find-b2b-contact/alhgpfoeiimagjlnfekdhkjlkiomcapa). Some of this data sharing is necessary to access the full functionality of Apollo's [prospecting](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us#category-18201224845965) and [engagement](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us#category-18201371457421) tools. Whereas other aspects are necessary for the broader use of the product by all Apollo users, such as improving the accuracy and scope of Apollo’s [database of business contact information](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/19331318468621-Apollo-Data-Overview). This results in a better user experience and more value for all customers. Refer to the following tables for more information about each of the main ways in which you share data with Apollo. **CRM and CSV Upload** | Key Benefits | Data Sharing | | --- | --- | | Benefits include automatically:

* Deduping against your existing contacts and leads.
* [Bi-directionally](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412668783117-Bi-Directional-Sync-Overview) syncing activities between your CRM and Apollo.
* [Enriching](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4413921630989-CRM-Enrichment-Overview) any missing or inaccurate data in your CRM or CSV file.
* Porting over the value of the Apollo database into your own specific CRM instance so that you benefit immediately. | When you opt into Apollo's services, Apollo:

* Verifies business contact data from your CRM or CSV file that is not matched to data in [Apollo's contributor database](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/19331318468621-Apollo-Data-Overview#toc_2) of business contact information.
* Adds verified, non-matching business contact data to the Apollo database. No pricing, competitive, or other sensitive information is ever shared with the contributor database.
* Consistently updates and improves the Apollo database to provide you with the most recent, up-to-date records on the market.
* Consistently updates and improves your CRM contacts based on ongoing updates and improvements to the Apollo database. | **Mailbox (including email and calendar)** | Key Benefits | Data Sharing | | --- | --- | | When you connect your mailbox(es) you gain full functionality of Apollo's [core engagement tools](https://www.apollo.io/academy/how-to-win-more-deals-with-apollo), including:

* Automating emails and creating multi-touch [sequences](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409231193101-Create-a-Sequence).
* Calling contacts from the [Apollo dialer](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409140527757-Configure-the-Dialer).
* Coaching your team via [Apollo conversations](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8274034041997-Set-Up-Conversations-in-Apollo).
* Analyzing your outreach performance and leveraging actionable data with [Apollo analytics](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4410826842381-Build-and-Access-Reports-In-Apollo).
* Empowering your prospects to proactively [schedule meetings](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173-Manage-Your-Meetings-in-Apollo) with you.
* Eliminating friction between third-party platforms and reducing the risk of no-shows with automated meeting reminders.
* Gaining [valuable insights](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423692649101-Use-the-Apollo-Chrome-Extension-in-Google-Calendar) on your meeting guests directly from your calendar. | When you opt into Apollo's services, Apollo:

* Needs access to your mailbox (including email and calendar) to provide you with the full functionality of the Apollo engagement suite.
* May use automated algorithms to extract business contact information to improve and grow the Apollo database. This data is most commonly used as part of our verification process to confirm information that already exists in our database.
* May use automated algorithms to extract aggregate technology information about companies you communicate with. This does not involve the collection or use of any personal information.
* May use IP addresses or other metadata collected or inferred by us in the course of delivering emails to improve Apollo services.
* Only adds new business contact information to the Apollo database if it has been verified against multiple data sources to identify the best source of truth.
* Never ties business contact data that's added to its database to a specific customer, given that Apollo verifies data across multiple sources. | [Back to Top](#top) ## Can I opt out of data sharing at Apollo?[](#toc_5) Unless otherwise agreed with Apollo, the Apollo services contain the data sharing elements described in this article. Please reach out to [the Apollo Sales team](https://apollo.na.chilipiper.com/router/sales_router?leadsource=Inbound&lead_source_details__c=KnowledgeBase) if you want to discuss whether a custom plan that excludes these data sharing elements could be a good fit for your company. If you connect your [mailbox](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409127806093-Link-Your-Mailbox-to-Apollo-io), [calendar](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423692649101-Use-the-Apollo-Chrome-Extension-in-Google-Calendar), or [CRM](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412668783117-Bi-Directional-Sync-Overview) with Apollo or [upload a CSV of contacts](hhttps://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409161532045-Upload-a-CSV-of-Contacts-to-Apollo), it is because you use Apollo for data enrichment, prospecting, engagement, or sales intelligence. When you opt into these services, you agree to Apollo's [terms of service](https://www.apollo.io/terms) and become part of its network of over [2 million data contributors](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/19331318468621-Apollo-Data-Overview#toc_2). As a result, you can take key go-to-market actions like automating emails, creating templates, viewing open rates, attributing success to your booked meetings, viewing job changes, setting up the bi-directional sync of data between your CRM and the data in Apollo, and much more. If you choose not to use these features, you can still leverage Apollo for more limited use cases. However, you won't have access to the full functionality and numerous benefits of Apollo's entire product offering. As a result, you would miss out on a lot of the value gained from Apollo’s enrichment and engagement functionality. Privacy and Welfare Always Come First It's important to note that when you opt into Apollo's contributor network, Apollo takes your privacy and welfare extremely seriously. ## Overview[](#toc_1)

Data is the bread and butter of business at Apollo. As a result, Apollo takes data privacy and compliance very seriously and strives to be fully transparent about how it sources, collects, verifies, and maintains the Apollo database.

Have burning questions about Apollo data? You're in the right spot! Refer to the following sections for more information on all things data at Apollo.

## How Is Apollo Data Sourced and Collected?[](#toc_2)

Apollo collects and verifies data against multiple data sources to identify the best source of truth. There are 4 main ways in which Apollo collects data:

*   **Data contributor network**: Apollo has a strong database thanks to its large network of over 2 million data contributors that share information about their business contacts with Apollo in the course of using Apollo services. This means that Apollo can run verification checks against connected inboxes and CRMs.
*   **Engagement suite**: Apollo's powerful [engagement tools](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/10316295330573-Watch-A-Bite-Sized-Apollo-Demo#toc_8) enable it to track email replies and bounces to collect and verify valid emails against invalid ones.
*   **Public data crawling**: Apollo has proprietary algorithms that regularly crawl the web at scale, parse public-facing websites, and build a web-wide index of people and company data.
*   **Third-party data providers**: Apollo processes over 270 million records monthly from carefully vetted third-party data providers. These partnerships help to complement Apollo's already highly accurate and ever-growing database with additional high-quality verified data.

At Apollo, data isn't single-sourced. The combination of its multiple data sources, proprietary algorithms, and data network of over 2 million contributors allow Apollo to provide the best-in-class data coverage and quality.

For more information, refer to the [Living Data Networks](https://www.apollo.io/product/living-data-network) page.

[Back to Top](#top)

## What Is the Data Coverage on a Specific Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)?[](#toc_3)

The specific criteria of an ICP varies from company to company. The best way to identify the data coverage on your target audience is to [launch Apollo](https://app.apollo.io/#/people) and apply the [applicable filters](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412665755661-Search-Filters-Overview) to a search.

[![Search Filters](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/data_overview/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/data_overview/i1.png)

Apollo then loads the total number of records that match the criteria of your ICP.

Hold the Phone—What's an ICP?

An [Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4416471135245-Identify-Your-Ideal-Customer-Profile-ICP) is a fictitious company that combines the key characteristics that best portray your ideal customer. By analyzing firmographics such as company size, industry, location, annual revenue, and budget, you can more easily define the types of companies that you serve best.

**(Recommended)** Apply the [email status filter](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423314404621-Email-Status-Overview) to your search to find [Apollo-verified](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/10826699994381-How-Apollo-Verifies-Emails) emails.

[Back to Top](#top)

## How Does Apollo Ensure Data Is Accurate?[](#toc_4)

Lead data is Apollo's bread and butter. The Apollo team constantly improves and refines how it collects and verifies data to provide its users with a best-in-class solution.

Apollo's proprietary approach and automated multi-step verification process help it maintain a highly accurate database and keep records up-to-date. The secret potion includes:

*   A 7-step email verification process to identify valid emails within catch-all domains, verify data in real-time, predict email bounces, and automatically clean invalid emails. Learn more about Apollo's [email verification process here](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/10826699994381).
*   An automated, real-time verification process for direct dial requests. Apollo's proprietary algorithm runs the number through multiple checks using its large dataset to verify a number's accuracy.
*   The instant refresh of contact and company information every time a data signal, such as a job change or a new direct dial or email, informs Apollo of an update.

[Back to Top](#top)

## How Often Does Apollo Update Its Data?[](#toc_5)

Apollo takes data accuracy and compliance very seriously. As a result, Apollo:

*   Refreshes data in real-time whenever the Apollo system captures a data signal, such as a job change or a new phone number or email. This signal triggers the system to check for new data and verify its validity.
*   Runs monthly checks on its database to ensure that contact data stays accurate and up-to-date.
*   Regularly refreshes its database for individuals who request to opt out of Apollo services and from third parties who pass along opt-out requests from individuals to Apollo.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Why Do Third-Party Email Verification Vendors Flag Apollo’s Verified Emails as Invalid?[](#toc_6)

If you use a third-party tool in conjunction with Apollo, you may find that the tool flags some Apollo-verified emails as invalid. This is because the majority of popular tools use a method called [SMTP tickling](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/10826699994381-How-Apollo-Verifies-Emails#toc_1), which cannot differentiate between valid and invalid emails from [catch-all domains](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/10826699994381-How-Apollo-Verifies-Emails#toc_7).

Within Apollo's [7-step email verification process](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/10826699994381-How-Apollo-Verifies-Emails#toc_4), Apollo leverages its powerful engagement tools to track email replies and bounces. This means that Apollo can collect and verify valid emails within catch-all domains. For more information, refer to the [How Apollo Verifies Emails](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/10826699994381-How-Apollo-Verifies-Emails) article.

[Back to Top](#top)

## How Can a User Claim or Remove Their Profile in the Apollo Database?[](#toc_7)

Accurate data also means compliant data. Apollo takes opt-out requests and regulations seriously and has implemented the following practices:

1.  A clear, transparent, and consumer-friendly opt-out request process. You can learn more about it [here](https://www.apollo.io/company/privacy-center/). Apollo processes opt-out requests promptly to ensure its data is up-to-date with consumer opt-out rights.
2.  Once an opt-out occurs, Apollo deletes the contact from its database. Apollo then retains their email address solely to respect their opt-out preference and ensure they do not reappear in the Apollo database.
3.  Customers can and should filter data based on location. In Apollo, you can target your use of the Apollo dataset to certain locales, industries, people, or businesses where you have a legitimate interest in reaching out and where your reach-outs are compliant with local law.

Privacy Matters

Head to the [the privacy center](https://www.apollo.io/company/privacy-center/) if you want to submit a request for information access or request to remove your profile from the Apollo database. The Apollo privacy team will then take action accordingly.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Does Apollo Notify Contacts When It Adds Them to Its Database?[](#toc_8)

Apollo automatically sends an email notification to every new contact in certain regions—such as the European Union, the United Kingdom, and Switzerland—when it adds them to its database.

Subject to notification requirements, the email explains how Apollo processes contact data and informs the contacts of their rights.

[Back to Top](#top)

## How Does Apollo's Data Compare to Others?[](#toc_9)

Apollo consistently expands and refines its database to offer you the most accessible, trustworthy B2B data. To identify the best source of truth, Apollo collects and verifies data against multiple data sources as well as via its:

*   Network of over 2 million data contributors.
*   Email engagement tools.
*   Verified third-party data providers.
*   Crawling of public data sources.

Compared to other B2B databases, Apollo offers over 65+ data attribute filters so you can find and reach your entire target market.

Let's Go Head to Head!

For a data comparison of Apollo vs. others, refer to the "Battle Royale" section of [this customer story](https://www.apollo.io/customer-stories-overview/census).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Why Does Apollo Display Guessed Emails?[](#toc_10)

Apollo strives to help you connect with as many of your ideal customers as possible. As a result, whenever Apollo cannot fully verify an email but finds multiple pieces of evidence that suggest a probable email, Apollo marks it as guessed and indicates the confidence level. Apollo only returns guessed emails if the confidence level is 50% or above.

Use the guessed filter with caution to keep your [domain safe](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409225311885-Avoid-SPAM-Filters). If you don't want to include any guessed emails in your sales outreach, you can filter contacts by [email status](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423314404621-Email-Status-Overview).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Why Do I Have a High Bounce Rate for Emails Sent Via a Mailbox Connected to Apollo?[](#toc_11)

If you notice a high bounce rate from the emails you send via a mailbox connected to Apollo, you need to take action to lower the number of bounces and protect your sending reputation.

How High is High?

As a point of reference, if you consistently notice a bounce rate of 8% or above—cue the alarm bells! It's time to act fast to keep your domain safe and sound.

Multiple factors can contribute to high bounce rates. Refer to [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409227148045-Why-Do-I-See-Such-a-High-Bounce-Rate-for-Emails-from-Apollo-) for more information on the potential causes and steps to take to rectify any issues you may be facing.

[Back to Top](#top)

## What Permissions Does Apollo Need Access To When I Connect My Email or Calendar?[](#toc_12)

To access the full functionality of Apollo prospecting and engagement tools, it is necessary to link your business email and calendar with your Apollo account.

Apollo never deletes your emails or calendars. However, as providers like Google bundle all access as a single group of permissions, Apollo cannot request individual permissions for the specific privileges it needs to ensure Apollo features function correctly.

It is important to understand that when you link your email or calendar, Apollo may use automated algorithms to extract certain personal information from your email and calendar content and related metadata, which may be added to Apollo's contributory data network. However, this data is never tied to a specific customer. Apollo only adds a piece of data to its database if multiple separate users and accounts have the same verified information for that contact, account, or industry.

When you give Apollo the necessary access and permissions, Apollo can help you to:

*   [**Mailbox**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409127806093-Link-Your-Mailbox-to-Apollo-io): Automate emails, create templates and follow-ups, view open rates, and more.
*   [**Google Calendar**](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4423692649101-Use-the-Apollo-Chrome-Extension-in-Google-Calendar): Empower contacts to book meetings with you through the Apollo meetings scheduler, attribute success to your booked meetings, view job changes, and more.

For more information about data sharing with Apollo, please refer to [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409127806093-Link-Your-Mailbox-to-Apollo-io).
