## oops

## The page you were looking for doesn't exist

You may have mistyped the address or the page may have moved

[Take me back to the home page](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us "Home")

Overview

Dynamic variables enable you to personalize emails for individual contacts by leveraging Apollo's data and, in the case of [custom dynamic variables](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409494161677), your own data research. Advanced dynamic variables are somewhat different from [basic dynamic variables](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409415084813) in that they allow for limited conditional logic.

This means advanced dynamic variables can provide a fallback if there's no data for a specific field for a contact. Conditional logic helps emails with variables send successfully, instead of failing if Apollo doesn't have the necessary data to fill the variable for a contact.

[![Conditional Logic](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_advanced_snippets/i2.jpg)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_advanced_snippets/i2.jpg)

The following sections show how to use all of the different types of advanced dynamic variables supported in email templates.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables[](#toc_1)

Advanced dynamic variables come in several different flavors:

*   [Empty Fallback](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409735256845-Use-Advanced-Dynamic-Variables#toc_2)
*   [Dynamic Fallback](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409735256845-Use-Advanced-Dynamic-Variables#toc_3)
*   [Letter Case and Pluralization Operators](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409735256845-Use-Advanced-Dynamic-Variables#toc_4)
*   [Now-date/Time Operators](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409735256845-Use-Advanced-Dynamic-Variables#toc_5)
*   [Custom Date Operators](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409735256845-Use-Advanced-Dynamic-Variables#toc_6)

Each of these advanced dynamic variable types enables you to further personalize email templates for your customers.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Empty Fallback[](#toc_2)

Use the empty fallback advanced dynamic variable to send emails without fearing they won't send because a basic dynamic variable lacks data. With an empty fallback, your email sends with a blank space in place of the variable if Apollo doesn't have data for a contact.

Imagine you want to send an email that greets each recipient by their first name. You could use the `{{first_name}}` basic dynamic variable to say:

Greetings {{first\_name}},

However, if Apollo doesn't have a first name for a contact in your sequence, the dynamic variable fails and Apollo moves your email to the [Not Sent](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5403737512589-Why-Didn-t-My-Email-Send#toc_9) folder.

To avoid this situation, use the advanced dynamic variable `{{#if first_name}}{{#endif}}` to create a generic fallback:

Greetings {{#if first\_name}}{{#endif}},

If Apollo has the data for an email recipient, the dynamic variable renders in the email:

Greetings John,

If Apollo doesn't have the data, the email still sends with an empty space in place of the dynamic variable:

Greetings ,

[Back to Top](#top)

### Dynamic Fallback[](#toc_3)

Advanced dynamic variables with a dynamic fallback go a step further than the empty fallback variety. These dynamic variables insert text that you define in the event that there is no relevant data for a contact.

Imagine you want to use generic text if a recipient's first name is unavailable. To do that, use the following advanced dynamic variable to create a dynamic fallback:

Hi {{#if first\_name}}{{first\_name}}{{#else}}there{{#endif}},

If Apollo has the data for an email recipient, the first name renders in the email:

Hi John,

If Apollo doesn't have the necessary data, the email renders with `there` in place of the variable:

Hi there,

It's important to understand what each part of the dynamic variable does. The first part, `{{#if first_name}}{{first_name}}`, is the start of the conditional logic. It tells Apollo "If there is a value for first name, render that first\_name value in the opened email". This is similar to the basic dynamic variable `{{first_name}}`, with the inclusion of an `{{#if}}` statement.

The next part,`{{#else}}there`, tells Apollo "If no first name value is available for this contact, use the text `there` instead".

The final part, `{{#endif}}`, tells Apollo that this is the end of the conditional logic for this dynamic variable.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Letter Case and Pluralization Operators[](#toc_4)

Advanced dynamic variables with letter case and pluralization operators take the value of a field and change the case or the pluralization.

String Fields Only

These advanced dynamic variable types only work on `string` field types. They don't work for other field types.

The following examples show how letter case and pluralization operators can be used:

| Dynamic Variables | Description | Example |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `{{title->lowercase}}` | Takes the value of a contact's job title and converts every letter in it to lowercase. | `Engineering Manager` becomes `engineering manager` |
| `{{title->capitalize_each_word}}` | Takes the value of a contact's job title and converts the first letter in every word to uppercase. | `engineering manager` becomes `Engineering Manager` |
| `{{title->plural}}` | Takes the value of a contact's job title and converts it to the plural form. | `Engineering Manager` becomes `Engineering Managers` |

Add a `->` within the variable to combine multiple case and pluralization operators. For example, to convert a contact's job title to uppercase and plural form, combine the operators within the same variable:

{{title->capitalize\_each\_word->plural}}

This dynamic variable renders the job title `engineering manager` as `Engineering Managers`.

[Back to Top](#top)

### Now-Date/Time Operators[](#toc_5)

Advanced dynamic variables with `{{now_month}}`, `{{now_day}}`, and `{{now_time}}` operators take the current date and manipulate it in various ways.

Date-Type Fields Only

These advanced dynamic variable types only work on `date` field types. They don't work for other field types.

The following examples show how now-date and time operators can be used:

| Dynamic Variables | Description | Example |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `{{now_day->plus_X}}` | Takes the current day and moves it forward by the specified number of business days. If the number of business days exceeds the number of days in the current month, Apollo accounts for the transition and continues the count at the first day of the upcoming month. You can use any whole number (`integer`) here. | If today is the 15th day of the month and a Wednesday, the dynamic variable `{{now_day->plus_5}}` renders as `22` in the opened email. |
| `{{now_day->minus_X}}` | Takes the current day and moves it backward by the specified number of business days. If the number of business days exceeds the number of days in the current month, Apollo accounts for the transition and continues the count at the last day of the previous month. You can use any whole number (`integer`) here. | If today is the 15th day of the month and a Wednesday, the dynamic variable `{{now_day->minus_5}}` renders as `8` in the opened email. |
| `{{now_month->plus_X}}` | Takes the current month and moves it forward by the specified number of months. You can use any whole number (`integer`) between `1` and `11`. | If the current month is April, the dynamic variable `{{now_month->plus_1}}` renders as `May` in the opened email. |
| `{{now_month->minus_X}}` | Takes the current month and moves it backward by the specified number of months. You can use any whole number (`integer`) between `1` and `11`. | If the current month is April, the dynamic variable `{{now_month->minus_2}}` renders as `February` in the opened email. |
| `{{now_year->plus_X}}` | Takes the current year and moves it forward by the specified number of years. You can use any whole number (`integer`) here. | If the current year is 2024, the dynamic variable `{{now_year->plus_2}}` will render as `2026` in the opened email. |
| `{{now_year->minus_X}}` | Takes the current year and moves it backward by the specified number of years. You can use any whole number (`integer`) here. | If the current year is 2024, the dynamic variable `{{now_year->minus_1}}` will render as `2023` in the opened email. |
| `{{now_time_of_day}}` | Displays the current time stage of the day (`morning`, `afternoon`, `evening`). | If the current time is 9:00am, the dynamic variable `Good {{now_time_of_day}},` renders as `Good morning,` in the opened email. |

[Back to Top](#top)

### Custom Date Operators[](#toc_6)

Select Plans Only

Custom fields and dynamic variables that leverage custom date operators are only available for customers on [certain Apollo plans](https://www.apollo.io/pricing). If you don't have access and would like to upgrade your plan, reach out to the [Apollo sales team](https://apollo.na.chilipiper.com/router/sales_router?leadsource=Inbound&lead_source_details__c=KnowledgeBase).

Advanced dynamic variables with custom date operators make use of custom fields configured for dates and manipulate them in various ways.

Date-Type Fields Only

These advanced dynamic variable types only work on `date-type` field types. They don't work for other type fields.

Imagine you create a custom field called `product_announcement` for the date of your yearly product announcement that takes place on October 15, 2024. That custom field includes a month, day, and year, so you can use custom date operators in a dynamic variable to extract specific pieces.

The dynamic variable `{{product_announcement->day}}` renders as `15`, the dynamic variable `{{product_announcement->month}}` renders as `October`, and the dynamic variable `{{product_announcement->year}}` renders as `2024` in the opened email.

In addition, you could use the dynamic variable `{{product_announcement->weekday}}` to extract the day of the week for your custom date. In this instance, it renders as `Tuesday` in the opened email because October 15, 2024 is a Tuesday.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Example Use Case For Advanced Dynamic Variables[](#toc_7)

Formatting For Clarity Only

In this example, the text is formatted to offset the dynamic variables from the plain-text copy, and line breaks are inserted between each conditional logic statement for ease of reading. You should write dynamic variables in Apollo as a single, continuous line.

For additional context, take a look at a real-world example of how to use advanced dynamic variables in your email template. Within an automatic email task, we created an email template with body copy that leverages several different advanced dynamic variable types.

> Hi `{{#if first_name}}{{first_name}}{{#else}}there{{#endif}}`,
> 
> We know many companies like
> 
> {{#if industry == Marketing}}Company 1
> {{#else}}{{#if industry == Big Data}}Company 2
> {{#else}}Company 3{{#endif}}{{#endif}}
> 
> are looking for new tools to implement for `{{now_year->plus_1}}`, and we'd like to walk you through our platform so that you have a good understanding of our full capabilities. Does `{{now_weekday->plus_2}}` or `{{now_weekday->plus_3}}` `{{now_time_of_day}}` work for you?

[![View the use of advanced dynamic variables.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_advanced_dynamic_variables/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/use_advanced_dynamic_variables/i1.png)

**Use Case Explanation: Nested Dynamic Variables Pointing to Specific Field Values**

The `{{#if first_name}}{{first_name}}{{#else}}there{{#endif}}` dynamic variable sets up a fallback for the first name to render as `there` if there is no first name data available for the email recipient.

The `{{#if industry == Marketing}}Company 1` portion of the dynamic variable tells Apollo to render the text as `Company 1` if the **Industry** field for the email recipient is `Marketing`. If the industry is not `Marketing`, Apollo moves on to the next piece of conditional logic.

The `{{#else}}{{#if industry == Big Data}}Company 2` portion tells Apollo to render the text as `Company 2` if the **Industry** field for the email recipient is `Big Data`. If the **Industry** is not `Marketing` or `Big Data`, Apollo moves on to the fallback portion of the conditional logic.

The dynamic variable `{{#else}}Company 3` is the fallback if the email recipient's **Industry** field does not match `Marketing` or `Big Data`. In this instance, the text renders as `Company 3` in the opened email.

The final portion of the dynamic variable, `{{#endif}}{{#endif}}`, closes the conditional logic. Two `{{endif}}` statements are required because there are nested `{{#if}}` statements.

How many `{{endif}}` statements do I need?

As a general rule, for each `{{#if}}` statement in your dynamic variable, you need a corresponding `{{#endif}}` to close the dynamic variable.

**Use Case Explanation: Now-Time Dynamic Variables**

The dynamic variable `{{now_year->plus_1}}` tells Apollo to take the current year `2024` and add 1 year to it. When the recipient opens this email, this variable renders as `2025`.

The dynamic variable `{{now_weekday->plus_2}}` tells Apollo to take the current day of the week and advance it by 2 days. If Apollo sends the email on a Monday, the text in the email renders as `Wednesday`. If Apollo sends this email on a Thursday, the text will render the dynamic variable as `Monday` because it is the next available weekday.

The `{{now_weekday->plus_3}}` dynamic variable tells Apollo to take the current day of the week and advance it by 3 days. If Apollo sends the email on a Tuesday, the text in the email will render as `Friday`. If Apollo sends the email on a Wednesday, the text renders as `Monday`. Apollo renders the dynamic variable as the next available business day if the day of the week specified by the dynamic variable falls on a weekend day.

Finally, the `{{now_time_of_day}}` dynamic variable tells Apollo to display the current time stage of the day for the recipient based on their local time in their local timezone (when it is available) and renders `morning`, `afternoon`, or `evening`.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Every Plan is Welcome!

Please note that the data health center is available to all users, on all plans. The number of updates you can leverage depends on the credit limits within your plan.

If you want to use the data health center to uncover your total addressable market and identify market gaps between your data and the data available in Apollo, follow the instructions in this article to get started.

[![Data health center dashboard](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i16.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i16.png)

Read All About It

Curious to know more about the main benefits of the data health center before you get set up? Jump into the [Data Health Center Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/14570857378573) article for more detailed info.

Refer to the sections below for the initial steps to set up the data health center in your Apollo account.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Follow the Setup Process[](#toc_2)

Blessed with Admin Superpowers?

Please note that you can only connect your CRM and map your fields if you have admin access. Keen to start comparing your CRM data with Apollo's but do not have access to connect your CRM? Contact your Apollo admin to follow the CRM integration steps below. Then, jump to the [persona](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8862101479565#toc_9) and [account segment](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/8862101479565#toc_10) steps to narrow down your ideal customer profile while you wait.

Launch Apollo and click **[Data enrichment](https://app.apollo.io/#/data-health-center)**. Then, click **Set Up Dashboard**.

[![Set up dashboard button in onboarding modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i3.png)

There are 4 steps in the setup process:

### Import Your Data[](#toc_3)

If you want to make the most of the data health center, Apollo recommends you connect your CRM to Apollo. This allows you to check the health of your current data and compare it to the data in Apollo to identify key market gaps.

If you have already connected your CRM to Apollo and mapped your fields, you don't need to take any action. Click **Save & continue** to move to the next step.

[![Save and continue button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i4.png)

If you have not connected your CRM to Apollo, click the **Connect to** button next to the CRM you want to integrate.

[![Connect to buttons in import your data step](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i5.png)

Apollo redirects you to the integration page to connect your CRM. For more information about CRM integrations in Apollo, refer to the articles below.

CRM Integration Best Practices

Please note, when you sync your CRM to Apollo you can leverage the benefits of the integration across the platform and not just within the data health center. Make sure you read [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/7525314188173-Important-Information-about-the-Apollo-Salesforce-Integration) to set up the integration correctly from the get-go.

Don't Use a CRM?

### Personas[](#toc_9)

If you want to compare the right data and narrow down your results to take action on the contacts that best match your ideal customer profile, you need to create personas. This allows you to check the health of the specific contacts most relevant to your company and business strategy.

If you have already created and activated your key personas in Apollo, click **Save & continue** to move to the next step.

[![Save and continue button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i8.png)

[![Create more personas button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i9.png)

Will the Real ICP Please Stand Up!

Please note that this is a very important step in the setup process. The more specific you are when you create your personas, the easier it is to narrow down the data sets that you want to focus on. When you create highly targeted personas, you can better visualize the health of your data in the dashboard and pinpoint the specific records that match your core ICP.

For more information about how to create personas in Apollo, refer to the following articles:

### Account Segments[](#toc_10)

Account segments are similar to personas but for accounts instead of contacts. They are sets of key account filters that you can apply to find and target the right types of companies faster. Account segments include filters like company location, number of employees, stage, revenue, buying intent, job postings, and much more.

When you define the specific accounts that match your ideal customer profile, Apollo can narrow down the results in the data health center and show you the most relevant records for your company.

Click **Create more account segments** to create and activate your core account segments in Apollo.

[![Create more personas button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i10.png)

Give your account segment a name to make it easier to identify later.

[![Name field in new account segment modal](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i11.png)

Then, click the filter accordion next to the filters you want to apply to your account segment. Apollo displays the records on the right-hand side.

[![Expanded filter example](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i12.png)

Need a Helping Hand?

Click **Save account segment** when you have applied and saved the relevant filters for this target account segment.

[![Save account segment button](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i13.png)

Once you have created your core account segments, click **View Dashboard** to proceed to the data health center.

[![View dashboard in data health center onboarding flow](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/set_up_the_data_health_center/i14.png)

Now that you've finished the initial setup process, you can leverage the insights from the data health center to access your total addressable market.

## Overview[](#toc_0)

Inbound routers help you automate the process of scheduling meetings via Apollo and scale processes across teams and organizations. You can choose which meeting type your team's prospects can book based on their answers to your intake form. You can also redirect prospects to websites or present custom messages.

At an organization level, you as an Apollo admin can set up a single link that routes meetings across different teams or SDRs. This means prospects will always schedule meetings with the right people.

Admins Only!

Only Apollo admins can create inbound routers. Other users can be assigned meetings via inbound routers and view them, but cannot create them.

Customers on paid plans can create as many inbound routers as needed! If you are on a free plan, your organization's admins are limited to creating 3 inbound routers total across all admins.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 0: Before You Begin[](#toc_1)

A key function of inbound routers is to route scheduled meetings to the appropriate teams or SDRs. Before setting up your inbound routers, [create the meeting types](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173) that you want to use for this purpose.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 1: Create Your Intake Form Template[](#toc_2)

For the intake form, you decide which questions you ask your prospects when they schedule a meeting with you. Then, the answers determine the rules and actions that apply to them later in this process.

Each form template can be reused across your inbound routers as well as [round-robin meetings](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/9040988124173#toc_7). If you want to ask different prospects the same set of questions, add the same form template to the applicable routers.

[![The Create Inbound Router screen.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i61.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i61.png)

Prospects Become Accounts and Contacts

When a prospect submits your intake form, Apollo checks whether they are already a contact or account. If not, Apollo creates a contact/account with the information the prospect submitted.

To create your intake form template:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/inbound-routers).
2.  Click **Create**, then **Intake forms**. [![Create your intake form.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i75.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i75.png)
3.  Enter a name for your form template, then click **Create**. [![Name your form template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i76.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i76.png)
4.  By default, your intake form requires prospects to enter their name and email address. These fields cannot be removed from your form, but you can rename the question.
    
    To add more fields to the form, click **Add a question**. Choose from standard options such as company size and phone number, or create a custom question with your own input types. When choosing [routing options](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/17919970244109#toc_4), responses to custom questions can be linked to [custom fields](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4412498754445) you've created in Apollo.
    
    If you choose **Single-select** or **Multi-select** as your input type for a custom question, you need to provide answers that the prospects can select. [![Add additional inputs for your intake form.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i62.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i62.png)
    
5.  (Optional) If you add a custom question, there are 3 separate choices you can make.
    
    First, if a contact or account does not already exist, Apollo automatically creates them when prospects submit your intake form. Choose an option from the **Apollo field** drop-down to map responses to a [custom contact field](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/contacts/custom_fields) in Apollo. If you set up the [Salesforce](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4414469523981) or [HubSpot](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4416606988941) integrations and adjusted the push settings, Apollo might also push the response to the CRM field that you mapped to the Apollo field. [![Map your fields and choose to make the question mandatory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i70.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i70.png)  
    Next, to make a question mandatory, toggle the **Set as required** option on. [![Make the question mandatory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i71.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i71.png)  
    Finally, to hide the question from the prospect, toggle the **Set as hidden** slider on. Then, enter a URL query parameter and default field value to track meetings booked via this link. The URL query parameter serves as a UTM tracking component in the meeting link URL.
    
    This option enables you to track important metrics related to how a meeting is booked. For example, if you are adding the meeting link to your company's Facebook page, you can set the URL query parameter to `facebook` to track the source. [![Make the question mandatory.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i72.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i72.png)
    
    Salesforce Opportunities
    
    If you're using the Salesforce integration, Apollo also creates deals when prospects complete the meeting booking process. Refer to [Deals Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4415062467725) to learn how you can push Apollo deals to Salesforce to create opportunities.
    
6.  Click **Add** to save the intake form question.
7.  When you have finished adding questions, click **Save**.

Repeate these steps to create more form templates.

To edit or deactivate form templates, go to **Meetings** and click the [**Forms**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/intake-forms) tab. You cannot change the status of a form template until it has been removed from any linked meeting types and inbound routers.

[![Change form template status.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i68.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i68.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 2: Set Up a New Inbound Router[](#toc_3)

To set up an inbound router:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Meetings**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/inbound-routers).
2.  Click **Create**, then **Inbound router setup**. [![Create inbound routers.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i55.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i55.png)
3.  Enter a router name, then click **Create**. [![Name your router.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i10.png)
4.  Click **Select form** to add the form template that you created in Step 1. [![Add your form template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i64.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i64.png)
5.  Click the **Choose Form** drop-down and select the form template that you want to use for your inbound router. Then, click **Save**. [![Add your form template.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i65.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i65.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Step 3: Add Your Routing Options[](#toc_4)

With your intake form ready to collect prospects' answers, you can create rules and actions that determine which prospects Apollo filters to specific final destinations.

To set up rules and actions for your inbound router:

1.  Go to the rules and actions section of the inbound router. Here, you can choose from the following options:
    
    \-**If/else rule**: Create different Yes/No paths, with each path ending in a different action. For more details, refer to the [If/else Rule](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/17919970244109#toc_5) section of this article.  
    \-**Ownership rule**: Create a Yes/No based on whether a prospect is already assigned to account owners or contact owners within Apollo. For more details, refer to the [Ownership Rule](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/17919970244109#toc_6) section of this article.  
    \-**Book meeting**: End the path with the prospect scheduling a meeting. Choose from existing meeting types or create a new meeting type just for this path.  
    \-**Send to external url**: Redirect prospects to a landing page or other website of your choice. Prospects do not have the option to schedule a meeting.  
    \-**Display custom message**: Present prospects with a message that you craft. Prospects do not have the option to schedule a meeting.  
    \-**Default fallback**: Present prospects with a standard message across your inbound router. Use this option to display the same custom message to end multiple paths. Prospects do not have the option to schedule a meeting.
    
    [![Add rules and actions.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i18.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i18.png)
    
2.  For this walkthrough, Apollo shows you the simplest route—ending a path with prospects booking a meeting based on an existing meeting type.
    
    Click **Book meeting**, then **Link to existing meeting type**. [![Use an existing meeting type for your inbound router.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i25.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i25.png)
    
3.  Click the **Single-host meetings** tab if you want to send meetings to an individual. Click the **Shared meetings** tab to route to meetings with round robin or multi-host formats. Then, find and select the specific meeting type you want to use to schedule meetings. [![Choose between single-host and shared meetings.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i39.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i39.png)
4.  Review the details of the meeting type. Then, click **Add to router**. [![Add the meeting type to your router.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i40.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i40.png)
5.  Review your inbound router to ensure everything looks good. Then, click **Publish** to activate the router. [![Publish your inbound router.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i41.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i41.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## If/else Rule: Automate Your Meeting Routing[](#toc_5)

When creating inbound routers, the if/else rule is a powerful option that you can use to route prospects to different end actions based on their answers to the intake form questions.

The if/else rule creates yes/no paths, and you decide how each path ends based on whether a prospect's answers meet the criteria you set. For example, let's say you add the company size question to your intake form and you want to route prospects to different hosts based on their responses.

To do so:

1.  When you add rules and actions, click **If/else rule**. [![Add rules and actions.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i18.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i18.png)
2.  Click the respond type drop-down and choose **Company size**. Select an option from the value drop-down and decide whether your rule will match that value. Then, click **Save**.
    
    For this example, Apollo selected **is** and **5000+**. This means the yes path is for respondents that chose 5000+ as the answer and the no path is for everyone else. [![Add rules and actions.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i20.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i20.png)
    
3.  To finish each of your paths, select **Add rule/action**. Choose from the [routing options](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/17919970244109#toc_4). If you want to create more yes/no paths, add another if/else rule. [![Add rules and actions.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i24.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i24.png)
4.  Review your inbound router to ensure everything looks good. Then, click **Publish** to activate the router.

The if/else rule follows similar logic regardless of the input question. This means you can follow these steps to create inbound routers based on your needs. The following image shows what is possible when you add more paths.

[![Add more complex paths to your router.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i35.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i35.png)

[Back to Top](#top)

## Ownership Rule: Route Prospects to Account/Contact Owners[](#toc_6)

The ownership rule enables you to route prospects to their existing account/contact owners in Apollo. Use this option to create a single yes/no path. The yes path always ends with the prospect scheduling a meeting with the appropriate account/contact owner.

With the ownership rule, Apollo checks the email address that a prospect enters in your intake form to determine the routing. If the email address is owned by an account/contact owner, the prospect follows the yes path and is able to book a meeting with that account/contact owner.

To use the ownership rule:

1.  When you add rules and actions, click **Ownership rule**. [![Add rules and actions.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i44.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i44.png)
2.  Choose either **Account Owner** or **Contact Owner**. [![Route prospects to either account or contact owners.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i45.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i45.png)
3.  (Optional) By default, all of your account/contact owners are added, which means prospects with a matching domain can book a meeting with them. If you don't want owners to be available via this path, toggle the slider off for them. [![Choose which account or contact owners are available.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i48.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i48.png)
4.  (Optional) By default, Apollo sets the same standard meeting type for all account/contact owners under the ownership rule's yes path. The location of the meeting type (Zoom or Google Meet) is determined by the individual user's settings.
    
    To change the details of standard meeting type for all owners, select the **pencil** icon in the default meeting type section. To instead set meeting types individually, select an option from the **Meeting** drop-down for each owner. [![Change the default meeting type.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i47.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i47.png)
    
5.  Click **Save**. This creates your yes path. All prospects that are identified as matching an eligible account/contact owner will be able to schedule a meeting based on the options you selected.
6.  To finish your no path, select **Add rule/action** and choose from the [routing options](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/17919970244109#toc_4). If you want to create yes/no paths based on responses to the intake form, add an if/else rule.
7.  Review your inbound router to ensure everything looks good. Then, click **Publish** to activate the router.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Edit an Existing Inbound Router[](#toc_7)

To edit a published or in-progress inbound router, launch Apollo and click **Meetings** > [**Inbound routers**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/inbound-routers). Click the inbound router, or click **additional options (...)** and then **Edit**.

[![Edit an inbound router.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i66.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i66.png)

Depending on where in the inbound router you edit, click the **pencil** icon or the **additional options (...)** button and click **Edit**. Then, make your changes and either save or publish your inbound router again.

[![Make your edits.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i42.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i42.png)

You have now edited an inbound router in Apollo Meetings.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Delete an Inbound Router[](#toc_8)

To edit a published or in-progress inbound router, launch Apollo and click **Meetings** > [**Inbound routers**](https://app.apollo.io/#/meetings/inbound-routers). Click **additional options** (...), then **Delete**.

[![Delete an inbound router.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i67.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/create_inbound_routers_for_your_meetings/i67.png)

You have now deleted an inbound router in Apollo Meetings.

## Overview[](#toc_1)

After you configure your Salesforce integration in Apollo, you can view the **Opportunity** Stages as they are mapped between the two platforms. You can edit any unmapped **Opportunity** stages in Apollo.

Opportunity Stages and Salesforce

Please note, if you have integrated Salesforce with your Apollo account, Apollo automatically disables the creation of new **Opportunity** stages. Apollo does this because it is not possible to create or update **Opportunity** stages through the Salesforce API. The Salesforce **Opportunity** page is configured as read-only, which means Apollo can only pull this data from Salesforce. Apollo will reflect whatever **Opportunity** stages you have configured on the Salesforce side.

Refer to the sections below for details about how to view **Opportunity** stages and edit any unmapped **Opportunity** stages.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_0) When you integrate a CRM like HubSpot or Salesforce, Apollo lists the default contact and account fields you can map to the CRM. Fields that you do not map will not sync across Apollo and the CRM, so you should map all default fields to avoid data discrepancies. Additionally, mapping more default fields means your data will be more complete across both systems. To help with the field mapping process, Apollo offers recommendations for both [contact fields](#toc_2) and [account fields](#toc_3). You are not required to follow these recommendations. The following sections detail where you can map default fields and Apollo's recommendations for field mapping. Launch Apollo and click **Settings** > [**Accounts**](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/accounts/stages). 2. Click the **Default Fields** tab. ## Overview[](#toc_0)

Sequences are outreach campaigns with any number of sequential contact points and tasks that you can customize to personally engage your target audiences at scale. There are several types of steps available in Apollo sequences, including the ability to complete tasks in LinkedIn.

The benefits of using LinkedIn steps in a sequence include:

*   **Personalization at scale**: Create templates for connection requests and InMail messages and personalize your approach with [snippets](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/11509551262093) and [dynamic variables](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409415084813-Use-Basic-Snippets%E2%80%9D%20target=).
*   **Streamlined workflow**: Access a contact's LinkedIn profile with one click and document key information with ease.
*   **Improved performance**: Keep track of every task you execute and leave suggestions and prompts that can help you increase engagement.

Be Accountable

You need a LinkedIn account to see any information about a contact. You can use a different email account for your Apollo account and LinkedIn account.

Click [here](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?trk=guest_homepage-basic_nav-header-join) to create a new LinkedIn account. To learn more about how to prospect with LinkedIn, read the [Prospect in LinkedIn](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409229262093-Prospect-in-LinkedIn) article.

The following sections detail the LinkedIn tasks available to you in sequences and how to use them to track your LinkedIn prospecting efforts.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Understand the LinkedIn Tasks[](#toc_1)

There are 4 LinkedIn tasks you can use in your sequence. These steps create a task in Apollo that can be auto-executed from [Tasks](https://app.apollo.io/#/tasks) and the [Apollo Chrome extension](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409226637453). The steps include:

*   **View Profile**: View a contact's LinkedIn profile to gain specific information such as education history, job history, current company details, and colleagues. When executed, this step takes you to the LinkedIn's profile and marks the task as completed.
*   **Interact with Post**: Interact with a contact's posts on LinkedIn. When executed, this step takes you to the activity section of a contact's LinkedIn profile and marks the task as completed. Then, you can manually interact with a contact's LinkedIn post.
*   **Send Connection Request**: Connection requests allow you to direct message a contact and, in some cases, are necessary to see and interact with the contact's posts. When executed, this step automatically sends a connection request to a contact and, if it succeeds, marks the task as completed. You can send connection requests with or without a message.
*   **Send Message**: When executed, this step sends a direct message to a contact and, if it succeeds, marks the task as complete. A contact must be a connection on LinkedIn before a message can be sent to them, so this should be the last step in developing a relationship with a contact through LinkedIn. You only want to message a contact if you are sure they would like to speak with you. Otherwise, it will feel like spam.

When you choose to **Send Connection Request** or **Send Message**, you can create a template. You can also use snippets and dynamic variables to personalize outreach to your contacts. For more on snippets, refer to [Create and Edit Snippets](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/11509551262093). For more on dynamic variables, refer to [Use Basic Dynamic Variables](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409415084813).

Executing too many LinkedIn tasks at the same time can lead to your account being marked as a bot. LinkedIn temporarily restricts your account if you send too many invitations within a short amount of time, or if too many of your invitations have been ignored, left pending, or marked as spam by the recipients. Please be cautious and restrict the number of invites you send.

Types of Sequence Steps

For more information about the available step types in a sequence, please refer to the **Available Steps in a Sequence** section of [Sequences Overview](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409237165837).

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add LinkedIn Tasks to Existing Sequences[](#toc_2)

Shiny and New

If you prefer to add LinkedIn steps to a new sequence instead, refer to [Create a Sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409231193101).

When you combine prospecting with LinkedIn and the ability to track tasks with sequences, you can reach your goals easier. You can track each step of your LinkedIn prospecting process by adding tasks to your existing sequences in Apollo. To do so:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Sequences**](https://app.apollo.io/#/sequences).
2.  Click the sequence that you want to update. [![Update your sequence.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i12.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i2.png)
3.  Click **Add a step**. [![Add a task.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i13.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i13.png)
4.  Choose the LinkedIn task that you want to add to your sequence. [![Choose a task to add.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i14.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i14.png)
5.  Define the amount of time that Apollo should wait before triggering this step when the previous step is complete as well as the priority of the task. You can also add notes about the task.
    
    Use the advanced settings option if you want to automatically skip tasks after the due date.
    
    Then, click **Complete**. [![Choose a task to add.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i15.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i15.png)
    

The LinkedIn task is now added to your sequence. To rearrange the steps in your sequence, drag and drop a step to a different spot.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Add Contacts to Your Sequence[](#toc_3)

Now that you have your LinkedIn steps in your sequence, you should add contacts. The contacts you add will run through your LinkedIn sequence.

For step-by-step instructions on how to add contacts to a sequence, refer to [Add Contacts to a Sequence](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409396985741-Add-Contacts-to-a-Sequence).

One at a Time

Be aware that a contact should only be in 1 sequence at a time.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Execute LinkedIn Tasks in Your Sequence[](#toc_4)

With a contact added to your sequence, you can use your LinkedIn tasks to guide yourself through engagement. You do need to be logged in to your LinkedIn Account to execute your LinkedIn tasks.

To execute LinkedIn tasks in your sequence:

1.  Launch Apollo and click [**Sequences**](https://app.apollo.io/#/sequences).
2.  Confirm your sequence is toggled on, then click your sequence to access it. [![Check that your sequence is enabled.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i1.png)
3.  Confirm the steps in your sequence are also enabled. [![Confirm steps are activated.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i19.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i19.png)
4.  Go to [**Tasks**](https://app.apollo.io/#/tasks).
5.  Click the checkbox for each task that you want to execute, then click the **Execute tasks** icon. You will be taken to LinkedIn where the task will be automatically completed. If a contact does not have a LinkedIn profile, the task will not execute. [![Execute your LinkedIn tasks.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i17.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i17.png)

You have now executed the LinkedIn tasks in your sequence. A message from Apollo appears in LinkedIn to confirm the tasks have been completed.

[![View completed Apollo tasks.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i18.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/linkedin_tasks_sequence/i18.png)

You can repeat this process for each task until the LinkedIn sequence is complete.

Skipping Stones

You are not beholden to any of the tasks you create. You can skip any task that you do not want to complete.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Troubleshoot LinkedIn Task Errors[](#toc_5)

If Apollo encounters a problem executing a task for a specific contact, you will see an error icon in the tasks queue pop-up next to the contact's name.

[![Error icon in tasks queue pop-up.](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automate_linkedin_tasks/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automate_linkedin_tasks/i8.png)

There are a few reasons why you might encounter an error when executing a LinkedIn task:

*   You have attempted to execute a send message task before the contact has accepted your LinkedIn request. Apollo can only send messages to contacts that are already part of your LinkedIn network. If you see this error, try executing the task later once the contact has accepted your request to connect.
*   You use Sales Navigator. Unfortunately, Apollo's LinkedIn automation does not currently support automation for send message tasks if you have an active Sales Navigator subscription.
*   LinkedIn temporarily restricts your account if you send too many invitations within a short amount of time, or if too many of your invitations have been ignored, left pending, or marked as spam by the recipients.

[Back to Top](#top)

Yes, **Action Items** in your **Sequences** are subject to your sending schedule and are dictated by the **Wait Time** between steps.

In the below example, the **Wait Time** is 5 minutes. That means if there is no reply after 5 minutes, the action item takes effect.

[![Wait Time](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/faq_action_item_schedule/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/faq_action_item_schedule/i1.png)

Your Schedule

Please note, if you send an automatic email on Monday at 4.57pm and your **Sending Schedule** is Monday-Friday, with a **Wait Time** of 5 minutes, your action item won’t take effect until Tuesday morning at 9.02am. For more information about **sequence** schedules, please refer to the "[Create and Edit Sequence Sending Schedules](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409477927309-Create-and-Edit-Sequence-Sending-Schedules)" article.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

While you can always manually map stages between Apollo and Salesforce, you can also use automapping to make the job easier. If an unmapped stage in Apollo matches an unmapped value in Salesforce, then Apollo automatically maps the two together. Additionally, for Salesforce values that don’t have a matching stage in the platform, Apollo will create one for you.

Apollo will not overwrite any mappings you created before running the auto-mapping feature. Apollo will only automatically map stages that are not already mapped.

Refer to the sections below to automatically map contact, lead, or account fields from Salesforce to stages in Apollo. Keep in mind that the process for automatically mapping stages is the same for all record types.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Automatically Map Stages[](#toc_2)

To automatically map your Apollo stages to your Salesforce fields:

1.  Launch Apollo and click the [integrations icon](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/integrations). [![Settings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i1.png)
    
    Feeling Left Out?
    
    Only users with permission to edit the integrations settings can access the integrations page in Apollo. If you want to automatically map your stages, reach out to an admin to update your permissions. For more info on permission profiles, refer to [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4409154208269-Create-Permission-Profiles).
    
2.  Click **View** in the Salesforce section. [![View Salesforce Integration](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i3.png)
3.  Click **View** in the **Stage and Field Mappings** section. [![View Stage and Field Mappings](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i4.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i4.png)
4.  Click the Contacts, Leads, or Accounts tab depending on the record type that you want to map. [![Select Field Type](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i9.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i9.png)
5.  Click **Get Started** in the **Automatically Create and Map Stages** section. [![Automatically Create and Map Stages](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i5.png)
    
    Previously Mapped Stages
    
    Please note, if you have previously run the automapping feature, the **Get Started** button will display **Create & Auto-Map Stages** instead. The process is otherwise the same.
    
    [![Previously Mapped Stages](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i10.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i10.png)
    
6.  You will see a modal with additional details about how Apollo automatically creates and maps stages. When you're ready to start the process, click **Proceed**. [![Create and Map Stages](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i6.png)
7.  Click the drop-down and then click an unmapped Salesforce field. [![Salesforce Contact Field](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i7.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i7.png)
8.  When you're finished, click **Create and Map** to run the automation based on the selected field. [![=Create and Map](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i11.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i11.png)
9.  Apollo has now automatically mapped the field status you selected. Repeat this process for any additional mappings you'd like to create automatically. [![Mapping Complete](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i8.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/automatic_stage_mapping/i8.png)
    
    Unmapped Stages Without Matching Salesforce Values
    
    Please note, if an unmapped value from Salesforce does not match a stage in Apollo, Apollo will automatically create a stage and map the two together. If an unmapped value from a Salesforce field matches an existing stage, but that stage is already mapped to a different value, Apollo will not map the Salesforce field to the existing stage. Apollo will also not attempt to create a new stage and match the two together since that would incorrectly create a duplicate for an existing stage.
    

[Back to Top](#top)

## Stage Mapping Best Practices[](#toc_3)

To prevent stage mapping errors between Salesforce and Apollo:

1.  **Map all stages 1:1.**

*   Map each stage in your CRM to a corresponding stage in Apollo.
*   Don't map more than one stage to the same field in Salesforce.

3.  **Make sure the stage name matches.**

*   This is very important to remember if you plan to [automatically create and map stages](https://app.apollo.io/#/settings/contacts/stages). However, you can also manually map stages that don't share the same name.

5.  **Stay on top of housekeeping.**

*   Delete old or unused stages.
*   Move the contacts from the old stages into the correct, active, mapped stage.

Never Stop Learning!

Need a splash more of Salesforce guidance? [Check out the Salesforce section](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/sections/4409216721549-Salesforce-) of the Knowledge Base for more info on all things SFDC.

Want more context on how contact and account stages work in Apollo? Hop into [this article](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/4410623601165-Contact-and-Account-Stages-Overview) for a general overview.

## Watch the Video[](#watchthevideo)

## Overview[](#overview)

**Stage Triggers** are events in **Sequences** that automatically change the state of a **Contact** or **Account**. For example, you can set a trigger to change a **Contact's** stage to **Approaching** when your email to them is delivered, and then change their stage to **Replied** when they reply.

Refer to the steps below to create and edit different types of triggers.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Trigger Conditions[](#triggerconditions)

A condition needs to be met at each **Contact Stage** before the trigger activates. Refer to the list below for the different conditions.

### Email Trigger Conditions[](#emailtriggerconditions)

*   **Prospect Created**: The initial stage for **Contacts** when you add them to your Apollo Account. This is generally done with Lead Requests, CSV uploads, or integration with your CRM.
    *   The recommended setting for this stage is "Not Interested."
*   **Email Delivered**: A **Contact** receives an email. This is only delivery, and not to whether or not the email is opened.
    *   The recommended setting for this stage is "Approaching."
*   **Email Bounced**: An email to the **Contact** bounces.
    *   The recommended setting for this stage is "Bad Data" or "No Email."
*   **Prospect Unsubscribed**: A **Contact** opts out of email contact. This happens if you turn on unsubscribe links in your emails in your **User Settings**.
    *   This stage should _always_ be set to "Do Not Contact."
*   **Prospect Replied**: A **Contact** responds to an email you sent.
    *   The recommended setting for this stage is "Replied," but your success metrics may differ.
*   **Appointment or Email Marked as Interested**: You book a meeting with a **Contact** or they're marked as "Interested" in a sequence.
    *   The recommended setting for this stage is "Interested."
*   **Unresponsive**: A **Contact** does not respond, but you may want to reach out to them again later.
    *   The recommended setting for this stage is "Unresponsive."

[Back to Top](#top)

### Call Trigger Conditions[](#calltriggerconditions)

In addition to the conditions outlined above, the **Call Dispositions** you've set up can also be used as **Call Trigger** stages to set for your **Contacts**. Refer to the "[Create Call Dispositions to Log Your Calls](https://knowledge.apollo.io/hc/en-us/articles/5494331315853-Create-Call-Dispositions-to-Log-Your-Calls)" article for more information.

### Account Trigger Conditions[](#accounttriggerconditions)

There is only one **Account Trigger** condition: "When an account is created."

[Back to Top](#top)

## Overview[](#toc_1)

Each sequence in Apollo has its own set of statistics.

[![Sequence Statistics](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i1.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i1.png)

This data is divided into two categories:

*   Contact Stage statistics
*   Email Tracking statistics

Refer to the sections below for additional details about each type.

[Back to Top](#top)

## Contact Stage Statistics[](#toc_2)

"Contact Stage" statistics are available on the lefthand side of the sequence screen.

[![Contact Stage Statistics](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i2.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i2.png)

Click for Additional Details

Please note, clicking on an individual statistic will bring you to the relevant stage in your sequence's **Contacts** tab.

"Contact Stage" statistics provide the following data points:

*   **Active**: The total number of contacts who are currently in the sequence
*   **Paused**: The total number of contacts who are currently in the sequence, but are paused on a certain step
*   **Finished**: The total number of contacts who have either completed the sequence or met a **Mark sequence as finished** trigger in the sequence's **Settings** tab
*   **Bounced**: The total number of contacts who had their email bounce after receiving a message in the sequence
*   **Not sent**: The total number of contacts who have met a **Mark as failed when** trigger in the sequence's **Settings** tab

[Back to Top](#top)

## Email Tracking Statistics[](#toc_3)

Potential Data Mismatch

Please note, the totals in the **Delivered** and **Open** categories will rarely line up with the **Overview** tab and the **Emails** tab. This is because the **Emails** tab shows stats relative to the emails themselves, rather than the contacts who were emailed. The **Overview** tab shows stats relative to those contacts. It's possible to deliver more than one message to a contact in a sequence and this explains the discrepancy.

"Email Tracking" statistics are available on the righthand side of the sequence screen.

[![Contact Stage Statistics](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i3.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i3.png)

Click for Additional Details

Please note, clicking on an individual statistic will bring you to the relevant stage in your sequence's **Emails** tab.

"Email Tracking" statistics provide the following data points:

*   **Scheduled**: The total number of contacts currently scheduled to receive a message in the sequence
*   **Delivered**: The total number of contacts who have been delivered at least one message in the sequence
*   **Open**: The total number of contacts who have opened at least one message in the sequence
*   **Click**: The total number of contacts who have clicked at least one link in the sequence's messages
*   **Reply**: The total number of contacts who have replied to at least one of the sequence's messages
*   **Interested**: The total number of contacts who were marked as interested after receiving one of the sequence's messages, or accepting a calendar invite
*   **Opt out**: The total number of contacts who have clicked an opt-out (unsubscribe) link in one of the sequence's messages

Aggregate statistics are determined by the total number of emails delivered in the sequence. The overall sequence percentages are calculated by dividing by the total number of emails delivered. When you hover your mouse over the percentages, you will then see the numerical count for that stat.

[![Sequence Example](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i4.gif)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i4.gif)

In the example above, the 82.2% open rate for the sequence is determined by the total number of open emails (106) divided by the total number of delivered emails (129). Email stats in individual sequence steps are calculated the same way as the aggregate—dividing by the total number of emails delivered for that one message.

Where is My Mind...er...Data?

Please note, if you delete contacts from your account, Apollo reflects this change in the statistics header under the "Emails" tab.

[![Emails Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i6.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i6.png)

Apollo deletes the records of any emails that you sent to the deleted contacts; however, the “Overview” tab still displays statistics for every email that you have sent since you activated the sequence.

[![Emails Tab](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i5.png)](https://storage.googleapis.com/apollo-public-assets/kb_images/sequence_statstics_overview/i5.png)
